headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Molson Coors Brewing Company First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.Before we begin, I will paraphrase the company's safe harbor language. Some of the discussion today may include forward-looking statements. Actual results could diff
componenttext:
Welcome to the Molson Coors Brewing Company First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.
Before we begin, I will paraphrase the company's safe harbor language. Some of the discussion today may include forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from what the company projects today, so please refer to its most recent 10-K and 10-Q filings for a more complete description of factors that could affect these projections.
The company does not undertake to publicly update forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. You should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date they are made.
Regarding any non-U.S. GAAP measures that may be discussed during the call and from time to time by the company's executives in discussing the company's performance, please visit the company's website, www.molsoncoors.com, and click on the Financial Reporting tab of the Investor Relations page for a reconciliation of these measures to the nearest U.S. GAAP results. Also, unless otherwise indicated, all financial results the company discusses are versus the comparable prior year period and in U.S. dollars.
Now I would like to turn the call over to Mark Hunter, President and CEO of Molson Coors.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Connor. Hello, and welcome everybody to the Molson Coors earnings call, and thanks for joining us today. With me on the call this morning from Molson Coors, we have Gavin Hattersley, CEO of MillerCoors; Stewart Glendinning, our CEO in Canada; S
componenttext:
Thank you, Connor. Hello, and welcome everybody to the Molson Coors earnings call, and thanks for joining us today. With me on the call this morning from Molson Coors, we have Gavin Hattersley, CEO of MillerCoors; Stewart Glendinning, our CEO in Canada; Simon Cox, our European CEO; and Kandy Anand, the CEO of our International business; Sam Walker, our Global Chief People and Legal Officer; Brian Tabolt, our Global Controller; David Dunnewald, VP of Investor Relations; and Dave Heede, interim global CFO for the past 6 months as we completed our search for a permanent CFO. David is now transitioning back to his role as our Europe CFO as we welcome our new Global CFO, Mauricio who joined Molson Coors yesterday and is here with us this morning. 
Before our earnings call today, David and I will take you through the highlights of our first quarter 2016 results for the Molson Coors Brewing Company, along with some perspective on the balance of 2016. 
In the first quarter, we continue to focus in our First Choice ambition and on building a stronger brand portfolio delivering value-added innovation, strengthening our core brand positioning through incremental marketing investments and continuing to premiumize our portfolio. We began to see the benefits to our top line performance as we grew worldwide volume, improved core brand momentum in key markets, introduced fast-growing innovations in all of our businesses and achieved strong Above Premium growth globally, including in craft, flavored malt beverages and cider. We also significantly expanded gross operating and pretax margins globally and increased total company underlying after-tax earnings more than 28% while growing underlying EBITDA more than 15% versus a year ago.
At the same time, we completed a common stock offering in January to fund about 20% of the pending MillerCoors transaction, and we made solid progress in our planning for the integration of MillerCoors and the Miller global brand portfolio. Completion of this game-changing transaction is still expected in the second half of this year, and we intend to be ready to go on day 1 following the close. 
In brands, Coors Light grew volume 3.5% globally, including strong double-digit growth in the U.K. and Ireland and high-single digit growth in Latin America. In Above Premium, our craft portfolio drove from Doom Bar and broader shops portfolio in the U.K. and in Canada, Blue Moon Belgian White in the U.S. and in the U.K. and its sister brand, Belgian Moon in Canada and also the newly acquires in the U.S. In ciders, we grew volume of Rekorderlig in Europe and in Strongbow in Canada. In flavored malt beverages, the introduction of soda is proceeding well expectations and driving incremental Above Premium volume for us in the U.S. We continue to strengthen our business through improvements to our sales execution and revenue management capabilities. We increased efficiency of our operations, and we implemented common global systems. To ensure that our supply chain is fit for future, we completed the sale of our Vancouver brewery in Canada for CAD 185 million and we'll lease the brewery back from the buyer as we build a new, more efficient and flexible brewery. We also gained agreement to the closure of Burton South Brewery in the U.K., allowing us to further consolidate U.K. brewing operations. 
Regional highlights for the first quarter are as follows. In the U.S., underlying equity income increased 22.1% from a year ago, driven by higher net pricing, positive sales mix, timing of shipments and lower cost of goods sold. Coors Light and Miller Lite each gained share in the U.S. premium light segment for the fourth consecutive quarter, with both brands achieving flat sales-to-retail volume for the first time in MillerCoors history. Improved momentum for these 2 brands was driven by ongoing improvements to our consumer communications, which appears to our broad cross-section of men and women, millennials and multicultural consumers.
Coors Banquet remains the only national premium beer in category that continues to grow. In the higher margin Above Premium segment, craft brand Blue Moon Belgian White delivered another quarter of growth as the Leinenkugel's great for Shandy and a newly acquired Saint Archer brands. In FMBs, we achieved strong initial results from introduction of Henry's Hard Sodas in the first quarter. According to Nielsen, Henry's hard orange soda has the best velocity of any hard soda since the fourth week of its launch, and Henry's Hard ginger ale soda is the #1 ginger ale in this fast-growing segment. 
In Canada, we delivered strong earnings growth with our top line performance was lower in both volume and revenue per hectoliter. And brands Coors Light and Molson Canadian both had the challenging quarter, and we're taking additional concrete steps to improve performance in the balance of the year, which I'll discuss in a few minutes. In Above Premium and craft, Coors Banquet, Belgian Moon, Mad Jack Apple Lager, Heineken and Strongbow Cider all grew volume and share in the quarter along with our and craft brands. 
In headline financial results for the quarter, Canada underlying pretax income increased 25.2% in constant currency, primarily due to a timing-led reduction in distribution costs, lower pension expenses and results of our ongoing cost saving initiatives.
These factors were partially offset by the impact of lower volume and higher brand investments. Excluding the impact of the loss of the Miller brands, Canada STRs declined 1.6%. Including the Miller brands STRs declined 5.2%. Increased competitor trade spend and pricing activities, especially in Québec in the west region, led to overall softer volume.
In Europe, earnings were lower in the quarter, primarily due to higher brand investments and amortization expenses, lower net pension benefit and the termination of the Heineken contract brewing arrangement in the U.K. Notwithstanding our business, our business and our brands performed well across the region. We increased market share, and we continue to premiumize our portfolio and reduce costs. We grew our volume in 7 of 11 countries and for [ph] 7 of our lead core and premium brands in the region. In core brands, Carling, Bergenbier beer and increased share of segment in their primary markets. Above Premium portfolio increased momentum with strong double-digit growth by Coors Light on the craft portfolio, including Doom Bar and other Sharp's brands. Additionally, our cider portfolio achieved strong growth with the inclusion of Rekorderlig since the middle of 2015, and the full repatriation of the Staropramen brand in the U.K. also added to the solid progress made in premiumizing our Europe portfolio. 
Our International business improved pretax performance in the first quarter, driven by continued volume growth in Latin America, India and Japan as well as lower marketing and overhead expenses due to substantial restructure of our China business last year. Coors Light grew a high single-digit rate in international markets due to launch in Colombia as well as growth in our existing Latin America markets.
Now I'll turn over to David to give our first quarter financial highlights and perspective for the balance of 2016. David?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark, and hello, everybody. Our first quarter financial headlines are as follows. Headline net sales increased 0.1% on a constant currency basis, driven by 1.2% growth in worldwide volume. Including foreign currency movements, net sales were do
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark, and hello, everybody. Our first quarter financial headlines are as follows. Headline net sales increased 0.1% on a constant currency basis, driven by 1.2% growth in worldwide volume. Including foreign currency movements, net sales were down approximately 6% in U.S. dollars. Our net sales per hectoliter decreased 1.9% in constant currency due to negative mix in Canada and lower Heineken contract brewing volume in Europe. Underlying after-tax income increased 28.1% to $110.3 million or $0.54 per share, driven by worldwide volume growth and lower cost of goods sold.
On a U.S. GAAP basis, we reported income from continuing operations attributable to Molson Coors of $159.3 million, which is nearly double the prior year results. In addition to the factors that drove underlying income, this increase was primarily due to $110.4 million gain on the sale of the Vancouver brewery at the end of the first quarter, partially offset by special charges related to brewery closures. Please note that we received the cash from the Vancouver brewery sale on the first day of the second quarter.
Underlying EBITDA in the quarter is $263.4 million, a 15.2% increase from a year ago. We issued 29.9 million shares of Class B common stock from our equity offering in January for approximately $2.5 billion of net proceeds, which will fund about 20% of the $12 billion pending MillerCoors transaction.
Please see the earnings release we distributed earlier this morning for a detailed review of our business unit financial results in the quarter. Total debt at the end of the first quarter was $3 billion, and cash and cash equivalents totaled $2.6 billion, resulting in a net debt of just over $400 million, which is significantly lower than prior year due to the proceeds received from our equity offering earlier this year.
Looking forward to the remainder of 2016, our strong first quarter results were aided by the timing of Easter holiday and the additional days sales as a result of 2016 being a leap year along with relatively favorable cost compression in the U.S. and lower Canada distribution costs. We anticipate that the results will not benefit from most of these factors in the balance of this year. Other trends to consider for the last 3 quarters of this year include higher investments in our brands this year including a double-digit increase globally in the second quarter leading into peak season in the U.S, Canada and Europe. Incremental Europe expense with an annualized impact of approximately $15 [ph] million, which began in the fourth quarter of 2015 along with lower net pension benefit in Europe this year. A total prohibition on the sale of alcohol and expected the implemented by the state government in India in early April. We don't know how long this ban will be in place, and we expect this development to present headwind for International business results as this is our largest state of operation in India. Note, however, that this prohibition of has no impact on the business in India that we purchased last year. The impact of terminated contracts, which are now nearly all behind us and, finally, foreign currency translation, which at current exchange rates would not be a significant factor in our underlying pretax results of this year. This appears improved significantly since our February earnings call because of the recent strengthening of the Canadian dollar to the U.S. dollars. Given the recent volatility of our key foreign currencies, however, it is important to watch these rates closely.
Regarding 2016 guidance, all of the following matrix exclude any effects of the MillerCoors and Miller global brands transaction, the timing of which will have a big impact on virtually all guidance measures. For the full year, we expect cash contributions to our defined pension plan to be in the range of $45 million to $65 million in 2016 and pension expense of approximately $17 [ph] million including our 42% of MillerCoors contributions and expense. Capital spending of approximately $300 million, MG&A expense and corporate of approximately $120 million as we invest more behind innovation and commercial excellence this year. Consolidated net interest expense of approximately $110 million and underlying effective tax rate in the range of 18% to 22%, assuming no further changes in tax laws, settlement of tax audits or uncertain tax provisions.
Regarding free cash flow guidance, we still have a large number of dynamic factors in play in relation to cash use and capital deployment, principally due to the pending MillerCoors transaction and, therefore, we plan to issue 2016 underlying free cash flow guidance later in the year with the goal of removing some of the recent volatility to guidance that has occurred. As far as cost outlook is concerned, we continue to expect cost of goods sold per hectoliter in Canada and Europe in local currency to increase at low single-digit rate for full year 2016. We now expect 2016 MillerCoors COGS per hectoliter to be approximately in line with prior year. Lower-than-expected prices of the diesel, aluminum and as well as acceleration of summer our cost savings initiatives drove the change from previous guidance above the low single digits.
We now expect our international COGS per hectoliter and local currency to increase at the high single-digit rate for 2016. This is up from low single digits previously due to geographic mix changes.
We continue to expect cost savings for the next 2 years to be in the range of $50 million to $70 million. This excludes cost savings from MillerCoors as well as synergies resulting from the pending MillerCoors acquisition, which we expect to be $200 million by the year following the transaction close. Finally, here are the most recent volume trends for each of the businesses early in the second quarter, which are impacted by the early timing of the Easter this year. In the U.S. and Canada for the 3 weeks through April 23, sales to retail decreased at [ph] mid-single-digit rates. In Europe, volume through April 25 decreased low single digits. And our international sales volume, including royalty volume through to April 23 decreased our double-digit rate, partially due to the alcohol prohibition in being all, India. As ever, please keep in mind these numbers represent only a portion of the current quarter, and trends could change in the weeks ahead. Also, note that although we closed the pending MillerCoors transaction, we plan to discontinue providing early next quarter volumes.
At this point, I'll turn it back over to Mark for outlook, wrap-up and the Q&A. Mark?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. In 2016, we will continue to drive our First Choice for consumer and customer agenda in the geographies and segments where we choose to play. As we move into peak season this year, we are seeing additional competitive pricing pressure and w
componenttext:
Thanks, David. In 2016, we will continue to drive our First Choice for consumer and customer agenda in the geographies and segments where we choose to play. As we move into peak season this year, we are seeing additional competitive pricing pressure and we intend to step up our brand investment significantly, particularly in the second quarter. In the U.S, there has been a great deal of change in MillerCoors over the past 10 months. Those changes were necessary to create the foundation for the volume growth we aim to achieve by 2019. As we work to close a transaction, MillerCoors remains discipline, decisive and accountable for growing the business and transforming its portfolio and driving value for our shareholders. In American Life lagers gladness, we continue to gain momentum by the revitalization of our 2 largest brands, Coors Light and Miller Red Light in above. We continue to develop higher-margin offerings that can scale including strong early results in the launch of Henry's hard orange and ginger ale sodas and will introduce a cherry cola flavor later this year. We've also made a decision to offer our fastest growing line and Google's extension, great for handy in a year-round basis to strengthen the line in Google's brand family, which alongside Blue Moon and Belgian White forms the base of a formidable craft portfolio. In cider, we're broadening the Smith and Hard Cider, Smith & Forge Hard Cider by adding a bottle package to our lineup. We continue to deliver First Choice customer partnerships with our building with retail strategy, which leverages the higher velocity and broad appeal of American light lagers. We plan to expand this valuable tool beyond on-premise additional channels in the balance of this year.
In Canada, the restructuring of our brand portfolio was largely complete and gaining traction. In the first quarter, we achieved strong volume growth behind Coors Banquet and Pilsner. We also continue to see strong momentum for our craft brands and Granville Island as well as in our Mexican portfolio with and and the flavored malt beverages with Mad Jack. At the end of the quarter, we launched Mad Jack root beer and ginger ale, the first major hard soda increase in Canada. We continue to focus on accelerating growth for our core brands, Coors Light and Molson Canadian, as our biggest opportunity and challenge. Coors Light brands helped us improve behind our North American packaging update, which continue to roll out in first quarter along with high impact retail execution such as positive momentum and social engagement. For Molson Canadian, following another successful for hockey company in the first quarter will continue into peak season with strong programming and new communication that celebrates all of the rich qualities of our beer and our Canadian identity. Operationally, we continue on our mission to first choice for consumers and customers focusing on our sales management program to deliver brilliant store level execution across space assortment and pricing. In 2016, we will also continue to restructure our supply chain to ensure we are fit for the future. The sale of our Vancouver brewery for CAD 185 million at the end of the first quarter was a significant first step towards allowing us to build a more efficient and flexible brewery over the next few years.
In Europe, we achieved solid top line performance in the first quarter on the strength of our core brands and the addition of the Rekorderlig cider and Staropramen brands in the U.K. Our load increased brand amortization expense will present ahead and for the next couple of quarters will continue to invest in our core brand portfolio across Europe to grow share of segment. In fact, earlier today, we announced the signing of a global Carling sponsorship as the official beer partner of the English premier league. This sponsorship reaches well beyond Carling in the U.K. It allows us to leverage any branded any market with the most sports properties globally. We also continue to premiumize our portfolio with Coors Light, Sharp's portfolio led by Doom Bar. Ireland's leading craft brand consistent well COBRA, Rekorderlig and Staropramen and to ensure that our supply chain is fit for future, the plant closure of our broken site brew in the U.K. is progressing well along with the transition of production to a recently modernized Burton month brewery by the end of 2017. Our International business is focused on attaining profitability in 2016. On a cost and currency basis, versus 2015 foreign exchange rates when we originally made this commitment and continuing to accelerate our overall growth and existing in select new markets. Upon closing of the MillerCoors and Miller global brands transaction, we will integrate the Miller international brands into our portfolio and leverage a footprint in the complement our growth strategy and allows us to gain entrance into priority markets while increasing our business, scale and current markets. We also intend to continue to drive rapid growth for Coors Light in Latin America, including the high potential market where we launched the end of last year. Going forward, we expect the course Miller and Staropramen brands to form the backbone of our international portfolio. In India, we'll continue to add skill through our Mount Shivalik business, which we acquired last year as we developed contingency plan related to the BR alcohol prohibition. 
To wrap up. In the balance of 2016, we'll continue to focus on our First Choice for consumers and customer -- customers' ambition, all driven through our lens and with intent to drive total shareholder returns.
Now before we start the Q&A portion of the call, just a quick comment. As usual, our prepared remarks will be on our website for your reference within a couple of hours this afternoon. Also at 1 p.m. Eastern Time today, David Dunnewald will host a follow-up conference call, which is an opportunity for you to ask additional questions regarding quarterly results. This call will also be available for you to hear via webcast on our website. Additionally, in the next few months. we hope to see many of you at 2 events. Firstly, we will hold our Annual Meeting of stockholders on Wednesday, May 25, 2016, here in Denver. And second, we'll host our annual New York investor and Analyst Day at New York Stock Exchange in the afternoon of Wednesday, June 8, 2016. Finally, I want to offer a thank you to David Heede who has capably led the finance function over the past almost 6 months. So at this point, Connor, I would like to open up for questions, please.

componenttext: I think if you look away, we've been going with our portfolio. Our focus has been on developing the top end, and we're really pleased with the way that the Above Premium brands are gaining share in the marketplace. If you looked at our NSR in total, the underlying increase in NSR is close to about 1%, and the mix that we're talking about is really driven by 2 items. One is the loss of Miller and the other is the impact of our contract brewing revenues, which impacted top line but don't impact the volume. So I would focus on the 1% is what fits underneath the real performance.

componenttext: No. I mean, I don't have the most recent data for the first quarter. It will be out next week. I would step back and look at the health of the beer industry. I think the first quarter has the benefit, obviously, if an extra trading day. And Easter, broadly, this quarter has felt healthier then previous years, number one. With number 2, I would point out that the challenges in Canada we saw in the fourth quarter were limited really to Québec and to Alberta. In this past quarter, I think the most challenging market remained Alberta, but the rest of the industry looked healthy.

componenttext: The only thing I would add to that is I think if you look at what's been happening on a macro level within the beer industry and Canada that consumers generally are choosing to invest their hard-earned dollars in some of the higher price segments, whether that's craft or Above Premium and imports the exception to that really has been in Alberta we're obviously that economy is under a lot of pressure with what we've seen from the oil industry but not the similar to what you've seen in the U.S. where in the relatively benign what volume market the areas of real consumer momentum tend to be higher price segments like FMBs and craft.

componenttext: So I wanted to ask about Europe. I think the quarter had a pretty decent volume growth, but there were some timing benefits. componenttext: If you look to the top line results, Judy, then our volumes grew by 5% in Europe in the quarter, and that translated into just over 4% top line or net sales revenue growth if you extract currency changes. So we were very pleased with that. We think that's very, very solid performance. And to answer your question and give back some context, the markets in which we operate we're pretty much flat from a volume perspective. So in other words we can share and you will calculate that to be 0.6% or 0.7% share gain across the quarter, which again, I think is very solid. And I think, pleasingly, it's share gain driven by the majority of countries, by the majority of our main brands. And we also saw some pretty good trends on our premium brands. So overall, if you're looking for outperformance in the context of markets, good performance on volume, strong performance on revenue, good share gain and a good shape to the portfolio growth as well.

componenttext: And Judy, just to your broader question about Europe and the impact of MillerCoors, it's business as usual. We got a big business and it will be a bigger business in the U.S. we were a big business in Canada, we have got fast growing International business and we have a big business in Europe and we want all of our businesses to be focused on top line growth. The European business will have additional benefits of, in particular, the MGD volumes in the U.K. and Ireland, but it will be very much business as usual. And I think the opportunity is on an enhanced platform how we can lift and shift some of our faster growing brands. So brands like the Sharp portfolio Franciscan well and really leverage them and more broadly internationally. So very much business as usual. I think you've seen solid improvements, our competitive position in Europe and we'll continue to have that path going forward. Europe is a big part of our overall business, and it's an important part of our business.

What are Mauricio priorities now that he's the new CFO, and then Mauricio, you come from the experience from and is there anything special about that experience that you think pertains to the drop from Molson Coors?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So let me pick up Mauricio's job description and his goal-setting conversation, which will take place probably for the week. I anticipate this being a very seamless transition. We're delighted that Mauricio has joined our business. He's got great ex
componenttext: Okay. So let me pick up Mauricio's job description and his goal-setting conversation, which will take place probably for the week. I anticipate this being a very seamless transition. We're delighted that Mauricio has joined our business. He's got great experience in both development, developing markets and across the alcohol sector broadly. And I think we're going to be provocative and add his value in a number of fronts. So I mean, the short short-term priorities are pretty clear, and I think we've been consistent on that which is you've got to deliver a 2016 plan, make sure that we are delivering both top line, bottom line and strong cash performance and be prepared to go when the deal is approved and then subsequently closes in relation to MillerCoors and Miller International, and Mauricio is going to play a very explicit part of that agenda. It's really no more complicated than that. So if you want to say hi and offer any perspectives.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: With 1 full day under my belt, what I can say is I'm very excited to be here at Molson Coors, the company with outstanding people, great brand portfolio, and it's really a very exciting time for the company, and I'll be essentially focusing on furthering
componenttext: With 1 full day under my belt, what I can say is I'm very excited to be here at Molson Coors, the company with outstanding people, great brand portfolio, and it's really a very exciting time for the company, and I'll be essentially focusing on furthering of the strategy of the company, which is to delight the world's beer consumers with our products, as Mark said, offering hopefully some interesting points of view in terms of my experience in the spirits industry and formerly at SABMiller. That being said, I look forward to seeing and meeting most, if not all of you, in person at our event in New York in early June.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could also in Canada, and Mark or Stewart, I want to focus particularly on Coors Light and Molson Canadian, and what I'd like to better understand is why we're really coming around the corner because we've been coming around the corner for quite
componenttext: And if I could also in Canada, and Mark or Stewart, I want to focus particularly on Coors Light and Molson Canadian, and what I'd like to better understand is why we're really coming around the corner because we've been coming around the corner for quite some time with these 2 brands. And it sounds like you feel a little better but -- and I guess you're going to be spending more, so that in itself is real. But what are you seeing that makes you think that maybe it's not second quarter, maybe it's 2017? These brands really are in a better position than they've been because I appreciate you've been working hard on correcting the issue, but it's still an issue, and the U.S. is improving. Molson Canadian is not a U.S. brand of any size, but it's hard from where we sit, at least from where I sit, to believe that anything meaningful is going to change for those 2 brands anytime soon. So can you give us a little bit more on what's going on there?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me offer a little bit of context, and Stewart, do you want to just talk about the specifics, I think our building confidence. But if you look across our business, Mark, whether that's Coors Light and Miller Lite in the U.S, whether it's the wa
componenttext: Yes. So let me offer a little bit of context, and Stewart, do you want to just talk about the specifics, I think our building confidence. But if you look across our business, Mark, whether that's Coors Light and Miller Lite in the U.S, whether it's the way that Carling has gone back into share segment growth over the last couple of years in the U.K. I think we've got a track record of where we've seen challenges and our business continuing to work that challenge in place the right response. And I think the most recent trends in the U.S. on our 2 biggest brands demonstrate our ability to get focused through the right inputs in place, and these are big, big brands like driving an oil tanker. It doesn't turn around overnight, but you got to remain resolute and focused on the right inputs. We demonstrated it in the U.S. We demonstrated it in other markets. And honestly, we had a couple of misfires and some of our consumer communication in Canada. I think Stewart and the team have really got to grips with what's required now and feeling very good about the quality of our communications that we got in the marketplace. Stewart, do you want to talk a little bit about a few more of the specifics, building confidence as we go into Q2 and Q3, in particular?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. But actually, just Mark, step back one second and just say that as we look at our strategic plan 3 years ago, we really built out 3 big blocks. One was redoing our supply chain footprint. The other was lowering our G&A cost base, and the third was im
componenttext: Yes. But actually, just Mark, step back one second and just say that as we look at our strategic plan 3 years ago, we really built out 3 big blocks. One was redoing our supply chain footprint. The other was lowering our G&A cost base, and the third was improving our commercial capability and portfolio. So -- and those are relevant. Why? Because on the cost base and the supply chain the savings that we're getting from that have allowed us to start to feed the investments required to get the brands going. On the brand side, we're really focused on making sure that we had the portfolio that was right for consumers. And on the Above Premium, which is where we built up all the brands, we're performing well, and we're really happy with those brands. On Molson Canadian and on Coors Light, those brands sit in the mainstream. That is the part of the market that is under the most pressure. And if you looked at this past quarter, Canadian health share segment, our Coors Light did not. Coors Light is where our real challenge is. I've been pretty clear about calling out where the challenges are for Coors Light. Those being our need to improve our brand scores, our need to reach out to millennials and to engage those consumers more actively in our brands. I think when you look at the first quarter from a cost standpoint, our G&A cost went down. We spent some of that money back in the brands. So that's living our strategy. I think, against the brand itself, we saw finally the introduction of some marketing that is working. Our advertising is scoring better than any of the campaigns we've seen over the last 3 or 4 years. That's a positive, and then we're seeing an uptick in our brand equity. So those are positives. I think if you look at the activity that we have for the second quarter and the callout that we made in the earnings release and the script this morning, we pointed to the fact that we expect to put more money behind the brands, and that is because we have a pretty full activation agenda. We've got a full advertising agenda, and they know that we need to spend some money to get the energy going on these brands. So that's where we are, and I think you'll be in a position in June to hear more from us and to see some of that work when we meet in New York.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. One quick follow-up. Is there any history or what does the history say about the relationship between the U.S. and Canada for the brand Coors Light? The U.S. is seeing this improvement. Is there a historical analog to make you believe
componenttext: That's very helpful. One quick follow-up. Is there any history or what does the history say about the relationship between the U.S. and Canada for the brand Coors Light? The U.S. is seeing this improvement. Is there a historical analog to make you believe that you can get some tailwind, so to speak, off of that with this added spending you're going to be doing for the brand in Canada?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure whether there's a strong correlation between the markets just because the development of the brand has been a little bit different. But what I will say is that we've been working well together as a North American group to understand what driv
componenttext: I'm not sure whether there's a strong correlation between the markets just because the development of the brand has been a little bit different. But what I will say is that we've been working well together as a North American group to understand what drives our consumers. You will see us leveraging more ideas back and forth between the 2 business units. And in fact, here in the next few weeks, you will see us starting to use some of that U.S. messaging.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick questions. The first one, Mark, in very general terms, 10 months after almost 6, 7 months after we know the Coors transaction. Do you have more, the same or less conviction about the guidance of the $200 million synergies? So if you can answe
componenttext: Just 2 quick questions. The first one, Mark, in very general terms, 10 months after almost 6, 7 months after we know the Coors transaction. Do you have more, the same or less conviction about the guidance of the $200 million synergies? So if you can answer that and maybe give some color in terms of why. And then the second question related to these questions you have in global terms, after the transaction is closed, MillerCoors, the U.S. market is about 80% of your earnings. What about trying to diversify the regional profile of the company later on? Is that a priority or it doesn't matter at all? And reason I asked that is when you hear high solution them trying to sell their assets in Pole and Czech Republic, are those potential assets that could be for your company?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: To your specific question on the synergy target, I would say having done the planning, I'm more convicted -- or convinced, that's the right word with regards of number, but I don't want to talk in any specifics. I've been very clear once our planning team
componenttext: To your specific question on the synergy target, I would say having done the planning, I'm more convicted -- or convinced, that's the right word with regards of number, but I don't want to talk in any specifics. I've been very clear once our planning team finished all of the planning work we get deal approval, and we're moving towards close, and we can update more specifically about, I think, the games last November as you walk through the planning sounds good, and we'll update more broadly in due course. From your question with regard to the center of gravity that will be our business being the U.S., our overall strategy doesn't change. We will have a bigger position in the U.S. and as does many benefits associated with it. But we've been on a journey to build our footprint over the course of the last 5 years in particular led by Coors Light and more recently by Star a prominent that will continue. I'm not going to comment specifically on any M&A opportunities. We never do as you're aware but we need to play to win in both the U.S, Canada and in our European business and we need to continue to build our global footprint lead through our global brands. It's principally been an asset like license and export model it's likely that that model will continue as we look to take Coor's trademark, Staropramen trademark. In the future, the Miller trademark into more markets. That's probably all I can say at this stage.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mark here. Just a couple of comments. Firstly, Coors Light isn't available in India, so no issues there. I don't think has any plans to launch in India. The spoken to me about it, but Coors Light globally was up about 3.5%, and across Europe and our
componenttext: It's Mark here. Just a couple of comments. Firstly, Coors Light isn't available in India, so no issues there. I don't think has any plans to launch in India. The spoken to me about it, but Coors Light globally was up about 3.5%, and across Europe and our International business we are close to 19% growth. So what we've seen very, very strong performance as we take the brand outside of North America. Tremendous traction and velocity and growth in Central and South America, and so a brand, which has become our second largest brand in our U.K. and Ireland portfolio and has grown to well over 1 million hectoliters across the U.K. and Ireland. So it's in a number of international markets. I wouldn't describe as having a global footprint center gravity outside of North America, Central and South America, now U.K. and Ireland business and strong and growing momentum behind Coors Light brand. Alongside that, we've introduced Coors 1873 in a couple of market just to introduce the brand of Coors Banquet. And again, we've seen that perform strongly so we're looking to build up the Coors trademark and the proof-of-concept in Coors at 1873, I think, it gives us some signal as to how we can build that trademark more broadly going forward.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think we're in a great position because the positioning. The brand is very complementary. The Coors positioning is very clear in terms of being born in the Rockies and owning the whole sense of refreshments. Miller is much more of an urban positioning, MGD in particular. I think as very complementary to Coors Light and then Staropramen clearly operates with a very, very strong Czech and European prominence in really simplistic terms. Robert, we've got a great clear bottle offering and green bottle offering, but that's me probably getting out of my depth in my marketing skills. But the overall positionings of the brand are very complementary it gives us more skill in the number of existing MCI markets, and that gives us an entry points into a number of new markets as well. So our International business will scale up very significantly on the back off of this addition of our portfolio. And what they think will be a great back one of international brands and around of that we can then start to really test our ability to build some of the international footprint for some of our craft brands as well. So I think we're poised for the next phase around international brand development.

componenttextpreview: Sure. As you mentioned, it's relatively small part of our business. We launched around a little over 18 months. We launched Coors Light, but we have to call it Coors because of the laws there which where lights are low-alcohol beers only, so it's basicall
componenttext: Sure. As you mentioned, it's relatively small part of our business. We launched around a little over 18 months. We launched Coors Light, but we have to call it Coors because of the laws there which where lights are low-alcohol beers only, so it's basically the same Rocky Refreshment that Mark referenced to, but they call it Coors. It's doing well and we've got a really good summer season we just finished in Australia in March. And we're looking forward also at the Miller portfolio to that with the 2 we've actually increased our scale in Australia more than twofold with the addition of Miller. So it's something that we believe in the long run will be a reasonable size business as well as reasonably profitable business, and it's going to take a while to grow these 2 brands.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's a good observation, Robert, and I think we've led that way with development of Blue Moon in a number of markets. Obviously, got Belgian 1 up in Canada. Blue Moon has been in the U.K. and Ireland business for a number of years in this gro
componenttext: Yes, I think it's a good observation, Robert, and I think we've led that way with development of Blue Moon in a number of markets. Obviously, got Belgian 1 up in Canada. Blue Moon has been in the U.K. and Ireland business for a number of years in this growing strongly in the team multiple markets Australia's one of those markets Japan is another market. And interest from around the world continues to grow, so were already on that path and have been developing that over the course of the last 3 to 5 years, in particular, and we're seeing demand growing it. I think we're in a strong position when you look at the #1 Irish brands, the leading brand in the U.K. with Sharp's and our Canadian brands as well. There's opportunities for us to really build out that portfolio at international level, and that's essential to some of our international expansions thinking it this point in time.

componenttext: So thanks for the acknowledgment on the M&A question. I would just mention it, obviously, our definitive agreement with ABI is that those and our brand remains in our portfolio on the U.S. an eventuality 3 bases. So that's our portfolio currently and will remain in our portfolio irrespective of what's been announced last week by ABI and the CB divestiture. With regard to the Carling business in the U.K. and BRICS, that's as a great question. I think if you ask you'll probably get 10 different points of view. It's outside of our control as the consumer demand and the U.K. for Carling and our other brands, I think, will remain unaffected by whatever decisions made. The impact on currency and any translational impact I think is probably the thing that we're keeping our eye on at the moment. But I don't want any real demand patterns in the U.K. which is clearly what we're interested in. I don't know, Simon, whether you'd offer more color on that. Such a difficult one to call. Any perspective, Simon?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think markets. I mean of all the things we should keep on eye, it wouldn't be one of the things that necessarily keeps me awake at night. I just don't see it actually having any material impact on the overall demand in the beer market in the U.K. And I
componenttext: I think markets. I mean of all the things we should keep on eye, it wouldn't be one of the things that necessarily keeps me awake at night. I just don't see it actually having any material impact on the overall demand in the beer market in the U.K. And I certainly think, based on our recent trends of Carling performance in that portfolio in the U.K, we'd be able to withstand whatever effect that comes. So no, I wouldn't assume -- I wouldn't put that in any future model of any real importance.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure. To your point, Mark, I think we could spend a lot of time doing individual diagnoses on 11 different countries. I think the theme that I would point you to is, in general, we are increasing our investment in marketing, and those investments are
componenttext: Yes. Sure. To your point, Mark, I think we could spend a lot of time doing individual diagnoses on 11 different countries. I think the theme that I would point you to is, in general, we are increasing our investment in marketing, and those investments are playing out well for us with stronger volumes, stronger revenues and premiumizing that portfolio. And actually that's across all the markets. So, for example, I took Staropramen, we are investing in Staropramen across all of our European markets, and we've also repatriated that to the U.K. and we're investing behind it. It has given a stable digit growth almost universally across those markets. So there are always some puts and takes from the timing perspective in individual markets, but the general strategy of investing behind our core brands and investing in premiumization is working at the aggregate level in Europe. And any countries that isn't true in this quarter might be confident we could continue to drive those countries back to the norm. So I don't think there's actually as much variation as perhaps you might be pointing to. I think over all our strategy is just working in aggregate.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me give you just a couple of comments on that. Obviously, selling alcohol is something that comes with significant obligations, and we are in all of our markets very, very careful about the way that we both introduce market brands. FMBs have been a bi
componenttext: Let me give you just a couple of comments on that. Obviously, selling alcohol is something that comes with significant obligations, and we are in all of our markets very, very careful about the way that we both introduce market brands. FMBs have been a big part of our business for the last couple of decades. Back in the U.K. mid-90s launched a brand, which was one of the forerunners of the FMB category, and it's been part of our businesses in a couple of decades so we are very careful, very responsible very clear about the fact that that these are adult drinks clearly marked as adult drinks, and we'll continue to comply with all regulations in all of our markets to build our portfolio responsibly. I think beyond that, it's probably not worth getting into any specifics. That's just our general philosophy in our business.

componenttext: Gavin, I realize on the Miller's made the call earlier today, but 2 very quick ones for you. So is the industry, traditionally, we increase prices in the fall and most of it companies would follow. Has the industry changed in that regard? And what happened really with that price increase in the fall, did it stake or not? That's the first question. The second one in the earlier call, you said that pricing ex mix was up 0.8% for the MillerCoors portfolio. can you give us some nuance there in terms of what was increased in the value brands compared to, say, mainstream? It seems to me like value pricing might have come down, if you could explain that. And then the third and last question. I think that Miller High Life, in my opinion, in a very unique position within your value portfolio and one we think that it's may be stuck between mainstream and value, and there's an opportunity for you to have a very strong value brand if Miller High Life were to trend down pricewise into fully the value segment as opposed to what seems to be happening there is moving up in mainstream. If you could comment on that, Gavin.

componenttext: Right. I mean it's a little difficult for me to give you detailed specifics, as Marks says. From an industry pricing point of view, price increases take place in the fall and take place in the spring. Personal general one-size-fits-all. And as I said quite often on these calls is we follow clear pricing strategies in the market by market and brand by brand basis. Your second question around breaking out the 80 basis points between the various subsegments is we just simply don't do that publicly. And from a Miller High Life point of view, we do think you got any proposition year as the champagne appears and then we intend to continue to enlist quite strongly behind that brand. It's an important part of our premium portfolio and will play an important role in reducing the last market share that we've experienced in the portfolio. Beyond that, I can't give you any more detail.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I'd add is if you look at the choice in the U.S. market, there's more proliferation, more choice for consumers that we've seen in living memory. So our job is to make sure our brand delivers great value for consumers, and we'll make sure we
componenttext: The only thing I'd add is if you look at the choice in the U.S. market, there's more proliferation, more choice for consumers that we've seen in living memory. So our job is to make sure our brand delivers great value for consumers, and we'll make sure we do that through a combination of our price points, SKUs that we offer, the quality of our brand communications. We've got to be competitive and as I say consumers have got more variety and more choice than we've ever had before, so we've got to be really sharp, everybody's got to stay very local, and we got to ensure that we are completing various in the marketplace.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Molson Coors Brewing Company first quarter 2016 earnings follow-up session conference call. Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Dave Dunnewald, Global Vice President of Investor Relations for Molson Coors. Please go ahead, Mr.  Dunnewald.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jonathan, and good morning, everyone. On behalf of Molson Coors Brewing Company, thank you for joining us today for our first quarter 2016 follow-up earnings conference call. Our goal on this call is to address as many additional earnings-relat
componenttext:
Thank you, Jonathan, and good morning, everyone. On behalf of Molson Coors Brewing Company, thank you for joining us today for our first quarter 2016 follow-up earnings conference call. Our goal on this call is to address as many additional earnings-related questions as possible following our regular earnings conference call with Mark Hunter, David [indiscernible], Mauricio Restrepo, and our business unit CEOs earlier today. We will use the standard Q&A format, and we anticipate that the call will last less than an hour. 
Before we begin, I will paraphrase the company's safe harbor language. Some of the discussions today may include forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from what the company projects today, so please refer to its most recent 10-K and 10-Q filings for a more complete description of factors that could affect these projections. The company does not undertake to publicly update forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. You should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date they are made. 
Regarding any non-U.S. GAAP measures that may be discussed during the call and from time-to-time by our company's executives in discussing the company's performance, please visit our website, www.molsoncoors.com, and click on the Financial Reporting tab at the Investor Relations page for reconciliation of these measures to the nearest U.S. GAAP results. 
Also unless otherwise indicated, all financial results the company discusses are versus the comparable prior-year period and in U.S. dollars. We also encourage investors and analysts to read SAB Miller plc news releases and trading statements that include financial and other information relating to the MillerCoors joint venture. 
So let's get started with an introduction of the team with me on this call. We have Kevin Kim, Investor Relations Senior Manager; Ashley [indiscernible] Finance Forecasting Senior Manager; Briant Tabolt, Controller; and Steve Mack, Director of Tax. 
Regarding quarterly results, as Mark Hunter mentioned on our regular earnings call earlier this morning, in the first quarter we continued to focus on our First Choice ambition and on building a stronger brand portfolio, delivering value-added innovation, strengthening our core brand positions through incremental marketing investments and continuing to premiumize our portfolio. We began to see the benefits flow to our top line performance as we grew worldwide volume, improved core brand momentum in key markets, introduced fast-growing innovations in all of our businesses and achieved strong Above Premium growth globally, including in craft, flavored malt beverages and cider. 
We also continued to strengthen our business through improvements to our sales execution and revenue management capabilities, increased efficiency of our operations and implementation of global systems on a common basis. 
As a result, Molson Coors reported significantly expanded gross, operating and pretax margins globally, along with growth more than 28% in total company underlying after-tax earnings and more than 15% growth in underlying EBITDA versus a year ago. 
At the same time, we completed a stock offering, a common stock offering in January, to fund about 20% of the pending MillerCoors transaction. And we made solid progress in our planning for the integration of MillerCoors and the Miller global brand portfolio. Completion of this game-changing transaction is still expected in the second half of this year, and we intend to be ready to go on day one following the close. 
In the balance of 2016, we will continue to focus on our First Choice for consumers and customers ambition, all driven through our Profit After Capital Charge lens and with the intent to drive total shareholder returns. 
So with, Jonathan, we'd now like to open it up for questions. Over to you.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I want to follow-up, please, on my question from the 9 A.M call, maybe it really just for this call, but I'm having a hard time, Dave, reconciling what I'm seeing in the Nielsen data for Miller Lite and Coors Light, specifically. I recognized there's s
componenttext: So I want to follow-up, please, on my question from the 9 A.M call, maybe it really just for this call, but I'm having a hard time, Dave, reconciling what I'm seeing in the Nielsen data for Miller Lite and Coors Light, specifically. I recognized there's some disconnect between on premise and off premise, but I'm seeing, on a trailing 12-week basis, for instance, Coors Light volumes up 1.1% but Miller Lite down 2.6%. There's some really notable divergences in terms of price mix. So is there anything kind of going on in terms of price back architecture or promotion in the off-premise that would drive some of that divergence in terms of the syndicated data?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for the clarity around the data that you're looking at. To be quite frank, I don't spend a lot of time on the standard data. But I guess what I would say is there's let say a few things come to mind. It's 12-week data and so, in some cases, yo
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for the clarity around the data that you're looking at. To be quite frank, I don't spend a lot of time on the standard data. But I guess what I would say is there's let say a few things come to mind. It's 12-week data and so, in some cases, you'll see what I would call sample error or call it divergence versus the population, if you're a statistician. And so that's one thing. Particularly, for example, you can see differences between Nielsen data and the IRI data for exactly the same periods, and that could be explained by what I call sample error. Also as we talked about on the earlier call, there are channel differences. So you are missing the liquor store and on premise. We already talked about that. Miller Lite does skew toward the on premise, but I don't think that's -- other factors are really important, along with geography, which I think is probably a important factor. For example, Miller Lite would skew more heavily toward the Midwest, where there's divergent call it total industry volume trends as obviously brand trend differences by geography. And whereas Coors Light would skew more toward to the Northeast and the West. And then also another difference between the scanner data and our sales to retail data in the first quarter would be an extra trading day, except we did for the number the numbers that we provided to we did adjust for that trading day. So it would show up in the reported numbers, but not in the ones we provided for you. So there you go. Sample error, geography and channel, primarily, is the way I would look at it.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, actually, no. We probably won't be able to provide a full sort of like a quarterly flow of things. But we did say that we said it on the last call and we said it on this one as well, we expect our total global brand spending or investments to b
componenttext:
Yes. Well, actually, no. We probably won't be able to provide a full sort of like a quarterly flow of things. But we did say that we said it on the last call and we said it on this one as well, we expect our total global brand spending or investments to be up for the full year. And at the same time, we want to emphasize that the second quarter is a significant piece of that in that we anticipate double-digit increase in brand investments, which that is an unusually large increase. But no, we didn't put dimensions around the full year or the subsequent quarters. There was some timing, how do you say, phasing of marketing that's worth remembering from last year, where MillerCoors was quite light on marketing and brand spend in the first half of the year for a variety of reasons. And then really, how do you say, raised the bar in the sense that more than 3/4 of the increase in brand spend for MillerCoors last year was actually in the fourth quarter, because we had ad properties and brand communications that we really wanted to invest behind. 
This year, in the first half of the year, we also have the introduction of Henry's Hard Soda and we have great ad creative behind Coors Light leading into peak season. And I think great ad created behind Miller Lite in the U.S. as well. So the earlier question about Henry's margins, if you look on Nielsen, you'll see an index vis a vis to consumers of 1 67 versus call it mainstream maybe Coors Light of 100. That was more to Vivien's question, though, sorry, Brett, but I thought I'd throw it in when I was thinking of it.

componenttextpreview: Let me give you some headlines and let's see whether there's anything we need to add to that. As far as options creep goes, unlike past times, call it 10 to 20 years ago, we gave out relatively few options. They really only go to the top, say, 8 or 10 peo
componenttext: Let me give you some headlines and let's see whether there's anything we need to add to that. As far as options creep goes, unlike past times, call it 10 to 20 years ago, we gave out relatively few options. They really only go to the top, say, 8 or 10 people in the entire company. So we've had, in some of those options, the last ones that were provided to a more broader employee group were actually 11 years ago. So if you look in more recent times, I think you'll see relatively modest option exercise. Our comp plans tend to lean more toward performance shares and restricted shares at this point, which call it less dilution overhang if you will. MillerCoors compensation, essentially, we'd be adding or we'll be doubling the size of the company, and we will be including those team members as appropriate or as the plans are designed on our compensation plans. So we have more people. But as far as bringing them over, that's the only thing I can think of where we'll just be adding more team  members to the...

componenttext: All right. Okay. As far as MillerCoors compensation programs go, there --  none of those utilize parent company stock. So for the last 8 years, we have not had a -- MillerCoors does not had any incentives long-term or short-term that utilize either SAB Miller stock or Molson Coors stock.

And then, I guess, on pensions, again, just thinking about the merger, is there anything from an accounting perspective that we should be thinking about in terms of like pensions being mark-to-market or maybe a change in the way that you are expensing pensions versus the way they were done with MillerCoors? Again as we're sort of just mashing the 2 together, is there something that we should be thinking about in terms of pensions that might be higher or lower in terms of ongoing expenses?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. Good question. One thing to clarify, the cash contributions we anticipate this year were $45 million to $65 million. Just make sure you got that number, pension expense of approximately $17 million, and that includes 42% of our -- our 42% owners
componenttext: Yes, yes. Good question. One thing to clarify, the cash contributions we anticipate this year were $45 million to $65 million. Just make sure you got that number, pension expense of approximately $17 million, and that includes 42% of our -- our 42% ownership interest in MillerCoors. Upon close of the transaction, we would be like -- we would essentially revalue the plan as if we'd had a curtailment. And sometimes when you have a plan change, a pension plan change, depending on how much changes, you can have a curtailment. And therefore, you do revaluation. And on the close of the transaction, Brian informs me, yes, we would revalue the pension plans. But it wouldn't change -- any way, let's leave it at that. We feel good about where our pensions are at this point. And some are even actually fully funded at this point, particularly in the U.K. and in Canada, overall, on a U.S. GAAP basis. So I don't know, you've probably seen that come through the filings where the funded status has improved from being down like a little let's call it a year and a half ago being close to $0.5 billion short. And at the end of this last year, we were only $162 million short as far as funded status for the overall plan, including 42% of   MillerCoors.

componenttext: Dave, so after the call I got a number of, I guess, I call it semiconcern questions from folks worried about a significant pickup in marketing and kind of just I think probably based on some of the comments in terms of Europe. And I was just wondering if you can frame this a little bit more in terms of what you're doing in Europe? Is it like particular opportunities that you see that, obviously, are passing your pack model and look very exciting and is somewhat tactical? Or is it a large concerted effort, just you're going to gain market share and just increase spending and keep on taking it up? I mean, how should we get a sense and comfort in terms of the higher marketing spend that you're budgeting this year and going forward?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess what I would do is point you back to the commentary we said on the earlier call, where we said that we anticipate higher brand investments this year, which is actually no different from what we said on the last call. In this case, though, we
componenttext: Sure. I guess what I would do is point you back to the commentary we said on the earlier call, where we said that we anticipate higher brand investments this year, which is actually no different from what we said on the last call. In this case, though, we did want to help people a little bit with their call it phasing, if you will. And so we actually said including a double-digit increase globally in the second quarter. And particularly, that's because we see great opportunities leading into peak season in not only the U.S. and Canada, but also in Europe. And we just wanted to make sure that people model that in. As far as specifics on balance of the year, I don't think I'd provide anything at this point, but it is about having more opportunities this year leading into peak season than we had last year as far as what we could invest behind to really drive our brands and drive value for our shareholders.

componenttextpreview: Yes, that's fair. So we think about brand investment similarly to all of our other, call it, cash usage, capital allocation and what have you, and that means pack model. So probably that's a capital charge. Where do we think we can get a great return on o
componenttext: Yes, that's fair. So we think about brand investment similarly to all of our other, call it, cash usage, capital allocation and what have you, and that means pack model. So probably that's a capital charge. Where do we think we can get a great return on our investment dollars? We do have a bias to invest behind our brands, but that's actually nothing new, we have that for over a decade at least in that range. And then so PACC model matters. Mark Hunter said a number of times, it's the quality of the spend, not the amount or tonnage. It's not about tonnage. In other words, we could have spent more behind our brands last year in Canada when and actually in the U.S., when we had in say the first and second quarter when we had some pretty rough trends behind the Coors Light brand. But that would not have been high-value use of our shareholders cash. So we did not do that, because we frankly didn't have the ad creative or the promotional properties to invest behind to get a great return. So we didn't do that. This year, we got Henry's Hard Soda. We've got great ad opportunities and call it consumer communication in Mark Hunter's words around Coors Light and Miller Lite. We've got the English Premier league in Europe now, although I would hasten to add to that, that's something that we would generally when we pick new your promotional properties, we fund them with sort of within an existing sort of reasonable budget, if you will.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Molson Coors Brewing Company First Quarter 2016 Earnings Follow-Up Session Conference Call. Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Dave Dunnewald, Global Vice President of Investor Relations for Molson Coors. Please go ahe
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Molson Coors Brewing Company First Quarter 2016 Earnings Follow-Up Session Conference Call. 
Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Dave Dunnewald, Global Vice President of Investor Relations for Molson Coors. Please go ahead, Mr. Dunnewald.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jonathan, and good morning, everyone. On behalf of Molson Coors Brewing Company, thank you for joining us today for our first quarter 2016 follow-up earnings conference call. Our goal on this call is to address as many additional earnings-rel
componenttext:
Thank you, Jonathan, and good morning, everyone. On behalf of Molson Coors Brewing Company, thank you for joining us today for our first quarter 2016 follow-up earnings conference call. 
Our goal on this call is to address as many additional earnings-related questions as possible following our regular earnings conference call with Mark Hunter, David Heede, Mauricio Restrepo and our business unit CEOs earlier today. We will use standard's Q&A format, and we anticipate that the call will last less than an hour. 
Before we begin, I will paraphrase the company's safe harbor language. Some of the discussion today may include forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from what the company projects today, so please refer to its most recent 10-K and 10-Q filings for a more complete description of factors that could affect these projections. 
The company does not undertake to publicly update forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. You should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date they are made. 
Regarding any non-U.S. GAAP measures that may be discussed during the call and from time to time by our company's executives in discussing the company's performance, please visit our website, www.molsoncoors.com, and click on the Financial Reporting tab at the Investor Relations page for a reconciliation of these measures to the nearest U.S. GAAP results. 
Also, unless otherwise indicated, all financial results the company discusses are versus the comparable prior year period and in U.S. dollars. We also encourage investors and analysts to read SABMiller plc news releases and trading statements that include financial and other information relating to the MillerCoors joint venture. 
So let's get started with an introduction of the team. With me on this call, we have Kevin Kim, Investor Relations Senior Manager; Ashley Dunlop, Finance Forecasting Senior Manager; Brian Tabolt, Controller; and Steve Mack, Director of Tax. 
Regarding quarterly results, as Mark Hunter mentioned on our regular earnings call earlier this morning, in the first quarter, we continued to focus on our First Choice ambition and on building a stronger brand portfolio, delivering value-added innovation, strengthening our core brand positions through incremental marketing investments and continuing to premiumize our portfolio. 
We began to see the benefits flow to our top line performance as we grew worldwide volume, improved core brand momentum in key markets, introduced fast-growing innovations in all of our businesses and achieved strong Above Premium growth globally, including in craft, flavored malt beverages and cider. 
We also continued to strengthen our business through improvements to our sales execution and revenue management capabilities, increased efficiency of our operations and implementation of global systems on a common basis. 
As a result, Molson Coors reported significantly expanded gross, operating and pretax margins globally, along with growth of more than 28% in total company underlying after-tax earnings and more than 15% growth in underlying EBITDA versus a year ago. 
At the same time, we completed a stock offering, a common stock offering in January to fund about 20% of the pending MillerCoors transaction. And we made solid progress in our planning for the integration of MillerCoors and the Miller global brand portfolio. Completion of this game-changing transaction is still expected in the second half of this year, and we intend to be ready to go on day 1 following the close. 
In the balance of 2016, we will continue to focus on our First Choice for consumers and customers ambition, all driven through our Profit After Capital Charge lens and with the intent to drive total shareholder returns. 
So with that, Jonathan, we'd now like to open it up for questions. Over to you.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to follow up, please, on my question from the 9 a.m. call, and maybe it really is just better suited for this call. But I'm having a hard time, Dave, reconciling what I'm seeing in the Nielsen data for Miller Lite and Coors Light specifically.
componenttext: So I wanted to follow up, please, on my question from the 9 a.m. call, and maybe it really is just better suited for this call. But I'm having a hard time, Dave, reconciling what I'm seeing in the Nielsen data for Miller Lite and Coors Light specifically. I recognize there's some disconnect between on-premise and off-premise, but I'm seeing, on a trailing 12-week basis, for instance, Coors Light volumes up 1.1% but Miller Lite down 2.6%. There's some really notable divergences in terms of price mix. So is there anything kind of going on in terms of price/pack architecture or promotion in the off-premise that would drive some of that divergence in terms of the syndicated data?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for the clarity around the data that you're looking at. To be quite frank, I don't spend a lot of time on the scanner data. But I guess what I would say is there -- let's say a few things come to mind. It's 12-week data, and so in some cases,
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for the clarity around the data that you're looking at. To be quite frank, I don't spend a lot of time on the scanner data. But I guess what I would say is there -- let's say a few things come to mind. It's 12-week data, and so in some cases, you'll see what I would call sample error or call it divergence versus the population if you're a statistician. And so that's one thing. Particularly, for example, you can see differences between the Nielsen data and the IRI data for exactly the same periods, and that could be explained by what I call sample error. Also, as we talked about on the earlier call, there are channel differences. So you are missing the liquor store and on-premise. We already talked about that. Miller Lite does skew toward the on-premise, but I don't think that's the -- I think those other factors are really important, along with geography, which I think is probably a very important factor. For example, Miller Lite would skew more heavily toward the Midwest where there's divergent, call it, total industry volume trends as obviously brand trend differences by geography, and whereas Coors Light would skew more toward, say, the Northeast and the West. And then also, another difference between the scanner data and our sales to retail data in the first quarter would be an extra trading day except we did, for the number that we -- the numbers that we provided to -- we did adjust for that trading day. So it would show up in the reported numbers but not in the ones we provided for you. So there you go. Sample error, geography and channel primarily is the way I would look at it.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, actually, no. We probably won't be able to provide a full sort of like a quarterly flow of things. But we did say that -- we said it on the last call, and we said it on this one as well, we expect our total global brand spending or investments
componenttext: Yes. Well, actually, no. We probably won't be able to provide a full sort of like a quarterly flow of things. But we did say that -- we said it on the last call, and we said it on this one as well, we expect our total global brand spending or investments to be up for the full year. And at the same time, we wanted to emphasize that the second quarter is a significant piece of that in that we anticipate double-digit increase in brand investments, which that is an unusually large increase. But no, we didn't put dimensions around the full year or the subsequent quarters. I can -- there was some timing, how do you say, phasing of marketing that's worth remembering from last year where MillerCoors was quite light on marketing and brand spend in the first half of the year for a variety of reasons and then really, how do you say, raised the bar in the sense that more than 3/4 of the increase in brand spend for MillerCoors last year was actually in the fourth quarter because we had ad properties and brand communications that we really wanted to invest behind. This year in the first half of the year, we also have the introduction of Henry's Hard Soda, and we have great ad creative behind Coors Light leading into peak season and I think great ad creative behind Miller Lite in the U.S. as well. To the earlier question about Henry's margins, if you look on Nielsen, you'll see an index of -- vis-à-vis the consumers of 167 versus, call it, mainstream maybe Coors Light of 100. That was more to Vivien's question, though, sorry, Brett, but I thought I'd throw it in when I was thinking of it.
