headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Molson Coors Brewing Company Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.Before we begin, I will paraphrase the company's safe harbor language. Some of the discussion today may include forward-looking statements. Actual results could dif
componenttext:
Welcome to the Molson Coors Brewing Company Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.
Before we begin, I will paraphrase the company's safe harbor language. Some of the discussion today may include forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from what the company projects today, so please refer to its most recent 10-K and 10-Q filings for a more complete description of factors that could affect these projections.
The company does not undertake to publicly update forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. You should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date they are made.
Regarding any non-U.S. GAAP measures that may be discussed during the call and from time-to-time by company's executives in discussing the company's performance, please visit the company's website, www.molsoncoors.com, and click on the Financial Reporting tab of the Investor Relations page for a reconciliation of these measures to the nearest U.S. GAAP results. 
Also, unless otherwise indicated, all financial results the company discusses are versus the comparable prior year period and in U.S. dollars.
Now I would like to turn the call over to Mark Hunter, President and CEO of Molson Coors.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Nicole, and hello and welcome everybody to the Molson Coors earnings call. Apologies for the slight delay due to technical issue. Many thanks for joining us today. With me on the call this morning from Molson Coors, we have Mauricio Restrepo,
componenttext:
Thank you, Nicole, and hello and welcome everybody to the Molson Coors earnings call. Apologies for the slight delay due to technical issue. Many thanks for joining us today. 
With me on the call this morning from Molson Coors, we have Mauricio Restrepo, our Global CFO; Gavin Hattersley, the COO of Miller Coors; Stewart Glendinning, the CEO of Canada; Simon Cox, our European CEO; Kandy Anand, our International CEO; [indiscernible] our Deputy General Counsel; Brian Tabolt our Global Controller; and David Dunnewald, the VP of Investor Relations.
For our earnings call today, Mauricio and I will take you through highlights of our second quarter 2016 results for Molson Coors Brewing Company along with some perspective on the second half of 2016.
In the second quarter, we continued to focus on our First Choice ambition and in building a stronger, broader and more premium brand portfolio, underpinned by incremental sales and marketing investment as we discussed on our first quarter earnings call. Progress in the second quarter included net sales revenue per hectoliter growth on a constant currency basis in all of our businesses, strong Coors Light growth globally. Improved core brand momentum, fast-growing innovations in key markets and strong Above Premium growth globally. 
We significantly increased investments behind our brands while retaining our shipments and other short-term factors held back bottom line performance in the quarter. In brands, Coors Light grew volume more than 4% globally, including strong double-digit growth in Europe and Latin America and low single-digit growth in the U.S., its best performance in nearly 3 years. In Above Premium, our craft portfolio drove growth, from Doom Bar and other Sharp brands in the U.K. from Creemore Springs and Belgium Moon in Canada and from Leinenkugel's grapefruit shandy and the newly acquired Saint Archer in the U.S. 
Staropramen grew strongly across Europe outside of its home market, and ciders grew volume at Rekorderlig in Europe and Strongbow Canada. In flavored malt beverages, we now have the largest hard soda franchise in the U.S. with the successful introduction of the Henry's hard soda brands earlier this year. We continue to strengthen our business to improvements through sales execution and revenue management capabilities, increased efficiency of our operations and implementation of global systems. In short, our supply chain is fit for the future. In the second quarter, we reached an agreement to purchase land in British Columbia on which will build a new efficient and flexible brewery over the next few years. This new brewery site is attractively priced real access situation in the TransCanada Highway making it ideal for serving the Western Canada and U.S. market, and we anticipate completing the land purchase just this month.
In the past few months, we have also made substantial progress in the pending MillerCoors transaction, including an integration planning and completing the necessary financing at very attractive rates. Investor demand for our recent debt offering was very strong, and we achieved record and near-record low interest rates on our debt issue. We're pleased with the transaction progress made to date, and we continue to plan for closing before the end of 2016, more specifically, October 10 based on the joint ABI SAB recent announcements. We're very excited to be much closer to completing this game-changing transaction, which will enable simplified decision-making and will reduce the complexities of dual ownership. It will help us become a more integrated and efficient brewer and will enable us to become a more effective competitor as a single owner consumer choice in an increasingly diverse and fast-growing brewing industry. 
As part of integration planning process, last week, I announced the leadership appointments that will strengthen our combined organization, and it will take effect on the close of the transaction. Our transaction and timing remain dependent clearly on the completion of the ABI and SABMiller transaction. 
The regional highlights for the second quarter are as follows. In the U.S., while overall sales to retail volume decreased 1.7%, driven primarily by our Below Premium brands, Coors Light STRs were up low single digits in the quarter, which was its best quarterly performance since the fourth quarter of 2012. Domestic net revenue per hectoliter grew 0.7% for the quarter as a result of favorable pricing and positive sales mix. Our largest brand gained share of the Premium Light segment for the first consecutive quarter. And please note that all of our performance discussions related -- relating to Coors Light exclude the citrus that was discontinued last year. With flat STRs, Miller Lite gained share of the Premium Light segment for the seventh [ph] consecutive quarter. Improved momentum for these 2 brands was driven by continued rollout of the new visual identity and consumer communications, which appeal to our broad section of men and women, millennials and multicultural consumers. Additionally, Coors Banquet is now on its 10th consecutive year of growth. In higher margin Above Premium segment Henry's was #1 hard soda franchise in the second quarter in the strength of Henry's hard orange and ginger ale. In craft Leinenkugel's grapefruit shandy and the newly acquired Saint Archer brands continue to drive volume although Bloom and Belgian White declined low single digits. As an important indication of the traction we are gaining in the U.S., for the first time in history of the joint venture, in 2016, MillerCoors finished #1 in the supplier survey, which polled hundreds of U.S. distributors performance of wine and spirit suppliers. This is a key accomplishment in our First Choice a mission for our customers and is an example of the type of efforts we are driving globally to ensure we are focusing on these important customer relationships. On the bottom line, MillerCoors' second quarter underlying net income declined 3.8% to $468.8 million, driven primarily by the timing of shipments due to calendar shifts, which are partially offset by lower cost of goods sold, higher net pricing and positive sales mix. Meanwhile, Molson Coors' second quarter underlying equity income in the U.S. segment increased 1.4% due to an $11.1 million anticipated refund of federal excise tax paid on imports. This tax refund is based on qualifying volumes exported from the U.S. by the Coors Brewing Company, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Molson Coors and was driven by new legislation enacted this year in the U.S. First half underlying equity earnings in the U.S. segment, which was not significantly affected by the timing of beer shipments, increased 9.4%.
In Canada, STRs declined 0.1%, and our sales volume declined 0.8% in the second quarter. Weak economic conditions in western Canada were largely offset by favorable timing of the Canada Day holiday this year. Net sales per hectoliter in local currency increased 1.2% in the quarter despite competitive pressures in the east and a pronounced consumer shift of value brands in Alberta. 
In core brands, although Coors Light volumes declined our new packaging advertising impacts sales promotions are driving improved consumer purchase intent and brand health scores. Molson Canadian volume suffered from a significant shift towards the value segment in Alberta. In Above Premium and craft, we continue to see strong performance with Coors Banquet, Belgian Moon, Mad Jack, Heineken, Dos Equis and cider all grew volume and share in the quarter along with our Creemore Springs craft brands. 
And headline financial results for the quarter, Canada underlying pretax income decreased 19.7% in constant currency, primarily due to a significant increase in sales and marketing investment as we discussed in our last earnings call. 
Looking at the first half of the same basis underlying pretax income decreased 10.1%, also driven primarily by increased brand investments. Our Europe business achieved 1.6% volume growth and increased market share across the region, driven by growth in 7 of our 11 lead core and premium brands. Net sales revenue per hectoliter increased 1.3% in local currency, driven entirely by brand and geographic mix. In core brands, Carling, Bergenbier and all grew share of segment in their primary markets. And our Above Premium portfolio increased momentum with strong double-digit growth by Coors Light and our craft portfolio, including Blue Moon, Doom Bar and other Sharp's brands. Finally, the inclusion of Rekorderlig Cider since the middle of 2015 and the dollar repatriation of the Staropramen brand in the U.K. this year added to the solid progress we made in premiumizing our Europe portfolio. Consistent with the first quarter, underlying pretax income was lower in the quarter due to higher brand investments and amortization expenses, lower net pension benefit and the termination of the Heineken arrangements in the U.K. along with unfavorable foreign currency movements of this quarter. Our International business grew Coors Light at strong double-digit rate in the second quarter, driven by Latin America, including our brand launch in Colombia late last year. Overall volume including royalty volume declined 9.3%, driven by the enactment of alcohol prohibition in Bihar in India, the transfer of Staropramen in the U.K. to our Europe segment and the volume impact of our substantial China restructure. Underlying pretax performance improved in the second quarter, and drivers included volume growth in Latin America and Japan, favorable sales mix as well as lower price promotion and overhead expenses related to the restructure of our China business last year including cycling $3.6 million of price promotion expense a year ago.
Now I'll turn over to Mauricio to give second quarter financial highlights and perspective for the balance of 2016. Mauricio?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark, and hello, everybody. As a reminder, all of the results that I will be discussing are in U.S. dollars, unless I note otherwise. Our second quarter financial headlines are as follows. Net sales were down approximately 2% in U.S. dollars du
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark, and hello, everybody. As a reminder, all of the results that I will be discussing are in U.S. dollars, unless I note otherwise. Our second quarter financial headlines are as follows. Net sales were down approximately 2% in U.S. dollars due to currency movements. On a constant currency basis, net sales increased 1.9% driven by Europe, Canada and international. Our net sales per hectoliter increased 2.4% in constant currency due to positive mix. On a U.S. GAAP basis we reported pretax income of $196.9 million, 32.1% lower than a year ago. While after-tax income from continuing operations attributable to Molson Coors was $174.1 million, down 24.1% from the prior year result. These decreases were primarily due to noncash special charges and other noncore expenses related to our pending acquisition, the alcohol prohibition in Bihar and the planned brewery closures along with higher MG&A expenses. Underlying pretax income in constant currency decreased 6.9% in the quarter and 8.6% on a reported basis, partly due to year-over-year differences in the timing of brand investments and other expenses as well as lower worldwide volume. First half results eliminate some of these quarterly timing differences and reflected 3.4% growth in constant currency underlying pretax income and 2% growth on a reported basis in U.S. dollars. 
Second quarter underlying after-tax income decreased 9.2% to $239.5 million or $1.11 per diluted share, driven by lower worldwide volume, higher brand investments in all of our businesses and the negative foreign currency movements, which are partially offset by a positive mix, lower underlying net interest expense and higher underlying U.S. equity income. Underlying EBITDA in the quarter was $428.7 million. That is 5.8% lower than a year ago, while our first half underlying EBITDA grew 1.2%. Underlying free cash flow in the first half of 2016 was $158.9 million. This represents a decrease of $82.2 million from the prior year, primarily driven by lower underlying after-tax income, negative foreign currency and less benefit from working capital changes, excluding special and other noncore items, including higher cash paid for taxes. In early July, we completed a $7 billion long-term debt offering with a weighted average coupon of 2.9%, including the lowest 30-year BBB- coupon ever issued in U.S. dollars as well as a 1.25% coupon for our 8-year euro debt issuance. As a result of these attractive rates, we anticipate that our annualized interest cost on the transaction financing will be approximately $260 [ph] million at current interest and foreign exchange rates. This annual interest expense is nearly $200 million lower than the assumed bridge loan and other transaction-related interest expense included in the 2015 pro forma financial results that we filed in May. With the debt offering, we achieved broad high-quality investor participation and attractive pricing. More than 400 institutional investors participated in the offering. Combining this debt issue with our $2.6 billion equity offering in February and up to $3 billion of a previously arranged term loan, we now have in place all the financing needed for the pending MillerCoors transaction. 
Total debt at the end of the second quarter was $3 billion, which does not include the $7 billion of long-term debt we issued in July. Cash and cash equivalents totaled slightly less than $3 billion, resulting in net debt of $37 million, which is significantly lower than prior year due to the cash proceeds received from our equity offering earlier in the year. Please see the earnings release distributed earlier this morning for a detailed review of our business unit financial results in the quarter.
Now looking forward to the remainder of 2016 following some factors to consider for the last 2 quarters of this year. Incremental Europe brand amortization expense with an annualized impact of approximately $50 [ph] million, which began in the fourth quarter of 2015 along with lower net pension benefits in Europe this year. A total prohibition on the sale of alcohol an expectedly plummeted by the state government in Bihar in early April. We don't know how long this band will be in place, and we expect this development to present a headwind for our International business for the foreseeable future or until it is overturned. And finally foreign currency translation which at current exchange rates would be headwind of about $13 million to our underlying pretax results in the second half this year with most of the impact in Europe. Given the recent volatility of our key foreign currencies, particularly the British pound, it is important to watch these rates closely. Regarding 2016 guidance, all of the following metrics exclude any effects of the MillerCoors and Miller global brands transaction, the timing of which will have a big impact on virtually all of our guidance measures. For the full year, we continue to expect cash contributions to our defined benefit pension plans to be in the range of $45 million to $65 million in 2016 and pension expense of approximately $17 million, including our 42% of MillerCoors contribution and expense; MG&A expense in corporate of approximately $120 million on an underlying basis, which excludes expenses related to our pending transaction; consolidated net interest expense of approximately $110 million on an underlying basis, which excludes transaction-related  interest expense and income; and underlying effective tax rate in the range of 18% to 22% assuming no further changes in tax loss, settlement of tax audits or adjustments to our uncertain tax positions. In updated guidance, we now expect underlying capital spending of approximately $220 million, which excludes capital this year related to the construction of our new brewery in British Columbia. As far as our cost outlook is concerned, we continue to expect the cost of goods sold per hectoliter in Canada and Europe in local currency to increase a low single-digit rate for the full year 2016. We now expect 2016 MillerCoors COGS per hectoliter to decrease at a low single-digit rate versus prior year. Further cost reductions including acceleration of some of our cost savings initiatives and changes in sales mix drove the change from previous guidance of approximately in line. We now expect our international COGS per hectoliter to increase at a double-digit rate for 2016. This is up from a high single-digit increase previously due to geographic mix changes. We continue to expect annual cost savings for this year and next year to be in the range of $50 million to $70 million. This excludes cost savings for MillerCoors as well as synergies resulting from the pending MillerCoors acquisition, which we expect to be $200 million by year 4 following the transaction close. Finally, here are the most recent volume trends for each of our businesses early in the third quarter. 
In the U.S. for the 3 weeks through July 23, STRs decreased at a mid-single-digit rate, partially due to the timing of the loading for the July 4 holiday while they decreased at a high single-digit rate in Canada for the same period. In Europe, volumes through July 25 decreased high single digits. And our international sales volume, including royalty volume through July 23, decreased at a low single-digit rate, primarily due to the alcohol prohibition in Bihar. As ever, please keep in mind these numbers represent only a portion of the current quarter, and trends could change in the weeks ahead. Also as a reminder, following the close of the pending MillerCoors transaction, we plan to discontinue providing these early next quarter volume trends.
At this point, I'll turn it back over to Mark for outlook, wrap-up and the Q&A. Mark?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mauricio. In the second half of this year, we will continue to drive our First Choice for consumer and customer agenda in the geographies and segments where we choose to play, ensuring built up broader, stronger and more premium portfolio while dr
componenttext:
Thanks, Mauricio. In the second half of this year, we will continue to drive our First Choice for consumer and customer agenda in the geographies and segments where we choose to play, ensuring built up broader, stronger and more premium portfolio while driving best-in-class customer service and partnerships. In the U.S., MillerCoors remains laser focused on the strategy to drive total volume growth by 2019. For the first time in many years, our largest business is in line with its volume expectations for the first 6 months. The quarter also provides additional steps towards its growth ambition with strength in marketing behind flagship brands, Coors Light and Miller Lite, and we're starting to see the positive impact. Also, we continue to see success in the innovation space. in Above Premium, we remain bullish in the potential of Henry's as the hard soda category continues to grow. In the second quarter, Henry's became the #1 hard soda franchise. The MillerCoors plans to roll out Henry's hard cherry cola later this month. In segment, MillerCoors will continue to invest support for Blue Moon and Leinenkugel during the balance of the peak year selling season. MillerCoors also recently announced that it had agreed to purchase majority interest of Oregon-based Hot Valley brewing company and to increase its ownership of the Georgia-based and beer company from an minority stake to a majority interest. These are highly regarded brewers both in the region and nationwide and further strengthen U.S. craft portfolio, which also includes Blue Moon, Leinenkugel's and Saint Archer. Additionally, next month at its fall meeting with distributors, the U.S. team will share plans to improve the performance of Below Premium portfolio. And the team continues to expand its Building with Beer retail strategy beyond on premise the additional channels to build First Choice customer partnerships. The changes standing in the MillerCoors ownership structured the not one of apprehension but excitement. In the meantime, everyone at MillerCoors remains discipline, decisive and accountable for growing our business, transforming our portfolio and driving shareholder value. In Canada, we are investing behind the new product quality focused advertising and improved sales execution by our field sales management program. These efforts are aimed not only at improving our premium performance also continuing to accelerate our growing Above Premium portfolio. We will continue our position to hard soda space with Mad Jack root beer and ginger ale, the first major hard soda entries in Canada. Additionally, we signed a partnership agreement in May with Brazil de Montréal to leverage its craft and speciality beers in Québec and across the strong Canada distribution network. Following the close of the pending MillerCoors transaction, we're also looking forward to bringing the Miller brands back into our Canada portfolio.
In Europe, we achieved top line and market share growth in the second quarter on the strength of our core and Above Premium brands along with the addition of the Rekorderlig cider and Staropramen brands in the U.K. Increased brand amortization expense will continue to present a headwind for one more quarter, and we'll continue to invest in our core brand portfolio across Europe to continue to grow our share of segment. This will include leveraging our English Premier League sponsorship well beyond Carling in the U.K. to many high-potential brand and market opportunities. We will also continue to premiumize our portfolio with Coors Light, the Sharp's portfolio led by Doom Bar, Rekorderlig and Staropramen in the U.K. as well as Ireland's leading craft brand, Franciscan Well. Our International business is focused on continuing to accelerate our overall growth in existing and select new markets while maintaining profitability in 2016 on a constant currency basis versus the original 2013 commitment, now excluding the impact of the Bihar alcohol prohibition. Upon closing of the MillerCoors transaction, we will integrate the Miller International brands into our portfolio and leverage a footprint that complements our growth strategy and allows us to gain entrance into high-priority markets while increasing our business scale in current markets. We will also continue to drive rapid growth from Coors Light in Latin America. Going forward, Coors Miller and Staropramen brands will be the priorities for our international brand portfolio. And in India, we will continue to add scale through our Mount Shivalik business.
To wrap up, in the second half of 2016, we will continue to focus on our First Choice for consumer and customer ambition, all driven through our capital charge lens and with the intent to drive total shareholder returns.
Now before we start the Q&A portion of the call, just a quick comment. As usual, our prepared remarks will be in our website for your reference within a couple of hours this afternoon. Also 1 p.m. Eastern Time today, David Dunnewald will host a follow-up conference call, which is an opportunity for you to ask additional questions regarding our quarterly results. This call will also be available for you to hear via webcast on our website. Additionally, we hope to see many of you at the Barclays Consumer Staples Conference in Boston on September 7. So at that point, Nicole, we'd like to open up for questions, please.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes in the line of Judy Hong from Goldman Sachs.

componenttext: First, it seems like your volume trends have worsened in July for all of your regions. And understanding that this is really a short-term trend, but can you provide any color just in terms of how much is this maybe worsening macro versus timing versus any other drivers of that?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mark. Let me take that. I mean as we're going to discontinue post the acquisition the short-term trends because my view is that they are not helpful, and there's so much volatility around trading days, timing of holidays, some of the promotional acti
componenttext: It's Mark. Let me take that. I mean as we're going to discontinue post the acquisition the short-term trends because my view is that they are not helpful, and there's so much volatility around trading days, timing of holidays, some of the promotional activity in the market. So it's very, very difficult to take a read on it. So it's very early in the quarter. I think if you look at our longer-term volume trend is much better indication as to the health of the business, and I wouldn't read too much into these short-term numbers.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's fair. The second quarter, obviously, we're seeing your branded investments step up, and you certainly called out that this would happen in the quarter. But just wanted to get a sense of some of the paybacks that you're seeing as you stepped u
componenttext: Okay. That's fair. The second quarter, obviously, we're seeing your branded investments step up, and you certainly called out that this would happen in the quarter. But just wanted to get a sense of some of the paybacks that you're seeing as you stepped up of these investments and the likelihood that you continue to see these investments going forward. And then if I drill down into Canada, it seems like certainly the STR got better in the second quarter but margins did get negatively impacted. So sort of the trade-off that you're seeing in that particular region in terms of share versus profitability.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, couple of questions in there, Judy. I'll pass over to Stewart shortly to pick on the Canada-specific question. I think your broader part on investment is a good question. I mean, we are driving our First Choice for consumer and customer agenda
componenttext:
Okay. Well, couple of questions in there, Judy. I'll pass over to Stewart shortly to pick on the Canada-specific question. I think your broader part on investment is a good question. I mean, we are driving our First Choice for consumer and customer agenda. Central to that the quality the breadth and depth of our brand portfolio and our ability to premiumize our portfolio while building our customer relationship. So we made good on the commitment to step up our investment through the second quarter. I think if you look at our NSR per hectoliter, we saw per hec growth in all of our regions. I'm encouraged by the sequential improvement in our share trends and all of our regions as well from Q1 into Q2. But clearly, brand building is a long-term game. And my objective and the executive objective here is to continue to invest in a sustained way. Clearly, the focus is always in the quality of our investments I'd rather spend less dollars in a great than more idea on a bad idea, but our job is to develop great ideas and then invest in a sustained way. And that's what we're doing, and I expect to see us continue to do that through the third quarter as well as I say that the sequential improvement that you've seen from Q1 to Q2, I think, is testament to the focus right across our business. Stewart, you want to pick up on the Canada-specific question?
[Technical Difficulty]
It looks like we lost Stewart for a second. Judy, we'll get him back and then I'll fill him back to your specific question if you can just bear with us. We seem to have a couple of technical hitches this morning.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] So If I could just answer that question, I was talking and nobody could hear me. But obviously 2 pieces to margins, Judy. The NSR, which we were quite pleased, was broadly in line with the underlying trend in Q1, really was driven by the C
componenttext: [indiscernible] So If I could just answer that question, I was talking and nobody could hear me. But obviously 2 pieces to margins, Judy. The NSR, which we were quite pleased, was broadly in line with the underlying trend in Q1, really was driven by the COGS. And if you look at what happened in cost of goods sold in the second half, we broadly offset our inflation with cost savings. And the increase you see there was the increase in some of our marketing investments for impact promotions, which go in case. So that was investment behind the brands. You saw some impact from transactional FX and volume deleverage. But I would look at the first half and say, if you look at the first half, actually, we had an improvement in COGS of about 0.7%. So hopefully that helps.

So could you just offer a little bit more color on the pricing environment in Europe and whether there's any reason for optimism that the pricing outside of positive product or geographic mix could start to materialize?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm speaking now, I hope you can hear me. Yes, I got the question. I mean, overall, we would characterize that the European quarter is pretty solid, and net sales revenue are up at 3%. And what we're trying to do, obviously, is make sure that we've got an
componenttext: I'm speaking now, I hope you can hear me. Yes, I got the question. I mean, overall, we would characterize that the European quarter is pretty solid, and net sales revenue are up at 3%. And what we're trying to do, obviously, is make sure that we've got an appropriate balance between price and volume or NSR per hectoliter in volume, which again we achieved in the quarter. Volumes are up 1.6%, and NSR per hectoliter up [ph] 1.3%. So I think that's a reasonably good balance. It is true that the NSR per hectoliter was driven by mix with price under pressure but, that goes back to our to strategy we've been trying to make sure that we invest behind the premium brands to drive the right both portfolio and geographic mix. So whilst pricing is under pressure across many of the markets, I think we're doing a pretty solid job in recognizing that and driving volumes and shares and mix to get to an overall positive revenue growth. So we'd be quite satisfied with it, recognizing that pricing remains competitive.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Just if I could follow up on that. In terms of the share gains that you're generating, those are in volume terms. Do you have a sense of how your dollar share is trending? I'm just curious whether this pricing pressure is true across the c
componenttext: That's helpful. Just if I could follow up on that. In terms of the share gains that you're generating, those are in volume terms. Do you have a sense of how your dollar share is trending? I'm just curious whether this pricing pressure is true across the categories or whether your pricing is under a little bit more pressure on an apples-to-apples basis.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do believe that our pricing is under excessive pressure. Obviously, we've got 11 markets we have to cover, so it's very difficult to give you a generic answer. But we believe that our pricing and our volume is sensible collaboration. We talked about 0.
componenttext: We do believe that our pricing is under excessive pressure. Obviously, we've got 11 markets we have to cover, so it's very difficult to give you a generic answer. But we believe that our pricing and our volume is sensible collaboration. We talked about 0.3% share across the region, and I don't think we sacrificed price in an uncontrolled way to do that. So I keep coming back to, Vivien, it's important for us that we manage and mix overall volume share and overall pricing and I think as long as we're getting overall net sales revenue like we had to in the quarter around 3%, we would be happy with that and think that's pretty solid.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Mark Swartzberg from Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: One on Canada, Mark or Stewart, and another one on the global potential of some brands besides Coors Light. But on Canada, I think the takeaway here is that the spend increase is working. The share trends are improving. When you lift the hood, what gives
componenttext: One on Canada, Mark or Stewart, and another one on the global potential of some brands besides Coors Light. But on Canada, I think the takeaway here is that the spend increase is working. The share trends are improving. When you lift the hood, what gives you confidence, if you have it, that the upgrade in trends is sticky, so to speak? What are you seeing with brands and channels that makes you think that it won't be an issue 3 months from now? Of course, the category is competitive, but trying to get a little better understanding of much confidence you can hold? And to the extent you can factor in July appreciating that it's just 1 month of data, that would be helpful, too. So that's my question on Canada.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Mark, you want to come back for the global question and ask Stewart if you go back on the global brand piece?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're probably talking about the First Choice agenda just briefly in saying that against the 3 platforms, we've been driving lowering our cost base overhauling our supply chain network and improving the front end, all 3 of those actually are looking good
componenttext: You're probably talking about the First Choice agenda just briefly in saying that against the 3 platforms, we've been driving lowering our cost base overhauling our supply chain network and improving the front end, all 3 of those actually are looking good. On the first 2, we continue to see cost savings in the quarter, and that allowed us to drive some of that brand investment that we put behind commercial. And the money that we put behind commercial really went to 3 places. It went to invest behind our growing Above Premium portfolio, which is continue to grow share. So I think that's very sticky. Those brands have continued to grow. Coors Banquet turned in a better than 20% growth again this quarter. I think the second piece is we put money behind our big brands relative to in case promotions. And I think last year we had some concerns that we weren't competitive. I think this year, we were well-balanced, and I think that was a positive. And then on the third the investment, we pushed investment behind our share of voice. We were underindexing. And together with really effective advertising copy, we've seen that continue to grow our brand scores. So growing brand scores is a great telltale sign that you're spending money in the right place. So that's how I describe the brand expense for Q2.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Mark, do you want to pick up your global question?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That would be great. Coors Light, I mean plus 4 is a great number I think there's reasons to believe we can accelerate from there. So that in itself is something to draw attention to, but you mentioned Staropramen, you mentioned Miller. Could you give us
componenttext: That would be great. Coors Light, I mean plus 4 is a great number I think there's reasons to believe we can accelerate from there. So that in itself is something to draw attention to, but you mentioned Staropramen, you mentioned Miller. Could you give us a sense of where you think you are in the evolution, specifically of Staropramen? How much potential you see here for the brand in the U.S. but more broadly, we see how it's helping you in Europe. Just trying to get the sense of how much it can start to deliver on the kind of performance we're seeing from Coors Light.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you look at the shape of our existing international portfolio, the 2 backbone brands are principally Coors Light and Staropramen. Clearly, Blue Moon is now in many, many markets, growing rapidly from small base. If you look at Staropramen specific
componenttext: Yes. If you look at the shape of our existing international portfolio, the 2 backbone brands are principally Coors Light and Staropramen. Clearly, Blue Moon is now in many, many markets, growing rapidly from small base. If you look at Staropramen specifically post the start of acquisition we increased investment in the brand really across greater Europe. So outside of the Czech market, and we're seeing double-digit growth in many of those markets. My personal perspective is in a greater Europe basis, there's still a lot of runway ahead of us. And one of the changes I announced in the last couple of weeks, Mark, is we look at our European business including our export and license market, and one of the benefits from that is we have a more holistic Europe approach across all markets in Staropramen. Outside of Europe, that's part of our thinking and our emerging planning ahead of integration. Staropramen's currently in Canada. We're just going to testing and incubating the brand of their the U.S. marketplace is slightly more context because of the distributor relationship with importer relationship that we inherited when we acquired the business. We're working our way through that and his broader conversation with Gavin, and the team really looking at where we want to place our bets on our important part for you going forward recognizing we have an embarrassment of Richie's and Staropramen potentially in the future. So that's work that were currently thinking our way through just now. But in terms of the Staropramen, which is lets call it Greater Europe very, very solid progress in Ukraine, which is a really difficult market, we continue to take share there. So I feel very good about the possibilities ahead for Staropramen as part of kind of our three-pronged international portfolio, including the addition of the Miller brand.

And just a little bit more on the international brand potential, what if anything have you been able to accomplish in the last few months in terms of thinking through how you are going to go to market both in terms of route to market as well as manufacturing growing infrastructure for the Miller global brands and how quickly do you think you'll be able to move on that after the transaction closes?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mark here. So let me give you a couple of headlines, and Andy can fill in just a few of the details. I mean just to reiterate, obviously, this is a significant step change opportunity for international business. And I think as I've indicated in the p
componenttext: It's Mark here. So let me give you a couple of headlines, and Andy can fill in just a few of the details. I mean just to reiterate, obviously, this is a significant step change opportunity for international business. And I think as I've indicated in the past, if you think about the Miller brands internationally, there is really kind of 3 volume platforms and value platforms. One is across our existing infrastructures. So as I indicated we're looking forward to getting the Miller brands back to our portfolio in Canada. And obviously, the volumes in the U.K. and Ireland will roll into our existing business there. The second platform is those markets where we already have route to markets and strong positions, and that will build of those positions out further. So for example, in Panama our business which is a strong business will step change in scale terms with the addition of the Miller brands and that will open up a number of new markets very don't have the market. And Kandy, did you want to talk the progresses you made, particularly in the second and third areas?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it is very exciting for our International business in the Miller portfolio to already fast-growing Coors Light portfolio, which is growing strong double digits. In terms of the actual progress, if you take out our top 20 markets for the Miller brands t
componenttext:
So it is very exciting for our International business in the Miller portfolio to already fast-growing Coors Light portfolio, which is growing strong double digits. In terms of the actual progress, if you take out our top 20 markets for the Miller brands that we are inheriting, including Canada, U.K. Ireland, that basically covers 95-plus percent of that total volume. On these large markets, we have -- we either have agreements or we are in the process of getting agreements to ensure that we have a route to market in day 1. In terms of supply agreements, it's a combination of transition service agreements that we have previously negotiated with ABI post transition or exporting from our U.S. business. So those are supply agreements. They make good progress. I mean still a lot of work a lot of countries, a lot of new markets but I would say at this point of time, we are on track for our day 1 integration.
Just to add some of the tradition agreements would be with potentially with taking over some of the European supply locations.

componenttext: It's a mixed bag where markets are doing well and momentum, and there are others where it's down. So I think as you look at the totality, they're more or less we expected them to be based on the data we have, which is of course, a quarter [indiscernible] at this stage.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mark here. The thing to bear in mind is, clearly, this is going to be a complex transition I think we are well planned and ready for execution. There's some details to be sorted out, but I would actually think about it is very much in the medium- to
componenttext: It's Mark here. The thing to bear in mind is, clearly, this is going to be a complex transition I think we are well planned and ready for execution. There's some details to be sorted out, but I would actually think about it is very much in the medium- to long-term basis. As you think about the growth trajectory of our business, Coors Miller and Staropramen combined along with our emerging international craft portfolio you look at over the course of the next few years I think in places a very, very positive place to really build out our international footprint and our international trajectory. So the first year will be challenging and tricky in some places, but we've got to look beyond that to the value that's going to be created by the Miller international portfolio.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Terrific. And just one last question. Coors Light, you gave us, I think, a 4% global number. Could you tell us what it did in Canada, specifically, and then what it did outside of North America, please?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Off the top of my head, in Canada, we were down kind of low to mid-single digits. And then internationally, if you look at our MCI business, we were up double digit growth. And in the U.K. and Ireland, we were up double digit. In fact, kind of high 20s, l
componenttext: Off the top of my head, in Canada, we were down kind of low to mid-single digits. And then internationally, if you look at our MCI business, we were up double digit growth. And in the U.K. and Ireland, we were up double digit. In fact, kind of high 20s, low 30% growth. So Canada, down low to mid-single. Everywhere else outside of Canada, double-digit growth.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And any visibility in terms of stabilization in Canada?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Stewart picked up on that. The focus has been driving the right inputs. We've seen impact on the outputs on I'm certainly very encouraged by the fact that we've seen our brand health metrics and our purchase intent numbers move in a very po
componenttext: Well, I think, Stewart picked up on that. The focus has been driving the right inputs. We've seen impact on the outputs on I'm certainly very encouraged by the fact that we've seen our brand health metrics and our purchase intent numbers move in a very positive direction through the second quarter. So I think quality of our coffee, the promotional intensity in terms of our encase, the rollout of the identity, further alignment with the U.S. a platform, all of those things over well. But this is a big, big brand, and you don't turn things on auto turn things off overnight. So we are working this hard, and I think were working on the right inputs measures that are starting certainly through our brand tracking to demonstrate that we're pulling on the right levers, and I expect to see performance improved through the balance of this year and into 2017. Encouragingly, when you look at Coor's trademark in totality, in Canada with Banquet, which Stewart mentioned is up over 20% Again, the Coor's trademarks in generally good health Coors Light if we can get that moving in the right direction very strong position.

componenttext: I think that question was on alcohol beers. So that's something, which has already been a relatively large part of our thinking within Molson Coors. And one of the benefits we acquired the start business was actually the addition of the beer mix portfolio to our portfolio. So described as rattlers. These are beers that are in about 2% of alcohol so we've got some good learning in our business about the consumer drivers behind low and no alcohol and is essential innovation point within our business. So more to follow. I think many people and alcohol are now looking at low and no alcohol choices. It's very much on our agenda and be news on that front in due course.

componenttextpreview: I've got 2 questions, one related to interest rates and the other related to reporting. So I guess, the first one just on interest rates. With interest rates I guess post Brexit, the outlook looks like it's even lower it's going to stay low for a long tim
componenttext: I've got 2 questions, one related to interest rates and the other related to reporting. So I guess, the first one just on interest rates. With interest rates I guess post Brexit, the outlook looks like it's even lower it's going to stay low for a long time so Mauricio, could you just sort of talk to us about any effect that may potentially have on things like pension funding, assumptions of that you're using for pension funding and then also how it might affect the way you apply the PACC model, just simply because the cost of financing or cost of capital comes down, does it sort of change all the way you're planning you apply the PACC model in looking at certain projects?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, I mean, in terms of our financing, first of all, obviously, as you heard me say before, we had a fantastic result in our long-term debt offering. The interest costs that we were able to get on the financing was about $200 million lower than wha
componenttext: Yes. Look, I mean, in terms of our financing, first of all, obviously, as you heard me say before, we had a fantastic result in our long-term debt offering. The interest costs that we were able to get on the financing was about $200 million lower than what we had assumed in the pro forma financials that we have submitted a couple of months ago. So that clearly will have a very beneficial impact going forward. And as for the PACC model, of course, we're constantly updating the cost of capital that we would use to analyze and review the various alternatives i.e. should we deliver, should we invest behind our plans or should we pursue certain M&A opportunities or should we return money to shareholders. And obviously, those rates will be adjusted and are adjusted accordingly, given what's happening in the market and our outlook going forward.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just on pension, I guess, if you're contemplating the merger of MillerCoors and Molson Coors, is there anything we should watch for there related to the interest rate outlook being lower for longer, probably?
componenttext: And then just on pension, I guess, if you're contemplating the merger of MillerCoors and Molson Coors, is there anything we should watch for there related to the interest rate outlook being lower for longer, probably?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, I mean that tends to have a double effect on the one hand because of the returns that you have on the pension assets and also the discount rate that you used for the obligations. But at present, those things have been taking into accoun
componenttext: Well, as you know, I mean that tends to have a double effect on the one hand because of the returns that you have on the pension assets and also the discount rate that you used for the obligations. But at present, those things have been taking into account in terms of the guidance that we've given. And again, where our defined benefit pension plans, we think that the cash contribution will be in the order of between $45 million to $65 million this year and the expense of around $17 [ph] million, and that includes the 42% of our MillerCoors contribution and expense, obviously, that will be updated going forward for 100%.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one last one on financing financial reporting, I think, on the Investor Day in kind of walked through how you'll give us a little bit better visibility in terms of the transaction related reporting. The spring the SEC had, I guess, made som
componenttext: Okay. And just one last one on financing financial reporting, I think, on the Investor Day in kind of walked through how you'll give us a little bit better visibility in terms of the transaction related reporting. The spring the SEC had, I guess, made some rulings or statements about just sort of, I guess, more scrutiny on non-GAAP disclosures and maybe auditing it or scrutinizing it a little bit more, so can you just -- is there anything that we should think about in terms of your plans for the transaction-related reporting relative to kind of what the SEC has been commenting on?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, on the one hand, what you're saying is absolutely right. The SEC has revised their position in terms of GAAP versus non-GAAP disclosures, and we obviously are following in line with that as our many other companies, many other public companies
componenttext: Well, look, on the one hand, what you're saying is absolutely right. The SEC has revised their position in terms of GAAP versus non-GAAP disclosures, and we obviously are following in line with that as our many other companies, many other public companies in the U.S. And what that means is that in the 10-Ks and the 10-Qs, you will not now see some of the underlying measures we used to put in there before. As for the information that you would receive post transaction, obviously, that's information that you are going to receive through our calls, and we will still referred to those metrics because we think that they can give the investors and the analysts a very good indication of how our business is performing. And just to recap what we had mentioned to you at the New York analyst conference is that post the transaction close, we will be referring to a new number of updated synergies and cost savings. We are also going to talk about the transaction pro forma adjusted EPS and you're also going to talk about the cash flow generating ability of the new business going forward.

componenttext: Okay. Well, if there are no questions just now, I'd like to thank everybody for your interest in the Molson Coors Brewing Company. We are poised as we look forward to the hopeful conclusion of the transactional acquisition of the 58% in MillerCoors, which should transformational for our business so I'm sure everybody will be tuned in over the coming months as that comes to a culmination. Thank you for your interest and I look forward to seeing many of you shortly in the Boston conference at the beginning of September. Thanks for your interest today, everybody.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. On behalf of Molson Coors Brewing Company, thank you for joining us today for our second quarter 2016 follow-up earnings conference call. Our goal on this call is to address as many additional earnings related
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. On behalf of Molson Coors Brewing Company, thank you for joining us today for our second quarter 2016 follow-up earnings conference call. Our goal on this call is to address as many additional earnings related questions as possible following our regular earnings conference call with Mark Hunter, Mauricio Restrepo and our business unit CEOs earlier today. We will use a standard question and answer format and we anticipate that the call will last less than an hour. 
Before we begin, I will paraphrase the company's safe harbor language. Some of the discussion today may include forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from what the company projects today, so please refer to our most recent 10-K and 10-Q filings for a more complete description of factors that could affect the these projections. The company does not undertake to publicly update forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. You should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date they're made. 
Regarding any non-U.S. GAAP measures that may be discussed during the call and, from time to time, by our company's executives in discussing our performance, please visit the company's website, molsoncoors.com, that's www.molsoncoors.com, and click on the Financial Reporting tab at the Investor Relations page for a reconciliation of these measures to the nearest U.S. GAAP result. Also, unless otherwise indicated, all financial results the company discusses are versus the comparable prior year period and in U.S. dollars. We also encourage investors and analysts to read SABMiller PLC news releases and trading statements that include financial and other information relating to the MillerCoors joint venture. 
So let's get started with an introduction of the team with me on this call. We have Kevin Kim, Investor Relations Senior Manager; Ashley Dunlop, Finance Forecasting Senior Manager; Brian Tabolt, Controller; Jason, Treasury Director; and Mark, VP of Tax. 
So regarding quarterly results, as Mark Hunter mentioned on our regular earnings call this morning, in the second quarter, we continued to focus on our first choice ambition and on building a stronger, broader and more premium brand portfolio, underpinned by incremental sales and marketing investments as we discussed on our first quarter earnings call a few months ago. Progress in the quarter included net sales revenue per [indiscernible] growth on a constant currency basis in all of our businesses, included strong Coors Light growth globally, improved core brand momentum, fast-growing innovations in key markets and strong Above Premium growth globally. We significantly increased investments behind our brands, although the timing of shipments and other short term factors held back bottom line performance in the quarter. 
In brands, Coors Light grew volume more than 4% globally, including strong double-digit growth in Europe and Latin America and low single-digit growth in the U.S., this brand's best performance here in nearly 3 years. We continued to strengthen our business through improvements through our sales execution and revenue management capabilities, increased efficiency of our operations and implementation of global -- common global system. To ensure that our supply chain is fit for the future, in the second quarter, we reached an agreement to purchase land in British Columbia on which we will build a new efficient and flexible brewery over the next few years. This new brewery site is attractively priced, has rail access and is situated on the TransCanada Highway, making it ideal for serving the Western Canada and U.S. markets. We anticipate completing the land purchase this month. 
In the past few months, we've also made substantial progress on the pending MillerCoors transaction, including an integration planning and completing the necessary financing at very attractive rates. Investor demand for our recent debt offering was very strong, in we achieved record and near record low interest rates on our debt issue. We're pleased with the transaction progress made to date and we continue to plan for a closing before the end of 2016. 
In the balance of this year, we will continue to focus on our first choice for consumers and customers ambition, all driven through our Profit After Capital Charge and with the intent to drive total shareholder returns. 
So with that, I'd like to open it up for your questions. Over to you, Chris.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Vivien Azer from Cowen.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to circle back on the U.S. first, please. I'm just having a hard time reconciling comment from Gavin in the press release, that the second quarter started off slow, but finished strongly in June. And then, the FDR's down mid-single's through J
componenttext: So I wanted to circle back on the U.S. first, please. I'm just having a hard time reconciling comment from Gavin in the press release, that the second quarter started off slow, but finished strongly in June. And then, the FDR's down mid-single's through July 23. And I recognize you guys are getting rid of that mid-quarter commentary, but I'm still having a challenge just kind of reconciling the drop off seemingly, given the more constructive commentary in the press release. Can you help with that?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, it really gets back to what Mark was talking about on the earlier -- Gavin on the earlier call and that is, with only 3 weeks of data, relatively small changes in the timing of holidays in weather in various regions around the U.S. and so for
componenttext: Yes. I mean, it really gets back to what Mark was talking about on the earlier -- Gavin on the earlier call and that is, with only 3 weeks of data, relatively small changes in the timing of holidays in weather in various regions around the U.S. and so forth can have a disproportionate effect on those numbers and cause really quite a bit of volatility. And we've seen that pretty frequently over the many, call it, 27 years we've been providing those data points. And that actually limits their usefulness and in this particular time frame, call it, early July, you have the largest holiday of the year right on the edge of that time period, July 4, obviously in the U.S. And then if you're wondering about Canada, you've got the Canada Day holiday on July 1. Just -- yes, simply, a lot of volatility in the numbers. I think longer-term view of volume trends and brand health and so forth, they are actually more useful and that's why we talked about discontinuing those numbers upon or following completion of the transaction.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then, just on that point then, fairly notable disconnect between FDRs and STWs, so can you comment on inventory levels and whether we should anticipate seeing a normalization of those 2 trends in the back half, please?
componenttext: Understood. And then, just on that point then, fairly notable disconnect between FDRs and STWs, so can you comment on inventory levels and whether we should anticipate seeing a normalization of those 2 trends in the back half, please?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, I think, as always, you want to look at STRs and STWs sort of over a longer period of time. MillerCoors has consistently said that they plan to shift to consumption. And so they're not changing their -- or they have not indicated a change in in
componenttext: Sure. Yes, I think, as always, you want to look at STRs and STWs sort of over a longer period of time. MillerCoors has consistently said that they plan to shift to consumption. And so they're not changing their -- or they have not indicated a change in inventory policy. And so what I would do is, yes, you noticed in the second quarter there appeared to be inventory depletion of sorts, and then -- but you may have -- may recall that there was actually a bit of a build in the first quarter of this year. And if you look at FDRs and STWs on a year-to-date basis, they're within 20 basis points of each other, which tells you that there's, as always, maybe some relatively minor adjustments to wholesale inventories. But at least, on a year-to-date basis, they're largely in line.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So got a question on CapEx, you lowered the guidance and there were some technical components. What should we expect from an all-in number?
componenttext: So got a question on CapEx, you lowered the guidance and there were some technical components. What should we expect from an all-in number?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's see. Well, we haven't provided an all-in number. What I would say is that we changed the guidance in order to, well, really do 2 things. One, so we went through $300 million on our last earnings call of CapEx this year, excluding MillerCoors, down t
componenttext: Let's see. Well, we haven't provided an all-in number. What I would say is that we changed the guidance in order to, well, really do 2 things. One, so we went through $300 million on our last earnings call of CapEx this year, excluding MillerCoors, down to $220 million. The differences in 2 pieces: one, is the exclusion of the CapEx associated with the new brewery that we're going to build in British Columbia over the next 2 or 3 years; and then to the second piece would be adjustments to our capital plans, capital spending plans, for this year. So it's not just about the Vancouver brewery. So those 2 pieces. As far as essentially giving you a breakout between those pieces, which would get you to the answer to your question, we're not going to provide that level of granularity. But I guess what I would say though is that the primary driver of the 2 was the -- or -- yes, was the exclusion of the CapEx related to the Vancouver brewery.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I mean, I'll push for this [indiscernible]. But the changes...
componenttext: Okay. So I mean, I'll push for this [indiscernible]. But the changes...

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry -- [indiscernible] a good point.  At year-end, you will actually have a [indiscernible] CapEx number that includes the Vancouver brewery, so you'll get your number, just have to wait a little bit longer for it. Won't be exactly in sync with our guid
componenttext: Sorry -- [indiscernible] a good point.  At year-end, you will actually have a [indiscernible] CapEx number that includes the Vancouver brewery, so you'll get your number, just have to wait a little bit longer for it. Won't be exactly in sync with our guidance.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No significant changes. We believe we have an excellent site on which to build a new brewery, given that we can build the brewery for nearly the proceeds of the land sale in Vancouver, so the new brewery's about 100 kilometers east of Vancouver, the land
componenttext: No significant changes. We believe we have an excellent site on which to build a new brewery, given that we can build the brewery for nearly the proceeds of the land sale in Vancouver, so the new brewery's about 100 kilometers east of Vancouver, the land that we plan to close on this month. And that land is obviously much less expensive than the land that we sold because we can, not only buy new land but also build -- largely build new brewery for the -- with proceeds from that land sale, which we completed last quarter.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, just one question. Within your Q that was filed, in the discussion of working capital, there's a comment that said that we may be able to maintain these levels of working capital benefits in the long-term. Is there anything to that stateme
componenttext: Okay. And then, just one question. Within your Q that was filed, in the discussion of working capital, there's a comment that said that we may be able to maintain these levels of working capital benefits in the long-term. Is there anything to that statement? Is it just sort of normal cautionary commentary?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Working capital, particularly in a business like ours that has not only the large receivables and payables that you'd normally expect from a consumer product business but we also have a very large CapEx payments, for example, and just the timing of t
componenttext: Yes. Working capital, particularly in a business like ours that has not only the large receivables and payables that you'd normally expect from a consumer product business but we also have a very large CapEx payments, for example, and just the timing of those types of things can result in substantial movements in our working capital. And so we just like to caution people so that it doesn't surprise them if there's a bit of a swing. And it could be as little of the day or 2 difference in the payables or receivables item. And -- go ahead.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry -- but that comment is about volatility kind of year-to-year, quarter-to-quarter, not about a long-term drag from working capital.
componenttext: Sorry -- but that comment is about volatility kind of year-to-year, quarter-to-quarter, not about a long-term drag from working capital.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Long-term, we're going to drive as much cash out of the business as we can, but we're still going to put cautionary statements in our filings because it's the right thing to do.
componenttext: Right. Long-term, we're going to drive as much cash out of the business as we can, but we're still going to put cautionary statements in our filings because it's the right thing to do.

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rob Ottenstein from Evercore.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not to be the dead horse, Dave, but hopefully, to help a little bit, I think I saw somewhere that the number of shipping days in July was about 2 less than last year in the U.S., so maybe that's a driver. Can you confirm that? And if that's the case, perh
componenttext: Not to be the dead horse, Dave, but hopefully, to help a little bit, I think I saw somewhere that the number of shipping days in July was about 2 less than last year in the U.S., so maybe that's a driver. Can you confirm that? And if that's the case, perhaps, would that have been also may be the case in Canada and Europe?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Robert, that's a good point. Yes, there are, as I understand it, 2 fewer shipping days, depending on how you define those, in July this year and that would be a factor as well. And in all likelihood, it'd be a factor in a place like Europe to -- depe
componenttext: Yes, Robert, that's a good point. Yes, there are, as I understand it, 2 fewer shipping days, depending on how you define those, in July this year and that would be a factor as well. And in all likelihood, it'd be a factor in a place like Europe to -- depends a little bit in your -- the route to market that you have on a given geography. But basically, the answer is yes, that would be a factor, along with timing of holidays and weather and lots of other things going to affect such a short time frame.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And in terms of Europe, I think you mentioned that overall, you had gained about 30 basis points a share, kind of a big picture aggregate number's not as helpful as perhaps a little bit more granularity. And I know you can't give it maybe for every
componenttext: Right. And in terms of Europe, I think you mentioned that overall, you had gained about 30 basis points a share, kind of a big picture aggregate number's not as helpful as perhaps a little bit more granularity. And I know you can't give it maybe for every single country, but can you give us a sense of which countries in Europe you're gaining share, which ones you're losing share? And any notable changes?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't want to get too granular. We're talking about 11 different countries in Europe, and this is, I will just say, I guess what I would say is that as a rule, our business has performed particularly well. And this is not a specific share comment b
componenttext: Yes. I don't want to get too granular. We're talking about 11 different countries in Europe, and this is, I will just say, I guess what I would say is that as a rule, our business has performed particularly well. And this is not a specific share comment because I'm not going to give that to you. But it has performed particularly well in places like Romania, the U.K., we've talked about how strong Coors Light is there, Croatia has been doing well for a long time. And then, we've been particularly challenged in Serbia, for example.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you've had the Eastern European acquisition for a number of years now. You came into what was certain assumptions that this was actually a pretty promising long-term growth market. How -- and obviously, the economy hasn't helped us for the last few ye
componenttext: And you've had the Eastern European acquisition for a number of years now. You came into what was certain assumptions that this was actually a pretty promising long-term growth market. How -- and obviously, the economy hasn't helped us for the last few years here, but kind of as you look forward, do you -- are you still as optimistic on those markets? Or have things changed?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good point, kind of on a strategic level, I'd say yes, we're every bit as enthusiastic and optimistic about the performance potential of those central European businesses. They actually have performed very well. What has been really quite di
componenttext: Yes, that's a good point, kind of on a strategic level, I'd say yes, we're every bit as enthusiastic and optimistic about the performance potential of those central European businesses. They actually have performed very well. What has been really quite different from what we expected is actually the -- what you call it, the actual backdrop, the macroeconomic challenges of that Eurozone are obviously pretty well documented, but the actual performance of the businesses themselves have been quite good. We've had localized challenges in places like Serbia that we talked about. Originally, Romania was a particularly challenging market for us. And we've been able to make great progress in Romania and I would say meaningful progress in Serbia. The one thing that we did not anticipate when we did the transaction was the speed with which we would be able to combine the U.K. business with the Central Europe businesses. And that has allowed us to vastly increase the, call it, synergies or efficiencies of the overall Europe operating unit. And so we've had challenges like plugs, we've had macroeconomic challenges and so forth, but nonetheless, the business has performed really well and we've been able to vastly exceed our expectations for cost savings. And also, list some best practices out of the central Europe business too. Some of our other businesses, for example, our sales processes, we're now embedding in our Canada business. They've already been essentially lifted and shifted to our U.K. business. These have helped us to improve our efficiency and effectiveness in sales -- in the sales force in those geographies and obviously, there's more potential to do that going forward.
