componenttext: In the [indiscernible] can I suggest that we hear the question and it's important for us to give you an answer. So Dave and the team will try to give you that clarity. So I appreciate the question, we'll shape a response and take you through that this afternoon's call.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Shifting to the U.S., I'll just be curious, Mark or Gavin. Craft has been weak for everybody. So just from a broader industry perspective, why do you think weak craft has gotten weaker sequentially and how enduring you think that is? I know it's hard to h
componenttext: Shifting to the U.S., I'll just be curious, Mark or Gavin. Craft has been weak for everybody. So just from a broader industry perspective, why do you think weak craft has gotten weaker sequentially and how enduring you think that is? I know it's hard to have a crystal ball there, but why do you think that is? And just mechanically for U.S. business, it seems like your inventories are higher than you'd like them to be, so is it reasonable to think your own shipments will lag your STRs in the fourth quarter?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, let me split it to 2. Gavin, I'll pass it over to you on the STW, STRs section the second and let the offer a couple of headlines and craft. I didn't craft this week for everybody and that's a really generous statement. I think there's a number of c
componenttext: Mark, let me split it to 2. Gavin, I'll pass it over to you on the STW, STRs section the second and let the offer a couple of headlines and craft. I didn't craft this week for everybody and that's a really generous statement. I think there's a number of craft companies that continue to show very strong growth, and we've just acquired a number of the good thing for our business. I think what you are starting to see in the marketplace we described is probably oversupply of in SKUs or styles in SKUs in both retailers and consumers are trying to make sense of the plethora of choice, and that's against the backdrop that craft has been good for the beer industry because it's driven conversations of interest in beer to probably an all-time high. But you get to the point where each SKU has to deliver on a velocity basis and has to actually demonstrate customers and consumers. And as Gavin mentioned earlier, things like seasonal packs which been a big driver of the craft industry of really started to come under pressure because consumers are now, in essence, making up their own seasonal packs by the way they actually show up in shelves. I think what you're starting to see us from a retailer perspective, it really simplified the offering and the well marks recently as they reset all of their shares sets. So the more progressive retailers are really trying to focus on those brands have got long-term distinct positionings and drive velocity per SKU. Also think from a consumer perspective, because most of the craft growth has been driven in the back of heavily hopped IPAs, consumers are recognizing that beers are great, but they're not beers probably take here through a long location and were starting to see some consumer step back into some of the American light brands. So I think it's just craft starting to kind of shake itself out with the brands well-positioned, clearly distinctive of that the retailers really starting to simplify their offer. And that's in think that starting to have an impact over all in the craft velocity or craft trends. Gavin, I don't know if you want to add anything to that and then pick up the STW, STRs questions?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Anything I'd add to that, which is pretty much what you said, of choice and there's not a lot of force velocity of retail as important and that's why building with beer program, which we've launched and Mark talked quite a lot about this it had such
componenttext: Yes. Anything I'd add to that, which is pretty much what you said, of choice and there's not a lot of force velocity of retail as important and that's why building with beer program, which we've launched and Mark talked quite a lot about this it had such a positive impact with retail not only on premise but also off premise. As far as the STWs STRs are concerned, fundamental leaders just a difference in timing if you remember the at the end of Q2, that dynamic was reversed and domestic is down, STRs were down less than that year-to-date basis of those 2 numbers are much closer. And generally, we drive around those things much closer by the end of the year as we try to ship to consumption, so I wouldn't get too worked up on quarter-over-quarter because of timing holiday price increases and so on.

componenttext: I'm going to hold off on the free cash flow questions until 1:00. Dave, this could be one of the most anticipated calls 1:00 in a while, I think. So my question is just related to the cost savings and if you could give us some -- outside of the synergies, if you could give us some sense of like what's included and what's not you got the processor going through in Vancouver in terms of selling the brewery and you'll migrate to a new brewery there. I guess this a potential the same thing could happen in Montré, al is Eden, 0the Eden, Carolina brewery inside at savings, just any sense of some of those bigger items that that may be in there would be helpful.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mauricio, do you want to give specifics on that?
componenttext: Mauricio, do you want to give specifics on that?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So with respect to the cost savings, I mean some of the items that you allude to -- that you alluded to during your questions are indeed there. So for example, the savings that will come from the Eden Brewery closure are included in there. The work that w
componenttext: So with respect to the cost savings, I mean some of the items that you allude to -- that you alluded to during your questions are indeed there. So for example, the savings that will come from the Eden Brewery closure are included in there. The work that we are continually doing in terms of looking at our procurement in addition to these savings related to procurement that are in the synergy number and as Mark referenced to earlier, we made a concerted effort to ensure that we've separated what is sort of business as usual savings, which is a way of doing business here from the piece that's going to come specifically from the synergies. There are also other savings that are coming from looking at our supply chain network that are not included in the synergy piece of the optimization of the North America supply chain grid. So just a lot of savings that are coming from our business as usual, running -- running the business vis-à-vis the synergies that have specifically to do with those 3 buckets that we alluded to earlier.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mark. Another context point I'll give you is, over the course of the last 3 or 4 years, enterprise-level, we tried to drive for what we describe as our one-way principles. So across our major functional areas to try and drive for consistency of appro
componenttext: It's Mark. Another context point I'll give you is, over the course of the last 3 or 4 years, enterprise-level, we tried to drive for what we describe as our one-way principles. So across our major functional areas to try and drive for consistency of approach world-class supply chain were one way, we're now introducing that from a commercial perspective in terms of our commercial excellence approach. Really trying to drive for best practice orientation and consistency of approach wherever we can in the business, and that's been one of the drivers were unlocking additional efficiency savings for our business. I think a big part is been in a world-class supply chain where we truly believe that we are at world class or close to world class in many areas. So we'll continue to crank the handle on that and drive as much value and efficiency as we can over those areas well as the synergy opportunity as well.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Robert Ottenstein with Evercore.
componenttext: Our next question is from Robert Ottenstein with Evercore.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Gavin, we understand certainly the goals on the improvement in the volumes for trajectory for 2018, 2019. If that doesn't pan out and if we have a continuation of the current trends, what sort of opportunities would there be, do you think, in terms of managing the brewery footprint to address that?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, do you mind if I take that question?
componenttext: Mark, do you mind if I take that question?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go, Gavin.
componenttext: Go, Gavin.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not planning to fail, right? I mean I think we've got the right plants, the right strategies, the right brands and the right people to get this done, and I wouldn't look at this on a simple quarter basis. This is a longer-term plan. The industry had a
componenttext: I'm not planning to fail, right? I mean I think we've got the right plants, the right strategies, the right brands and the right people to get this done, and I wouldn't look at this on a simple quarter basis. This is a longer-term plan. The industry had a tough quarter surely, but our expectations are still flat in 2018 with growth in 2019. And I can run you through all the high-level plans that we got in our brands, but we as a business are certainly focused on that goal and believe we will achieve it.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Robert, the only color I'll add there is an enterprise-level, we're committed to supporting Gavin and the team to make that happen. And there's been a lot of questions over the course of the last 12 to 18 months on how will we get there, and we try t
componenttext: And, Robert, the only color I'll add there is an enterprise-level, we're committed to supporting Gavin and the team to make that happen. And there's been a lot of questions over the course of the last 12 to 18 months on how will we get there, and we try to really simplify this thinking in 3 specific areas. Our Economy, our Below Premium strategy and many of clarity on our thinking there that's now been clarified and launched and a lot of excitement but the distributors. Many of you have asked about our ability to get Coors Light and the Miller Lite growing at the same time and we're now doing that consistently. And alongside, the Coors Banquet is going from strength to strength, and we continue to drive premiumization of our portfolio, and the craft acquisitions and Henry is a great example. The forget which are now such a significant brand didn't even exist just over 3 years ago. And my view is that we still have untapped opportunities in our own portfolio as well. So the component parts are there along with them to we want to be from an execution perspective. But Gavin and the leadership team have driven a significant change in ambition, the energy and the focus in our U.S. business, and it's been great to see that happening. And some quarters will be tougher than others, but we're resolute on ambition to get this business back into growth trajectory. And as Gavin said, that's over the course of the next couple of years.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's terrific. On the international side, can you give us -- and I so know some of this may have come out earlier on in the prelude, but can you give us an update of where you are on the Miller brands globally? And has there been any new agreements in t
componenttext: That's terrific. On the international side, can you give us -- and I so know some of this may have come out earlier on in the prelude, but can you give us an update of where you are on the Miller brands globally? And has there been any new agreements in terms of supply and distribution?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me ask who's obviously transitioning at the moment from his previous role across Kandy has been leading that stream of work. So Kandy, do you want to offer some highlights around that?
componenttext: Yes. So let me ask who's obviously transitioning at the moment from his previous role across Kandy has been leading that stream of work. So Kandy, do you want to offer some highlights around that?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So good progress in terms of planning and executing the transition of the Miller brands into our systems because it's relatively easier in places like Canada and U.K., which came on to our business footprint. We have a series of markets where we hav
componenttext: Sure. So good progress in terms of planning and executing the transition of the Miller brands into our systems because it's relatively easier in places like Canada and U.K., which came on to our business footprint. We have a series of markets where we have existing partners. Panama, Honduras as an example that we move the distribution on to our existing partners. In the markets which are near loss, we have established with 1 or 2 exceptions, almost all of them new distribution agreements that are in place. In terms of production, we are relying either on our infrastructure like MillerCoors. And in certain cases, we are continuing to rely on traditional agreements via ABI, and we'll be working to transition those into our own system as well. But on the whole, I'm very pleased and are all involved in this in terms of transitioning over into our setup. Our initial 2 to 3 weeks has gone without any significant issues, and so we are quite pleased with the transition.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you able to discuss who -- in the more notable markets, are you able to discuss how any of the new partners are?
componenttext: Are you able to discuss who -- in the more notable markets, are you able to discuss how any of the new partners are?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't made any public statements around that other than markets like Panama, we have an existing partner there, and we've transitioned across, but I think I would probably say that maybe until our Q4 February call. Robert can give us a similar update
componenttext: We haven't made any public statements around that other than markets like Panama, we have an existing partner there, and we've transitioned across, but I think I would probably say that maybe until our Q4 February call. Robert can give us a similar update just because we are working through some of the finer detail at this point in time. But where there's not a partner in place, there are TSAs, transition service agreements, in place. And as I mentioned earlier, some of the markets are doing better than we anticipated, some of the markets are going to take a bit more work to get back on the front as you would expect in a transition of this nature, but we'll give probably more color and a fuller update on our February call.

componenttextpreview: I'd just like to thank everybody for their continuing interest in Molson Coors. We've opened a new chapter in the history of our business. And as the leadership team, we're delighted to be leading the business forward from this position, and we look forwa
componenttext: I'd just like to thank everybody for their continuing interest in Molson Coors. We've opened a new chapter in the history of our business. And as the leadership team, we're delighted to be leading the business forward from this position, and we look forward to updating you as we make our business bigger and stronger in the coming quarters ahead. So thank you for your continued interest in our business. Thanks, everybody.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Molson Coors Brewing Company Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Before we begin, I would like to paraphrase the company's safe harbor language. Some of the discussion today may include forwa
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Molson Coors Brewing Company Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
Before we begin, I would like to paraphrase the company's safe harbor language. Some of the discussion today may include forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from what the company projects today, so please refer to its most recent 10-K and 10-Q filings for a more complete description of factors that could affect these projections.
The company does not undertake to publicly update forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. You should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date they are made.
Regarding any non-U.S. GAAP measures that may be discussed during the call and from time-to-time by the company's executives in discussing the company's performance, please visit the company's website, www.molsoncoors.com, and click on the Financial Reporting tab of the Investor Relations page for a reconciliation of these measures to the nearest U.S. GAAP results. Also, unless otherwise indicated, all financial results the company discusses are versus the comparable prior year period and in U.S. dollars.
Now I would like to turn the call over to Mark Hunter, President and CEO of Molson Coors. You may begin, sir.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chad. And hello, and welcome, everybody, to the Molson Coors earnings call, and many thanks for joining us today. With me on the call this morning from Molson Coors, we have Mauricio Restrepo, our Global CFO; Gavin Hattersley, our CEO of our U.
componenttext:
Thank you, Chad. And hello, and welcome, everybody, to the Molson Coors earnings call, and many thanks for joining us today. With me on the call this morning from Molson Coors, we have Mauricio Restrepo, our Global CFO; Gavin Hattersley, our CEO of our U.S. business; Fred Landtmeters, the CEO of our Canada business; Simon Cox, the CEO of our Europe business; and Stewart Glendinning, the CEO of our International business; along with Sam Walker, our Global Chief Legal Officer; and David Dunnewald, our VP of Investor Relations.
Today, Mauricio and I will split our call into 2 parts. First, we will take you through our third quarter 2016 results to, in essence, close out Molson Coors Brewing Company as it's been structured for the past several years. Then we'll turn our attention to our recently completed MillerCoors transaction and [indiscernible] updated financial reporting metrics, along with some perspective for the fourth quarter of this year.
And in third quarter, we continue to focus on our First Choice ambition and on building a stronger, broader and more premium brand portfolio, underpinned by incremental sales and marketing investment as we've discussed all year.
Business highlights for the quarter and year-to-date included: Increased net sales revenue per hectoliter on a constant currency basis in all of our businesses for the quarter and year-to-date. We increased investments in our brands globally. Coors Light Miller Lite again gained share in the U.S. Premium Lite segment for the quarter, including the highest segment share gain in 3 years for Coors Light. We saw 1.2% global volume growth for Coors Light on a year-to-date basis with growth of more than 14% outside of North America.
We had fast-growing innovations in key markets, including Henry's hard soda in the U.S. and Mad Jack in Canada, and we saw global growth year-to-date in our Above Premium portfolio through, for example, Doom Bar and other Sharp's craft brands in the U.K., Creemore Springs and Belgian Moon in Canada and our 4 newly acquired brewers in the U.S. We also saw a strong growth by Staropramen across Europe outside of its whole market. And we also additionally saw cider volume increases with Rekorderlig in Europe and Strongbow in Canada. 
Overall, we continue to strengthen our business through improvements to our sales execution and revenue management capabilities, increased efficiency of our operations and implementation of common global systems. 
Regional highlights for the third quarter and year-to-date are as follows: In the U.S., overall sales to retail volume decreased 4% for the quarter and 2.5% year-to-date on a trailing day adjusted basis, driven primarily by our Below Premium and Premium Light brands. Coors Light and Miller Lite again gained segment market share while STRs declined, reflecting industry trends. Coors Banquet continued to grow STR volume and segment share. And in the higher-margin Above Premium segment, Henry's continues to be the #1 hard soda franchise. Also, our Saint Archer, Terrapin, Hop Valley and Revolver businesses have significantly expanded our craft offering for consumers and customers. 
Domestic net sales revenue per hectoliter grew 1.6% for the quarter and 1.2% year-to-date as a result of favorable net pricing and positive sales mix. On the bottom line, U.S. segment underlying equity income increased 9% in the third quarter, driven primarily by lower cost of goods sold, higher net pricing and positive sales mix. Year-to-date underlying equity income increased 9.3%, primarily due to the factors mentioned above, as well as a $12.3 million anticipated refund of federal excise tax paid in imports, which we discussed on our last earnings call.
In Canada, net sales per hectoliter in local currency increased 0.6%, driven by growth in our Above Premium brands. This NSR increase reflected headline price increases and positive brand mix, but with higher levels of spin back as we ensured our brands are competitive on a market-by-market basis. 
Our performance in the Above Premium segment continue to be strong as we saw growth in both our own brands and our partner brands. Coors Banquet, Mad Jack and Belgian Moon all continue to deliver strong growth, and our craft brands continued to grow share of the total beer category. 
The mainstream segment continued to face market pressure where our brand health scores for Coors Light and Molson Canadian have continued to improve month-over-month, and our sales execution input measures are similarly improving.
Our COGS per hectoliter increased 3.5% in local currency, with most of the increase being driven by volume deleverage and mix shift to higher-cost products. Our cost savings program continue to be strong and fully offset the impacts of inflation and other cost increases in the quarter. And the bottom line underlying pretax income declined by $15.9 million in the third quarter, driven by lower volume, increased COGS, higher marketing investments and foreign exchange impacts of U.S. dollar-based supplier contracts.
Europe net sales decreased 0.6% in local currency for the third quarter, driven by 1.4% lower volume due to weaker demand versus strong sales last year across much of the region, along with some trade inventory overhang from the Euro 2016 football or soccer championships in the second quarter this year.
Nonetheless, we held our share position in the region, and our continued portfolio premiumization and mix management drove a 1.2% increase in net sales revenue per hectoliter from local currency. In the quarter, we achieved strong growth by Coors Light, Staropramen outside of the Czech Republic and our craft portfolios, including Blue Moon, Doom Bar and the other Sharp's brands, as well as Rekorderlig Cider. Underlying pretax income was lower in the quarter due to higher brand amortization expenses, lower net pension benefit and unfavorable foreign currency movements, especially related to the depreciation of the British pound. Year-to-date, the benefit of higher net sales and NSR per hectoliter from local currency volume and market share in Europe were more than offset by unfavorable foreign currency movements, higher brand amortization expense, lower pension benefits and the termination of the Heineken contract brewing arrangements in the U.K.
Our International business continues to drive Coors Light momentum with year-to-date volume for this brand, up mid single digits, led by growth in Latin America and Australia. Excluding the impact of total alcohol prohibition in Bihar, India and the transfer of the Staropramen U.K. business to our Europe segment, our year-to-date underlying pretax performance has significantly improved versus last year, driven by volume growth in the remaining international markets.
Now I'll turn it over to Mauricio to give third quarter financial highlights and new performance metrics. Mauricio?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark, and hello, everybody. As a reminder, all of the results that I will be discussing are in U.S. dollars, unless otherwise noted. So our third quarter and year-to-date financial headlines are as follows: Net sales were down approximately
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark, and hello, everybody. As a reminder, all of the results that I will be discussing are in U.S. dollars, unless otherwise noted. 
So our third quarter and year-to-date financial headlines are as follows: 
Net sales were down approximately 7% in U.S. dollars in the third quarter and about 5% year-to-date, primarily due to currency movements, especially in Europe, as well as lower worldwide volume. On a constant currency basis, net sales decreased 2.2% in the third quarter and were virtually unchanged year-to-date versus the same period last year. Our net sales per hectoliter in constant currency increased 1.3% in the quarter and 0.9% year-to-date due to positive mix. 
On a U.S. GAAP basis, we reported third quarter after-tax income from continuing operations attributable to Molson Coors of $202.5 million, up from $13.7 million a year ago. This increase was primarily driven by cycling $275 million of impairment charges recorded for certain Europe brands last year. On a year-to-date basis, U.S. GAAP after-tax income increased 67.5% to $539.8 million, driven by brand impairment charges last year and a gain on the sale of our Vancouver brewery earlier this year. Third quarter underlying after-tax income decreased 14.3% to $222.7 million or $1.03 per diluted share, driven by lower worldwide volume, a higher underlying tax rate and higher brand investments globally, which were partially offset by positive mix and higher underlying U.S. equity income.
Year-to-date underlying after-tax income decreased 5.5% to $576.4 million, driven by the same factors as in the quarter, along with negative foreign currency movements. Underlying pretax income declined 6.2% for the third quarter and 1.3% year-to-date. Underlying EBITDA in the quarter was $403.1 million, 4.1% lower than a year ago, and our year-to-date underlying EBITDA declined 0.8%. 
Underlying free cash flow in the first 3 quarters of 2016 was $469.4 million. This represents a decrease of $24.9 million from the prior year, primarily driven by lower underlying after-tax income and lower distributions from MillerCoors. 
Total debt at the end of the third quarter was $9.9 billion. Cash and cash equivalents totaled slightly less than $10 billion, resulting in a net cash position of $94 million as we prepared to close the MillerCoors transaction on October 11. Please see the earnings release we distributed earlier this morning for a detailed review of our business unit financial results in the quarter. Also, please see the Investor Relations page of our website this morning for updated 2015 full year and 2016 year-to-date pro forma financial statements that reflect our preliminary purchase accounting for the transaction.
Now looking forward to the remainder of 2016, following are some financial quarters to consider for the fourth quarter. 
Our Europe business results will continue to reflect lower net pension benefits. Total alcohol prohibition in Bihar has presented a headwind in our International business since its enactment in April this year, and we will continue to address this within our business. And finally foreign currency translation, which at current exchange rate, would be a headwind of approximately $8 million to our underlying pretax results in the fourth quarter this year, with all of the impact in Europe. Given the volatility of our key foreign currencies, particularly the British pound, it is important to watch these rates closely.
Now regarding 2016 guidance, all of the following metrics exclude any effects of the MillerCoors and Miller global brands transaction. For the full year, we continue to expect cash contributions to our defined benefit pension plans to be in the range of $45 million to $65 million in 2016 and pension expense of approximately $17 million including our 42% of MillerCoors contributions and expense. Underlying capital spending of approximately $220 million, which excludes capital this year related to the construction of our new brewery in British Columbia, which we expect to be largely funded by the proceeds from the sale of our Vancouver brewery earlier this month. MG&A expense in Corporate of approximately $120 million on an underlying basis, which excludes expenses related to the MillerCoors transaction. Consolidated net interest expense of approximately $110 million on an underlying basis, which excludes transaction-related interest expense and income.  An underlying effective tax rate in the range of 18% to 22%, assuming no further changes in tax laws, settlement of tax audits, excess tax deductions for share-based compensation or adjustments to our uncertain tax position. As far as our cost outlook is concerned, we continue to expect full year 2016 cost of goods sold per hectoliter in Canada and Europe to increase at a low single-digit rate in local currency, and we expect a low single-digit decrease in MillerCoors and a double-digit increase in international versus prior year.  As we first mentioned several months ago, with the completion of the MillerCoors transaction, we are no longer providing the most recent volume trends for each of our businesses. 
Earlier this year, we told you that we would share more specifics regarding 3 new performance metrics with you once the transaction closed. These metrics are:  Transaction adjusted EPS, an all-in multiyear cost savings target and an early view of our combined company underlying free cash flow target for 2017 So taking these in order, transaction adjusted EPS is a new non-GAAP performance measure we are introducing to provide enhanced visibility to the performance and value of our company post transaction. To calculate this measure, we start with underlying book EPS, a non-GAAP measure, and then add back after-tax book amortization that is directly related to the transaction, and we then add the transaction related cash tax benefits. Based on our latest pro forma financial statements, which we will post on our website this morning, our 2015 pro forma transaction adjusted EPS was $6.11 per diluted share on an underlying basis. This calculation includes transaction-related after-tax book amortization of approximately $42 million and cash tax benefits of $275 million per year, but it does not include any pretax income related to the Miller global brands nor any benefit from deal synergies. Because the routes to market and supply-chain structures for many of the Miller global brands markets are being developed, the cost and margin structure for these businesses are also work-in-progress. As a result, we have decided to exclude the Miller global brands from our pro forma results for periods prior to the close of the transaction. 
For the first 3 quarters of 2016, pro forma transaction adjusted EPS was $5.43 per diluted share, an increase of 4% versus $5.22 per diluted share for the first 3 quarters of 2015.
Going on to our second metric, cost savings over the next 3 years. We have set an all-in target of $550 million, which will be made up of ongoing cost savings in all of our businesses, as well as transaction-related synergies, all of which will be delivered by the third full year of our combined company, which is 2019. Approximately half of this 3-year cost savings target is synergies, which represents a synergy goal that is nearly 40% larger and 25% faster than the original $200 million synergies target over 4 years that we shared with you when we announced the transaction nearly a year ago. We expect the synergies delivery to be weighted towards years 2 and 3, while the other cost savings will be weighted towards years 1 and 2 of the program. As we have been discussing for the past year, we expect these cost savings to come primarily from the areas of global procurement and shared services, along with North American supply chain so they will primarily benefit the cost of goods sold line. As part of the planning process for the past year, we have also identified a moderate amount of savings from information systems. Please note that we do not plan to provide additional specifics regarding annual phasing of the cost savings or a detailed breakout of transaction-related synergies versus other cost savings. 
Related to this cost savings goal, we anticipate incurring approximately $350 million of onetime incremental cash costs over 3 years to capture synergies, about evenly split between incremental capital spending and cash operating expense, primarily in the first 2 years of the program. Note that the incremental CapEx would be on top of our recent all-in CapEx run rate of approximately $650 million to $700 million, plus or minus 10%, including 100% of MillerCoors CapEx in recent years. With a base CapEx spend of approximately $2.1 billion over the past 3 years, the CapEx needed to capture synergies represents an increment of less than 10% to our current run rate.  We will continue to apply our PACC model to these and all other significant potential capital and cash deployment decisions to help ensure that they are aligned with our priorities. 
Finally, as always, when these cost savings initiatives are completed in 3 years, we will continue to pursue cost reductions across our business in order to provide resources to help drive our top line, bottom line and shareholder value. 
Finally, to help you model our business, we also want to share our preliminary underlying free cash flow target for 2017, which is $1.1 billion, plus or minus 10%. Note that this target includes the impact of incremental interest expense, U.S. tax expense and synergies-related CapEx in 2017 as well as the cash tax benefits resulting from the transaction. As in the past, we plan to report back to you each year regarding how we are performing against these targets.
So at this point, I'll turn it back over to Mark for highlights of the transaction, business outlook and Q&A. Mark?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mauricio. This clearly is a historic time in the evolution of Molson Coors. Three weeks ago, we completed our acquisition of the remaining 58% stake in the MillerCoors joint venture, along with the Miller global brand portfolio. We emerged as the
componenttext:
Thanks, Mauricio. This clearly is a historic time in the evolution of Molson Coors. Three weeks ago, we completed our acquisition of the remaining 58% stake in the MillerCoors joint venture, along with the Miller global brand portfolio. We emerged as the world's third largest brewer, bringing together Molson Coors and MillerCoors into a bigger, better organization. As one company with an expanded portfolio of iconic brands, we intend to leverage our increased scale, resources, synergies and combined commercial experience to accelerate our First Choice agenda and deliver long-term shareholder value. Because of this game-changing transaction, Molson Coors now controls 100% of the highly strategic and attractive U.S. business and will accelerate new growth opportunities in emerging and developed beer markets globally through the Miller brand rights. This transaction also includes our operating efficiency and go-to-market strategy by step-changing our commercial capability on a truly global scale. Financially, this is a compelling combination based on a very attractive price, planned operational synergies, substantial cash tax benefits and the attractive financial package that we put in place earlier this year.
As a reminder, for $12 billion of cash, we have purchased the remaining 58% of the MillerCoors joint venture that we didn't already own. Sole ownership of the Miller brands, which outside of the U.S., will be managed in more than 50 countries by our Molson Coors International, Molson Coors Canada, Molson Coors Europe businesses; perpetual royalty-free U.S. licensees for the existing SAB Miller import and licensed brands, including Peroni, Pilsner Urquell, Foster's, Grolsch and Redd's, for which MillerCoors most recently paid royalties of approximately $16 [ph] million in 2015. And finally, because this is an asset transaction for U.S. tax purposes, we will see immediate cash tax benefits that we now estimate will exceed $275 million annually for the next 15 years. This represents an increase from our previous estimate of more than $250 million per year due to the detailed tax diligence work that we've completed during the past year. 
The purchase price implies a headline enterprise value multiple of 11.5x 2015 combined underlying EBITDA. By including the present value of the cash tax benefits, the purchase multiple drops in effect of 9.2x. These tax benefits are common with this type of asset transaction, and they carry a high degree of certainty. As such, we believe this is the most appropriate way to value this combination. This represents a very attractive purchase multiple even though it does not include the anticipated benefit of our transaction-related synergies. We expect this combination to be accretive to underlying diluted EPS and transaction adjusted EPS in the first full year of operations before synergies, and we expected to meet our PACC hurdle rates in year 1, which is consistent with our disciplined use of cash framework.
Now looking forward as a combined company, our teams are focused on driving our First Choice agenda, finishing the year with strong performance in each of our businesses and hitting the ground running on integration. You've heard us speak about these themes in the past, but each of our businesses will continue to focus on transforming our portfolio to the Above Premium segment, introducing value-driving innovation, integrating the Miller brands and lifting and shifting best practices and talent across our global organization.
To provide just a few examples by business. In the U.S., Tenth and Blake will focus on the development and integration of these new craft partners in Archer, Terrapin, Hop valley and Revolver. In FMBs, Henry's will add a new hard grape flavor to its line of hard sodas, while introducing a new line of hard sparkling waters in the growing alcohol sparkling water category. Henry's hard sparkling will be launched nationally in March with lemon and lime and passion fruit flavors. Redd's and Blue Moon Belgian White will introduce new aluminum paint packaging in the second quarter of 2017. 
Over the past few months, we've built a strategy that elevates across our economy portfolio. For example, Miller highlight recently announced plans to reintroduce new advertising created that brings back its classic jingle, "If you've got time, we've got the beer," while also revamping its packaging to further play up it's unique heritage. 
Elsewhere across the Economy portfolio, Hams will be reintroduced nationally at an opening price point and Milwaukee's Best is getting a total packaging update to give a fresh new look. And beginning early in 2017, we'll fully revamp Keystone Light including all new packaging and advertising. 
For our innovation in the value category, we are introducing spiked watermelon, to the still reserve brand family, and we're increasing the size of our PET bottle singles from 40 MCs to 42 MCs for the same price, again, to deliver value to our consumers and customers. 
In Canada, our team is integrating the Miller brands back into our portfolio and will double down on Above Premium MGD. We're also assessing the opportunities for Miller High Life and other U.S. brands that we can lift and shift to the Canada market. Mad Jack is performing well in the FMB space and we will consider other innovative options that will drive value for our Canada consumers and customers.
In Europe, we now have the Miller brands in the U.K. and Ireland, and this business is also preparing to begin managing the international license and export business in the region starting on January 1. This will allow us to drive Staropramen, Carling and other lead brands with fully aligned strategies across Europe. We'll also continue to build our craft portfolio, including further expansion of Blue Moon across the region.
Our International business is well on the way to full integration of the Miller global brands into our portfolio, and we're leveraging a new footprint that complements our growth strategy in emerging markets. For example, in Panama and Honduras, where our partners are have already embraced Coors Light, we're ready to accelerate growth with the addition of the Miller brands. The International team has also begun planning -- the planning process for transitioning Puerto Rico over for MillerCoors on January 1. Going forward, the Coors and Miller brands will be the priority brands for our International business. 
To summarize, we're delighted to have completed the MillerCoors transaction, which is a compelling strategic and financial opportunity for our company and our shareholders that catapults Molson Coors to the next level. And this combination fits into our key priorities in 3 specific areas. 
Firstly, in brand lead growth, the cash tax benefits and cost savings made possible by this transaction provide resources that we can invest in accelerating the transformation at the front end of our business, through, for example, investing behind our core brands across all of our geographies, premiumizing our portfolio and engaging with consumers in new ways, including cross-border exchange of category changing innovation, expanding the depth and reach of our international brands in fast-growing markets, including securing a certain and aligned future for the Miller brands globally, and finally, leveraging our shared commercial capability through extraordinary brand building world-class insights, digital leadership and unrivaled customer excellence.
Secondly, this transformation of our company offers unique opportunities for us to drive cash through a substantial tax benefits, cost synergies, cross-border working capital improvements and disciplined use of our PACC model across the combined company. We expect all of these benefits to provide strong free cash flow and allow us to quickly pay down acquisition debt and maintain our commitment's investment grade debt ratings. 
And thirdly, this transaction represents a prudent high-return use of cash Molson Coors and our shareholders. We're using this transaction not only to make Molson Coors a bigger company but also a better company without integration complexity normally found in a deal of this size. As we focus on deleveraging our balance sheet over the next 2 to 3 years, we've suspended our share repurchase program and have announced that we plan to maintain our current dividend per share level, and we'll revisit our dividend policy once deleveraging is well underway. Overall, this combination is a game-changer in our ambition to become first choice for consumers and customers, and it's highly consistent with our goals and our focus on building extraordinary brands, delivering innovation and driving significant value to our shareholders.
Now before we start the Q&A portion of the call, just a quick comment. As usual, our prepared remarks will be in our website for your reference within a couple of hours this afternoon. Also at 1 p.m. Eastern Time today, Dave Dunnewald will host a follow-up conference call, which is an opportunity for you to ask additional questions regarding our quarterly results. This call will also be available for you to hear via our webcast in our web site. So at this point, Chad, we'd like to open up for questions.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from Wendy Nicholson with Citi Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from Wendy Nicholson with Citi Research.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick clarifying question. That $1.1 billion free cash flow number, did that include or exclude the costs required to get your synergies? Just a housekeeping item. And then second thing, of the $550 million of savings to come, can you talk specific
componenttext: Just a quick clarifying question. That $1.1 billion free cash flow number, did that include or exclude the costs required to get your synergies? Just a housekeeping item. And then second thing, of the $550 million of savings to come, can you talk specifically about how much reinvestment, specifically in advertising, you expect to redeploy? I know some of the strength in Coors Light is probably a function of the fact that spending is up a lot in the year-to-date period in the U.S. So I'm just wondering about sort of targeted reinvestment levels, if you can help us.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wendy, thanks for your question. I think, well, 2 questions there. Let me just touch on the savings number, and then Mauricio can just clarify in the free cash flow number. With regards to savings, we don't offer guidance as to how we'll allocate those sa
componenttext: Wendy, thanks for your question. I think, well, 2 questions there. Let me just touch on the savings number, and then Mauricio can just clarify in the free cash flow number. With regards to savings, we don't offer guidance as to how we'll allocate those savings through our business. I don't want to constrain our business with any specific formula. Clearly, as we drive the savings, they'll either drop to the bottom line or be reinvested back into our business or offset, for example, inflation in our business. We continue to review our sales and marketing investment on a geography-by-geography basis. We now have a return on marketing investment model, which is allowing us to drive significant efficiencies in our marketing spend, and we'll continue to monitor our level of spend in each of our markets to make sure that we can support our brands in a way that allows them to be competitive, but we're not going to offer specific guidance on  allocation of those savings. On the free cash flow number, Mauricio, do you want to just clarify?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The $1.1 billion is after taking into account the costs required to deliver the synergy.
componenttext: Yes. The $1.1 billion is after taking into account the costs required to deliver the synergy.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. But just us a follow-up sort of conceptually, I know you said earmarks that you're pleased that the Coors Light brand health scores have improved. To what do you attributable that? I mean, again, we've tracked the advertising spending and it looks
componenttext: Got it. But just us a follow-up sort of conceptually, I know you said earmarks that you're pleased that the Coors Light brand health scores have improved. To what do you attributable that? I mean, again, we've tracked the advertising spending and it looks like that's gone up a lot in the U.S. But is there other stuff specifically that you can call out that you're doing, whether its distribution, whether it's work with your sales force that's leading to those stronger brand health scores per se?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we could get lots and lots of detail here, Wendy. And across all of our businesses, we've seen Coors Light go from strength to strength, and I think what's at the heart of that is the clarity of the positioning of the brand, which is distinct
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we could get lots and lots of detail here, Wendy. And across all of our businesses, we've seen Coors Light go from strength to strength, and I think what's at the heart of that is the clarity of the positioning of the brand, which is distinctive and consistent. So I've said in the past, I would rather spend less money on a great idea than more money on a poor idea, and I actually think we've got a clarity of positioning and a great, creative platform, certainly, across our International U.S. and our European business. We've now started to transfer the U.S. creative platform into our Canada business as well. And as we've done that, we've seen our brand health scores accelerate in Canada through the last couple of quarters. So I really think it comes down to the differentiation in strength instead of consistency of the positioning.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me deal with that. So if you remember, the time we announced the definitive agreement to acquire the MillerCoors business, we've done some very quick, reasonably well-informed, analysis on cost savings opportunity, and we suggested it would be around
componenttext: Let me deal with that. So if you remember, the time we announced the definitive agreement to acquire the MillerCoors business, we've done some very quick, reasonably well-informed, analysis on cost savings opportunity, and we suggested it would be around $200 million over 4 years. We had the benefit of very, very detailed planning now over the course of the last 8 or 9 months, and that work has unearthed further opportunities, and really spin the detail planning that's allowed us to move with more pace and set a target that's materially higher than our initial target.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: But just in terms of the 3 buckets that you guys had previously identified, is there any one bucket that's driving an outsized contribution to that more constructive view?
componenttext: But just in terms of the 3 buckets that you guys had previously identified, is there any one bucket that's driving an outsized contribution to that more constructive view?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't given any color on the proportionality of the cost savings, but the 3 areas that we flagged historically in terms of procurement, North American supply chain, shared services, we've endorsed those numbers that we had originally. In some areas,
componenttext: We haven't given any color on the proportionality of the cost savings, but the 3 areas that we flagged historically in terms of procurement, North American supply chain, shared services, we've endorsed those numbers that we had originally. In some areas, they have improved. And in addition to that, we've unlocked some additional synergies in the area of IT systems as we consolidate our IT infrastructure, and we're pushing now into areas around commercial as well, particularly our North American label, as we look at the efficiency of our creative platforms there. So but in their own, it's still pretty much the same areas that we have identified initially. And hopefully, you would expect that because our familiarity with the business is high, so we went into this with a reasonably good estimate as to where we could drive the volume.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. That's very helpful. Moving on to Canada, I would've expected a slightly better outcome, given the level of investment spending that we saw in 2Q. So I was hoping you could comment a little bit more on that. I think you noted the softness in main
componenttext: Perfect. That's very helpful. Moving on to Canada, I would've expected a slightly better outcome, given the level of investment spending that we saw in 2Q. So I was hoping you could comment a little bit more on that. I think you noted the softness in mainstream, so it's really a 2-part question. Do you think that the investment spending is doing what it needs to? And as you think ahead to 2017, what potential impact to do you think the legalization of recreational cannabis could have on the beer industry in Canada could have in the beer industry in Canada?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would describe that as a broad spectrum touched on by your 2 questions, Vivien. I wasn't expecting the second part of that. So well, I'm chatting Stewart yet thinking. I mean, just a couple of comments on the first part in terms of performance in the qu
componenttext: I would describe that as a broad spectrum touched on by your 2 questions, Vivien. I wasn't expecting the second part of that. So well, I'm chatting Stewart yet thinking. I mean, just a couple of comments on the first part in terms of performance in the quarter, our strategy remains consistent in Canada around making sure that we modernize our supply chain and drive our costs down, taking further cost out of our business and then improving our overall commercial performance. You're aware of some of the changes that we've made at leadership level. And as Fred and -- Fred's #2 in the customer areas [indiscernible] move across from Europe. Their absolute focus will be on commercial execution, really driving our field sales management and model and really, I think, deploying more assertive execution in the marketplace. That started to show up in some of our input measures. But Stewart, do you want to offer just a little bit more color on the third quarter, the things that you're pleased about? And then if you can think about the recreational drugs questions as well and offer a perspective on that, that would be helpful.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. 100%, Mark. So looking at the third quarter, 3 big drivers of the result. First, FX -- transactional FX related to U.S. sourcing of raw materials, lower volumes and higher marketing spend. And on the volume side, Mark pointed out that we are seeing s
componenttext: Yes. 100%, Mark. So looking at the third quarter, 3 big drivers of the result. First, FX -- transactional FX related to U.S. sourcing of raw materials, lower volumes and higher marketing spend. And on the volume side, Mark pointed out that we are seeing some  green shoots.  I mean, we've been growing share in the Atlantic provinces. The West, which is -- has been a difficult area for us in September, as we saw progress in the third quarter, September, actually, was flat share. In Ontario, a big beer market for us. We saw growing share in the LCBO  and in the on-premise. So the number of tough areas is actually shrinking, and I think our increased execution certainly will help that. At the same time, the higher levels of marketing spend are yielding positive improvements in our brand scores. And of course, we expect that we'll be able to translate that into improved volumes. So that's a trend in the quarter, Vivien. I'll pause for a second in case there's anything else before I talk about cannabis.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's really helpful. And thanks for indulging the cannabis question.
componenttext: No, that's really helpful. And thanks for indulging the cannabis question.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes,  look, I mean, cannabis something that we are thinking very carefully about, not only in the business but also as an industry. And there's a lot of talks certainly about what it' going to -- how it's going to be used and where it's going to be deploy
componenttext: Yes,  look, I mean, cannabis something that we are thinking very carefully about, not only in the business but also as an industry. And there's a lot of talks certainly about what it' going to -- how it's going to be used and where it's going to be deployed, et cetera. But there's just a lot we don't know at the moment. And so we're not even really 100% clear on where it will be sold, when it will be solved. And the best place I could suggest to look for guidance of what the impact might be would be probably to look at a state like Colorado and see what that's done to beer. But for the moment, we -- steady as she goes here because of the lack of clarity about the deployment of the drug itself.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: So a few questions. First, Mauricio, the transaction adjusted EPS for 2015 that's now $6.11 versus the $5.72 that you've given us at the September conference, so it went up by $0.39. I think the cash tax went up by $0.12 and I think the book amortization actually went down. But can you just bridge from $5.72 to $6.11, what's gone up in that adjustment?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so. The 2 items that you mentioned are correct. But why don't I refer you to the call that we're going to have afterwards led by Dave, and you'll be able to bridge that. Now the other factor you're missing there is the fact that our interest costs we
componenttext: Yes, so. The 2 items that you mentioned are correct. But why don't I refer you to the call that we're going to have afterwards led by Dave, and you'll be able to bridge that. Now the other factor you're missing there is the fact that our interest costs went down from that preliminary number of $5.72 that we had given you. So that's the third component that gets you to the EPS, but we'll give you a more detailed walk on that call.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Judy, we can give you more details on that call a little bit later, but at least the initial headline is that the bridge -- sorry, the pro formas that we put out in May that you're referring to for the $5.72 per transaction of adjusted EPS included b
componenttext: Yes, Judy, we can give you more details on that call a little bit later, but at least the initial headline is that the bridge -- sorry, the pro formas that we put out in May that you're referring to for the $5.72 per transaction of adjusted EPS included bridge financing for U.S. GAAP. And then, of course, the financing that we actually put in place for the long-term funding of the transaction actually came at a favorable rate, much more favorable than the bridge loan financing. And so that's the driver of lower interest expense.

componenttext: Okay. Well, yes, adjustment to interest rate, additional refinement of purchase accounting and, right, some -- oh, and then the adjustment up of cash tax benefits related to the transaction.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. We can follow up later. And then Mauricio, just on the free cash flow follow up. So the -- can you give us the underlying pro forma free cash flow for either '15 or  '16? Because I'm just trying to get to the $1.1 billion based on kind of the transa
componenttext: Okay. We can follow up later. And then Mauricio, just on the free cash flow follow up. So the -- can you give us the underlying pro forma free cash flow for either '15 or  '16? Because I'm just trying to get to the $1.1 billion based on kind of the transaction adjusted EPS number that you've given us, and it seems to imply very little underlying growth, and I'm just trying to see if I'm reading that correctly.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Judy, look, at this point, we're just giving the -- we're just going to give you the underlying free cash flow projection for 2017. I would encourage you to a little bit later on, when we post the pro formas on our website, you can do your calculatio
componenttext: Yes. Judy, look, at this point, we're just giving the -- we're just going to give you the underlying free cash flow projection for 2017. I would encourage you to a little bit later on, when we post the pro formas on our website, you can do your calculations there. Obviously, when you do kind of the back of the envelope math that you can do there, you would think about the free cash flow generation for MillerCoors and then the free cash flow generation for Molson Coors pre the acquisition, and you would get to a level of maybe $1.3 billion, $1.4 billion. Now there are obviously some tailwinds that are represented in the form of the $275 million of cash tax benefits, but also some headwinds, because we have a significant interest expense increase of around $250 million per annum because of the acquisition financing. There's additional D&A expense from the step-up due to the fair value remeasurement required by purchase accounting of around $70 million. And there's higher income taxes, because now we own the other 58% of MillerCoors, so we're paying additional taxes of around 200 -- or we will be paying additional taxes of around $200 million in 2017 versus what we did before.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And the $350 million of cash restructuring charge, is all of that hitting in 2017?

componenttext: No, no. That $350 million number is what we will be spending that we will do onetime expenditure, but it will be spread over the 3-year period.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe Gavin, just wanted to get your perspective on the volume performance for MillerCoors in the third quarter. Obviously, the industry's been a little bit soft. And clearly, you still have a vision to get to flat volume by 2018, but just
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe Gavin, just wanted to get your perspective on the volume performance for MillerCoors in the third quarter. Obviously, the industry's been a little bit soft. And clearly, you still have a vision to get to flat volume by 2018, but just seems like that's a pretty challenging order, given the recent trends. So do you think that you need to really step up investments even more on some of your key brands? Or do you think this is really just a broader industry problem?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gavin, do you want to pick that up directly?
componenttext: Gavin, do you want to pick that up directly?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Thanks, Mark, and thanks, Judy. Look, you're right. I mean, Q3 STR volumes were down across all brand segments and reflective of the industry. Just as far as our expectations for -- you remember their long-term goals, right? So our expectations
componenttext: Yes, sure. Thanks, Mark, and thanks, Judy. Look, you're right. I mean, Q3 STR volumes were down across all brand segments and reflective of the industry. Just as far as our expectations for -- you remember their long-term goals, right? So our expectations are still to be flat in 2018 with growth in 2019. And yes, we did see soft industry trends, and you see that in our STR figure. But we have now, for 3 straight quarters, closed out our volume gap with the industry. We've got some work to do on the Above Premium segment, but we really like our portfolio there, with the largest craft brand in the country with Blue Moon, and Leinenkugel's is in the top 5 as well. We've made 4 acquisitions, which  we're pleased about, and we've grown our flavored malt beverage share meaningfully over the last year or so. Our Premium Light's continued to perform well. Miller Lite's gained share of the Premium Light segment for the eighth consecutive quarter, Judy; and Coors Light gained share for the sixth consecutive quarter. We've reengaged the Economy drinker, and it's a hot priority for us. We've recently announced our Economy strategy at the full distributor meeting and that was well-received by our distribution network. Our Above Premium performance specifically was hindered by some of the performance on Blue Moon and Leinenkugel's, particularly seasonals and variety packs, and that's an industry-wide trend, and it's an issue we're addressing. And we have execution plans for early next year but we are pleased with our performance on a brand like Grapefruit Shandy, which doubled its volumes. So overall, Judy, it's one quarter and I'm pleased with the performance overall, particularly from a share point of view.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Pablo Zuanic with SIG.
componenttext: The next question is from Pablo Zuanic with SIG.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, one, I want to ask 2 questions. So the first one, bigger picture, something that every investor I talk to ask me is, "What's the track record of Mark Hunter and Gavin Hattersley, and why are they the right people to execute here?" And of course, I a
componenttext: Look, one, I want to ask 2 questions. So the first one, bigger picture, something that every investor I talk to ask me is, "What's the track record of Mark Hunter and Gavin Hattersley, and why are they the right people to execute here?" And of course, I ask the question with great respect, right? But people look at -- breathe on Philippe  having been at that for 20 years. So what we want to understand when we look at MillerCoors; Leo Kiely, a few years ago; Tom Long for 4 years; and now, Gavin. So if you can answer the question in terms of, what's your track record and why should investors be comfortable that this is the right management team to execute the significant plan? And the second question maybe is more for Mauricio, just basic in terms of numbers. I guess there's different ways to get -- to judge the guidance that you've given us today. One way I judge it is that I look at the cost savings that MillerCoors generated over the last 4 -- over last 5 years on average, right? About $120 million per annum, $88 million this year, you're running about $80 million this year, if I look at the $90 million this year for the third quarter. So you've done $120 million on average over the last 5 years. But then I look at the synergy number you are giving us today, $275 million divided by 3, that's $92 million. And then I take out from the balance, the Molson Coors savings ex MillerCoors, there's another $32 million of cost savings in MillerCoors. So synergies plus cost savings in MillerCoors, and I know that the lines get blurred, are about $124 million per annum over the next 3 years, which is what MillerCoors did over the last 5 years. So not so sure to be -- how to judge that number. Nice that you can sustain it. But if this is the significant transaction and there's this plethora of opportunities that we've talked about in terms of cost savings because now you own the full company, why would the cost savings, $124 million as per my math, total, would be pretty much similar to what you've been doing for the last 5 years. I guess if you can answer -- well, those are the 2 questions.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pablo, it's Mark here, and thanks. Clearly, to your first question, I'm not going to conduct a performance over our quarterly earnings call or get into detail as to why our board believe that I'm the right leader for this business and why I believe Gavin'
componenttext: Pablo, it's Mark here, and thanks. Clearly, to your first question, I'm not going to conduct a performance over our quarterly earnings call or get into detail as to why our board believe that I'm the right leader for this business and why I believe Gavin's the right leader for this business. I'll let our track record speak for ourselves. We're both seasoned professionals who've been in the beer industry for a long period of time, driven significant change across many businesses, integrated businesses like StarBev and driven this transaction at a rate, which on a valuation multiple, I think, is utterly compelling for our business. So I'll just leave it there. I'm not going to talk in any more detail beyond that. And let me just back up on the second question. I know you asked for Mauricio. But what we have endeavored to do here is get full transparency and ensure that we are not duplicating any of the cost savings in our business. And clearly, we've now set a target for the next 3 years. We'll update that on an annual basis. There was a lot of questions around the synergies number, and we have scaled that up and picked up the pace on the synergies number. And we've ensured that there's no duplication with the synergies on an ongoing underlying cost savings, and we'll continue to test ourselves as to whether that number can be further improved as we actually get into fully running the business. But we feel it's a number we can meet and will attempt to beat. It makes sense as we look at a business, which if you remember, has very, very little geographical overlap. You got to drive this by a number of restructuring initiatives, setting up things like shared services globally, and we'll get at that. And we'll update you if there's any new news on that number, but we feel it's the right number for our business at this point in time.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a very quick follow up. Regarding cadence, I know you're not willing to talk about how much of a savings that are created to the bottom line, but would it be reasonable to assume that given that you have this target of stabilizing volumes by 2018
componenttext: And just a very quick follow up. Regarding cadence, I know you're not willing to talk about how much of a savings that are created to the bottom line, but would it be reasonable to assume that given that you have this target of stabilizing volumes by 2018 and growing after that, that a lot of those savings, we really invest in initially, and that we should be thinking more year 3 and 4 seeing accretion at the EBIT line. If you can comment on that, please.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Pablo. And I mean, again, I haven't given any guidance as to how portion the cost savings. One of the things I did indicated earlier this year was that we have now developed a small global growth group led by Kandy. That team will be looking
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Pablo. And I mean, again, I haven't given any guidance as to how portion the cost savings. One of the things I did indicated earlier this year was that we have now developed a small global growth group led by Kandy. That team will be looking for incremental opportunities to accelerate our top line performance. Clearly, some of those opportunities will require incremental investment in our business, but we'll look at those in the round as we aggregate our total sales and marketing spend across our business. So I'm more interested in the quality of our marketing. And I think there's plenty of examples, and there's one in the U.S. market at the moment where people or competitors have been spending very aggressively. And let's just say the incremental spend doesn't always buy you success. I'm really focus on the quality of our marketing and the discipline of our execution, and we'll continue to drive efficiencies across our marketing spend. And if there's a return, that makes sense for us, we'll put it through the PACC model and we will spend incrementally to generate additional returns. So we want to drive very hard on getting the top line moving, and that will be a focus for us over the course of the next 24 to 36 months. I'm not going to get any more specifics than that, Pablo.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Mark Swartzberg with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: The next question comes from Mark Swartzberg with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple on the free cash flow and then a couple on the U.S. On the free cash flow, the $1.1 billion you mentioned that it includes these onetime cash costs. How much of that $350 million is actually in that $1.1 billion? and how much is as an expense ite
componenttext: A couple on the free cash flow and then a couple on the U.S. On the free cash flow, the $1.1 billion you mentioned that it includes these onetime cash costs. How much of that $350 million is actually in that $1.1 billion? and how much is as an expense item and how much is a capital expenditure item? And then are there other onetime items in there? Because on a per share basis, you were at $509 million in free cash flow, so you're basically telling us you think that transaction adjusted EPS will be down in calendar '17 or you're saying there's some pretty significant CapEx? So I'm just trying to understand what else is going on in that number.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Mauricio. Look, we haven't given a specific breakout of the $350 million, other than to say that about half of that will be additional CapEx and half of that will be additional OpEx. Now if you think about the nature of the cost savings that
componenttext: Yes. This is Mauricio. Look, we haven't given a specific breakout of the $350 million, other than to say that about half of that will be additional CapEx and half of that will be additional OpEx. Now if you think about the nature of the cost savings that we're going to deliver, including the synergies, a lot of the delivery of the synergies will be happening probably towards the latter part of the 3-year period, which means that, actually, the investment to deliver those synergies will be weighted towards years 1 and 2. We haven't really given a specific amount of how much of that will specifically hit 2017. Now as for the headwinds and tailwinds, the $275 million of cash tax savings, obviously, that's the tailwind for the next 15 years. The additional interest expense because of the company financing, again, that's something that is going to be there for the foreseeable future, as will the additional D&A expense, obviously, even though that's not -- that's a noncash item, but that's something that's obviously also going to be there as a generator of those cash tax savings.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. I'm still confused only because I'm sitting here with 6 11 and you're saying this year, that number is growing. So call it, I don't know, 6 20, 6 25 in transaction-adjusted EPS, and then the free cash flow view is $509 million so we're at more
componenttext: Yes, okay. I'm still confused only because I'm sitting here with 6 11 and you're saying this year, that number is growing. So call it, I don't know, 6 20, 6 25 in transaction-adjusted EPS, and then the free cash flow view is $509 million so we're at more than $1 below the transaction adjusted EPS number, which implies -- again, it implies some pretty significant CapEx or something else is going on in transaction-adjusted EPS, which is all pro forma for this transaction and doesn't have the international brand. So maybe it's a 1:00, but I'm still not -- I don't know if you have a response to that, yes.
