headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And then just shifting to the U.S., I'll just be curious, Mark or Gavin, craft has been weak for everybody. So just from a broader industries perspective, why do you think weak craft has gotten weaker sequentially, and how enduring do you thi
componenttext: Fair enough. And then just shifting to the U.S., I'll just be curious, Mark or Gavin, craft has been weak for everybody. So just from a broader industries perspective, why do you think weak craft has gotten weaker sequentially, and how enduring do you think that is? I know that it's hard to have a crystal ball there, but why do you think that is? And just mechanically for your U.S. business, it seems like your distributor inventories are higher than you'd like them to be, so is it reasonable to think your own shipments will lag your STRs on the fourth quarter?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Mark, let me split it into 2. So Gavin, I'll pass the cross to you on the STW, STRs section the second, and let me offer a couple of headlines around craft. I don't think it's true to say that craft is weak for everybody. That's a really generous state
componenttext: So Mark, let me split it into 2. So Gavin, I'll pass the cross to you on the STW, STRs section the second, and let me offer a couple of headlines around craft. I don't think it's true to say that craft is weak for everybody. That's a really generous statement. I think there's a number of craft companies that continue to show very strong growth, and we just acquired a number of them, which is a good thing for our business. I think what you are starting to see though in the marketplace is what I described as probably oversupply of flavors in SKUs or beer styles in SKUs. And both retailers and consumers are trying to make sense of the plethora of choice, and that's against the backdrop that craft has been good for the beer industry because it's driven conversations and interest in beer to probably an all-time high. But you get to the point where each SKU has to deliver on a velocity basis and has to actually demonstrate as well to both our customers and our consumers. And as Gavin mentioned earlier, things like seasonal packs, which have been a big driver of the craft industry, have really started to come under pressure because consumers are now, in essence, making up their own seasonal packs by the way that they actually show up the shelves. So I think what you're starting to see is from a retailer perspective, a push to really simplify the offering. And Walmart just did that recently as they reset all of their shelf sets. So the more progressive retailers are really trying to focus on those brands have got long-term distinct positionings and drive velocity per SKU. Also I think from a consumer perspective, because most of the craft growth has been driven on the back of heavily hopped IPAs, consumers are recognizing that those beers are great, but they're not beers that you can probably take with you through a long occasion, and we're actually starting to see some consumer step back into some of the American light brands. So I think it's just craft starting to kind of shake itself out with the brands that are well-positioned, clearly distinctive, and alongside that, the retailers really starting to simplify their offer. And that's in its infancy at the moment, but I think that's starting to have an impact in overall kind of craft velocity or craft trends. Gavin, I don't know whether you want to add anything to that and then pick up the STW, STRs question?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Mark. Look, I mean, anything I'd add to that, which is pretty much what you said, right, I mean, there's tons of choice and there's not a lot of floorspace. And velocity of retail is important. And that's why our Building with Beer program, w
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Mark. Look, I mean, anything I'd add to that, which is pretty much what you said, right, I mean, there's tons of choice and there's not a lot of floorspace. And velocity of retail is important. And that's why our Building with Beer program, which we've launched, Mark, and talked quite a lot about has had such a positive impact with beer buyers at retail, not only on-premise, but also off-premise. As far as the STWs, STRs are concerned, Mark, I mean, fundamentally, there's just the difference in timing. If you remember, at the end of Q2, that dynamic was reversed, where domestic STWs were down and STRs were down less than that. On a year-to-date basis, those 2 numbers are much closer. And generally, we try and align those things much closer by the end of the year as we try and ship to consumption. So I wouldn't get too worked up on quarter-over-quarter because of timing of holidays, price increases and so on.

You've got the process you're going through in Vancouver in terms of selling the brewery and you'll migrate to a new brewery there. I guess there's a potential the same thing could happen in Montréal. Is Eden -- the Eden, Carolina brewery in that -- inside that savings number. Just any sense of some of those bigger items that may be in there would be helpful.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. So Bryan, with respect to the cost savings, I mean, some of the items that you allude to -- that you alluded to during your questions are indeed in there. So for example, the savings that will come from the Eden brewery closure are included in t
componenttext: Yes, yes. So Bryan, with respect to the cost savings, I mean, some of the items that you allude to -- that you alluded to during your questions are indeed in there. So for example, the savings that will come from the Eden brewery closure are included in there. The work that we are continuously doing in terms of looking at our procurement, in addition to these savings related to procurement that are in the synergy number, and as Mark referenced to earlier, we've made a concerted effort to ensure that we've separated what is sort of business as usual savings, which is a way of doing business here, from the piece that's going to come specifically from the synergies. There are also other savings that are coming from looking at our supply chain network that are not included in the synergy piece of the optimization of the North America supply chain grid. So just a lot of savings that are coming from our business as usual, run of the mill, running the business, vis-à-vis the synergies that have specifically to do with those 3 buckets that we alluded to earlier.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bryan, it's Mark. I mean, another context point I will give you is over the course of the last 3 or 4 years, on an  enterprise-level, we've tried to drive for what we've described as our one-way principles, so across our major functional areas to try and
componenttext: Bryan, it's Mark. I mean, another context point I will give you is over the course of the last 3 or 4 years, on an  enterprise-level, we've tried to drive for what we've described as our one-way principles, so across our major functional areas to try and drive for a consistency of approach. Now whether that's world-class supply chain, HR ph] one way, we're now introducing that from a commercial perspective in terms of our commercial excellence approach. Really trying to drive for best practice orientation and consistency of approach wherever we can in the business, and that's been one of the drivers for unlocking additional efficiency savings through our business. A big part has been in our world-class supply chain, where we truly believe that we are at world class or close to world class in many areas. So we'll continue to crank the handle on that and drive as much value and efficiency as we can of those areas while overlooking  the synergy opportunity as well.

componenttextpreview: Robert, I'm not planning to fail, right? I mean, I think we've got the right plans, the right strategies, the right brands and the right people to get this done. And I wouldn't look at this on a simple quarter basis. This is a longer-term plan. The indust
componenttext: Robert, I'm not planning to fail, right? I mean, I think we've got the right plans, the right strategies, the right brands and the right people to get this done. And I wouldn't look at this on a simple quarter basis. This is a longer-term plan. The industry had a tough quarter, surely. But our expectations are still flat in 2018 with growth in 2019. And I can run you through all the high-level plans that we've got in our brands. But we, as a business, are certainly focused on that goal and believe we will achieve it.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Robert, I mean, the only color I would add there is that as an enterprise-level, we're committed to supporting Gavin and the team to make that happen. And there's been lots of questions over the course of the last 12 to 18 months on how will we g
componenttext: Yes. And Robert, I mean, the only color I would add there is that as an enterprise-level, we're committed to supporting Gavin and the team to make that happen. And there's been lots of questions over the course of the last 12 to 18 months on how will we get there, and we've tried to really simplify the thinking into 3 specific areas: Our Economy, our Below Premium strategy, and many of you have asked about clarity on our thinking there. That's now been clarified and launched and generated a lot of excitement with our distributors. Many of you have asked about our ability to get Coors Light and Miller Lite growing at the same time, and we're now doing that consistently. And alongside them, Coors Banquet is going from strength to strength. And we continue to drive the premiumization of our portfolio, and the craft acquisitions and Henry's are great examples. Don't forget the Redd's, which is now such a significant brand, didn't even exist just over 3 years ago. And my view is that we still have untapped opportunities in our own portfolio as well. So all of the component parts are there. A lot was down to how ruthless we want to be from an execution perspective. But Gavin and the leadership team have driven a significant change in the ambition, the energy and the focus in our U.S. business, and it's been great to see that happening. And some quarters will be tougher than others, but we're absolutely resolute on our ambition to get this business back into a growth trajectory. And as Gavin said, that's over the course of the next couple of years.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: That's terrific. On the international side, can you give us -- and I so know some of this may have come out earlier on in the prelude. headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we've made good progress in terms of planning and executing the transition of the Miller brands into our systems, because it was relatively easier in places like Canada and U.K., which came on to our business footprint. We have a series of market
componenttext: Sure. So we've made good progress in terms of planning and executing the transition of the Miller brands into our systems, because it was relatively easier in places like Canada and U.K., which came on to our business footprint. We have a series of markets where we have existing partners; Panama, Honduras, as an example, that we moved the distribution on to our existing partners. In the markets which were new to us, we have established with 1 or 2 exceptions, almost all of them new distribution agreements that are in place. In terms of production, we are relying either on our infrastructure like MillerCoors. And in certain cases, we are continuing to rely on traditional services agreements via ABI, and we'll be working to transition those into our own system as well. But on the whole, I'm very pleased, and Stewart, Simon, Fred are all involved in this in terms of transitioning over into our setup. Our initial 2 to 3 weeks has gone without any significant issues, and so we are quite pleased with the transition.

componenttext: We haven't made any kind of public statements around that other than in markets like Panama, we have an existing partner there, and we've transitioned across. And as I mentioned earlier, I mean, some of the markets are doing better than we anticipated, some of the markets are going to take a bit more work to get back on the front. So you would expect in a transition of this nature, but we'll give probably more color and a fuller update on our February call.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Molson Coors Brewing Company Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Follow-up Session Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now I will turn the call over to Dave Dunnewald, Global Vice President of Investor Relations for Molson Co
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Molson Coors Brewing Company Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Follow-up Session Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now I will turn the call over to Dave Dunnewald, Global Vice President of Investor Relations for Molson Coors. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Laura, and good morning, everyone. On behalf of Molson Coors Brewing Company, thank you for joining us today for our Third Quarter 2016 Follow-Up Earnings Conference Call. Our goal on this call is to address as many additional earnings-related
componenttext:
Thank you, Laura, and good morning, everyone. On behalf of Molson Coors Brewing Company, thank you for joining us today for our Third Quarter 2016 Follow-Up Earnings Conference Call. Our goal on this call is to address as many additional earnings-related questions as possible following our regular earnings conference call with Mark Hunter, Mauricio Restrepo and our business unit CEOs as earlier today. 
We will use a standard question-and-answer format, and we anticipate that the call will last less than an hour. 
Before we begin, I will paraphrase our safe harbor language. Some of our discussion today may include forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from what we project today, so please refer to our most recent 10-K and 10-Q filings for a more complete description of factors that could affect these projections. We do not undertake to publicly update forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future results or otherwise. You should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date they are made. 
Regarding any non-U.S. GAAP measures that we may discuss during the call and from time-to-time by our executives in discussing our company's performance, please visit our website, www.molsoncoors.com, and click on the financial reporting tab at the Investor Relations page for a reconciliation of these measures with the nearest U.S. GAAP results. Also, unless otherwise indicated, all financial results we discuss are versus the comparable prior year period and in U.S. dollars. 
So let's get started with an introduction of the team with me on the call today. First of all, we have Mauricio Restrepo, CFO; Kevin Kim, Investor Relations Senior Manager; Alex Gowan [ph], Finance Forecasting Manager; Erik Mickelson, Technical Accounting Senior Manager; Brian Tabolt Controller; Mike Rumley, Treasurer; and Mark Saks, VP of Tax. 
Regarding quarterly results, as Mark Hunter mentioned on our regular earnings call this morning, in the third quarter, we continue to focus on First Choice ambition and on building a stronger, broader and more premium brand portfolio underpinned by incremental sales and marketing investments, as we have discussed all year. 
Business highlights for the quarter and year-to-date included increasing net sales revenue per hectoliter on a constant currency basis in all of our businesses for the quarter and for the year-to-date, increased investments in our brands globally. Coors Light and Miller Lite again gained share in the U.S. Premium Light segment, including the highest segment share gained in 3 years for Coors Light. 1.2% global volume growth for Coors Light year-to-date, with growth of more than 14% year-to-date outside of North America. Fast growth innovations in key markets, including Henry's Hard Soda in U.S. and Mad Jack in Canada. And global growth year-to-date in Above Premium through -- for example, Doom Bar and other Sharp's craft brands in the U.K., Creemore Springs and Belgian Moon in Canada and 4 newly acquired brewers in the U.S. And Above Premium also included strong growth by Staropramen across Europe outside of its home market, and cider volume increases with Rekorderlig in Europe and Strongbow in Canada. 
So we -- so kind of on an overall basis, we continue to strengthen our business through improvements to our sales execution and revenue management capabilities, increased efficiency of our operations and implementation of common global systems. 
This is a historic time for -- in the evolution of Molson Coors. 3 weeks ago, we completed our acquisition of the remaining 58% stake in the MillerCoors joint venture, along with Miller global brand portfolio. We emerged as the word's third largest brewer, bringing together Molson Coors and MillerCoors into a bigger, better organization. As one company with an expanded portfolio of iconic brands, we intend to leverage our increased scale, resources and synergies as well as combined commercial experience to accelerate our First Choice agenda and deliver long-term shareholder value. 
On the earnings call earlier this morning, Mauricio also shared perspective regarding 3 new performance measures: transaction, adjusted EPS and all-in multi-year cost savings target and an early view of our combined company underlying free cash flow target for 2017. In addition to any earnings-related questions you may have, we would be happy to answer any questions you have regarding these new or updated performance metrics. 
And finally, for your reference, please note that we have posted full year 2015 and year-to-date 2016 pro forma financial statements on our website to give effects to the MillerCoors acquisition and the related financing, as those were completed on January 1, 2015. 
So with that as an introduction, I'd like to turn it over or open it up for questions. Over to you, Laura.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So this is the long-anticipated follow-up call, where we get clarification on the free cash flow guidance. So I guess, what everyone is kind of trying to reconcile is you've got $6,000.11 of transaction-adjusted EPS in 2015. That translates to rough
componenttext: Okay. So this is the long-anticipated follow-up call, where we get clarification on the free cash flow guidance. So I guess, what everyone is kind of trying to reconcile is you've got $6,000.11 of transaction-adjusted EPS in 2015. That translates to roughly $1.32 billion in terms of the implied cash flow number. And then, Mauricio, you're guiding to $1.1 billion. So it seems like there is a pretty big step-down even after adjusting for cash restructuring charge. So can you just help us sort of reconcile kind of how we go from 2015 to '17 in terms of free cash flow?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let's see. Let me give you some headlines around that. I don't think I'll be able to reconcile it point-by-point, Judy. But what I would say, I guess, first of all, is we're really dealing with 2 different measures here in a sense that it's a cruel a
componenttext:
Yes. Let's see. Let me give you some headlines around that. I don't think I'll be able to reconcile it point-by-point, Judy. But what I would say, I guess, first of all, is we're really dealing with 2 different measures here in a sense that it's a cruel accounting versus cash accounting said moderately. The free cash flow guidance $1.1 billion is truly a cash performance measure. The transaction adjusted EPS number is not a cash performance measure. It actually starts with underlying book EPS and then makes to cash adjustments to kinds of amortization or cash -- and cash tax benefit. So they're really say not directly comparable. The types of differences that you'd see between those 2 numbers would be things like pension contributions, cash versus expense. So obviously, the pension cash would be directly reflected in the free cash flow number, but the pension expense number would be reflected in underlying EPS, which is the base for the transaction adjusted EPS. Another example would be capital expenditures versus depreciation and amortization. Third example would be cash taxes versus book taxes and we talked about the 270 -- more than $275 million of cash tax benefit associated with the transaction, but we have not provided guidance on other cash taxes or on book taxes. Now those are included in the performance, but we don't -- you don't have a specific view from a cash standpoint for the free cash flow.
And then finally, capital expenditures needed to capture synergy. As Mauricio mentioned on earlier call, we do anticipate some incremental CapEx related to the -- to capturing synergies. And those would tend will be loaded more toward the first 2 years of the 3-year time frame that we talked about as far as cost savings go. And -- so that then we can capture the synergies, again as we mentioned, predominantly in years 2 and 3 for those. Although, I would hasten to mention that the other cost savings that we mentioned, non-synergies in other words, actually re skewed towards more years 1 or 2 of the 3-year time period. Does that give your at least some headlines of why there might be some differences between those 2 numbers?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if I can maybe follow-up. So if you start with like '15 [ph] to $4.64 of underlying book EPS at starting point. And then you would add $2.75 of the cash tax benefit?
componenttext: So if I can maybe follow-up. So if you start with like '15 [ph] to $4.64 of underlying book EPS at starting point. And then you would add $2.75 of the cash tax benefit?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Right, the $4.64 per share is a pro forma full year 2015 number. And then yes, to that we would add back the transaction-related amortization, call it a noncash item add back that plus, yes, cash tax benefit of $275 million.
componenttext: Yes. Right, the $4.64 per share is a pro forma full year 2015 number. And then yes, to that we would add back the transaction-related amortization, call it a noncash item add back that plus, yes, cash tax benefit of $275 million.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that gets to $1.3 billion roughly? And what do we take out from there?
componenttext: So that gets to $1.3 billion roughly? And what do we take out from there?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, this is Mauricio. So again remember, when you're talking to the $4.54 and then you add those 2 items to get back to $6.11, you're not talking about cash flow EPS. You're not talking about cash flow per share. You're talking about an EPS per share t
componenttext: Sorry, this is Mauricio. So again remember, when you're talking to the $4.54 and then you add those 2 items to get back to $6.11, you're not talking about cash flow EPS. You're not talking about cash flow per share. You're talking about an EPS per share that's been adjusted by those 2 items. When you -- if that gets you to $1.3, well that gets you -- then $1.3 is not a cash flow number. It would just be an earnings transaction adjusted number, but it's not a cash flow number. The $1.1 is a cash flow number.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. These are really apples and oranges. The Judy, you'd really need to know what our pension cash contributions would be, what the CapEx is going to be. Clearly, we're going to have some incremental CapEx in the early years year here as well as things l
componenttext: Yes. These are really apples and oranges. The Judy, you'd really need to know what our pension cash contributions would be, what the CapEx is going to be. Clearly, we're going to have some incremental CapEx in the early years year here as well as things like cash taxes that I mentioned earlier.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So yes -- so what I was going to add is, if you conceptually think about it, the starting point for both numbers obviously is the same because you start from operating income. Then operating income, what you do is when you do want to calculate your cash f
componenttext: So yes -- so what I was going to add is, if you conceptually think about it, the starting point for both numbers obviously is the same because you start from operating income. Then operating income, what you do is when you do want to calculate your cash flow number, then you have to add back all the noncash, depreciation, use of your CapEx, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera to get to the cash flow number. To get to the earnings number, you just -- you go down to P&L and you get the earnings number. So those 2 aren't comparable.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we will always see sort of the similar gap between transaction adjusted EPS number versus the actual free cash flow number. So the 2017 is kind of the new norm from a free cash flow perspective and we should think about growing off of that going forwar
componenttext: So we will always see sort of the similar gap between transaction adjusted EPS number versus the actual free cash flow number. So the 2017 is kind of the new norm from a free cash flow perspective and we should think about growing off of that going forward? Or does the '17 free cash flow number depressed by either one-time cash outflow items or underlying operating income being significantly lower year-over-year?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Judy. Two points on that. One, yes, there are some -- there will be some one-time cash used items in 2017. We've highlighted CapEx to capture synergies as an example. But second of all, the factors that essentially drive the difference between fre
componenttext: Thanks, Judy. Two points on that. One, yes, there are some -- there will be some one-time cash used items in 2017. We've highlighted CapEx to capture synergies as an example. But second of all, the factors that essentially drive the difference between free cash flow number and a transaction adjusted EPS number will move over time. So I can't tell you one -- whether or not the gap will stay similar to that in the future. What I can say is we do have some one-time cash uses in 2017.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's fair, but I mean I guess, the issue is that we're looking at your transaction-adjusted EPS number to value or at least get a good feel for your underlying earnings power. But if there is a big gap that exist between your EPS versus free cash
componenttext: Okay. That's fair, but I mean I guess, the issue is that we're looking at your transaction-adjusted EPS number to value or at least get a good feel for your underlying earnings power. But if there is a big gap that exist between your EPS versus free cash flow, the transaction-adjusted EPS number becomes less meaningful, I think, on people's view. So I think that sort of the issue that we're trying to kind of reconcile with this is kind of the new norm? Or over time, we will get to kind of an underlying free cash flow number that more resembled the transaction-adjusted number that we can then assess your underlying free cash flow generation?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think as I say without some of the one-time cash uses in 2017, there may be more consistency between the 2. But I'm not going to say -- forecast those for you and whether they will increase or decrease, it depends on time frame. We don't give e
componenttext: Yes. And I think as I say without some of the one-time cash uses in 2017, there may be more consistency between the 2. But I'm not going to say -- forecast those for you and whether they will increase or decrease, it depends on time frame. We don't give earnings guidance.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And again, -- this is Mauricio. Judy, let me just reemphasize. So definitely, the one-time effect of the 2017 CapEx required to deliver the synergies, well, that something that's not going to be recurring, so that's going to obviously increase the free ca
componenttext: And again, -- this is Mauricio. Judy, let me just reemphasize. So definitely, the one-time effect of the 2017 CapEx required to deliver the synergies, well, that something that's not going to be recurring, so that's going to obviously increase the free cash flow going forward, if you assume all else being equal from a 2017 base. And then going forward, obviously, all of the accounting and accrual adjustments versus cash adjustments. Meaning, the idea of showing the transaction-adjusted EPS would simply to give a reflection of the earnings capability of the business once you take that underlying earnings per share and you just -- you adjusted for 2 items that are not evident, when you go back in time and look at the pro forma. Of course, going forward, the $275 million of cash tax benefit will be hitting your earnings. It's just that as we went back and we were looking at the earnings in 2015, that's one adjustment that we had to make. So at the end of the day, again, one is an accrual and an accounting measure and the other one is a cash flow measure. Now in that cash flow of the $1.1, you will have the impact of additional interest expense of the additional taxes that are being paid, et cetera, et cetera.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi Judy, this is Frank, controlling at Molson Coors the one thing I wanted to clarify is that when you're looking at the transaction-adjusted EPS, if you recall, I think when we announced the acquisition last year, one of the key things that we indicated
componenttext: Hi Judy, this is Frank, controlling at Molson Coors the one thing I wanted to clarify is that when you're looking at the transaction-adjusted EPS, if you recall, I think when we announced the acquisition last year, one of the key things that we indicated is that the cash tax benefits of $275 million, that will not impact our EPS on a go-forward basis. So that's why -- one of the reasons why we wanted to give you the transaction-adjusted EPS to give you visibility of those tax benefits. But otherwise, it won't come into the completion of our EPS number.

componenttext: Okay. I think it's a little clear. headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Yes, that's right. If you look at the pro forma on the left side, you will see that is transaction-related interest expense of $250 million that are included in the pro forma and that is a very different number from the interest expense that we gave you in the May '12 pro forma, which is the last time we filed them. And that's what I was referring to earlier -- on earlier call when I was mentioning the bridge financing. However compared to the Boston Conference pro forma number, what was that? 572, yes. Thanks, Brian. The -- as I think that you mentioned, Judy, there is $0.39 change and actually that was due to 3 main factors. One of them is the increase in the cash tax benefits that we're seeing, that's above $0.12. We're also seeing an adjustment to both amortization and depreciation, but as you know, we strip out amortization for transaction-adjusted EPS. However, depreciation, we do not strip out that actually was a $0.10 improvement via the purchase accounting work that the accounting team has been doing there. And then the rest of the difference is related to other purchase accounting adjustments, including valuation of assets and liabilities, things like pension and other property, plant and equipment, where they're going to continue to do their work and you'll actually in all likelihood see additional adjustments, albeit they may be a little bit smaller, but additional adjustments in future quarters and in fact the opening balance it is lockdown for one year from the close of transaction.

componenttext: Got it. Okay. headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping that you could help us to understand how we should think about your deleveraging plan in terms of when we should think -- or what sort of level we should think about when determining when you could potentially restart like your dividend growt
componenttext: I was hoping that you could help us to understand how we should think about your deleveraging plan in terms of when we should think -- or what sort of level we should think about when determining when you could potentially restart like your dividend growth or maybe even consider some share buybacks?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me give us some headlines and then we'll see whether Mauricio or Mike will add some color to that. So our deleveraging plan, obviously, that is our primary focus for capital allocation over the next 2 to 3 years debt pay down. We want to reduce
componenttext: Sure. Let me give us some headlines and then we'll see whether Mauricio or Mike will add some color to that. So our deleveraging plan, obviously, that is our primary focus for capital allocation over the next 2 to 3 years debt pay down. We want to reduce our debt levels in order to maintain our firm commitment to investment grade rating and we have a specific plan with the rating agencies to maintain that investment grade rating. What I would say as far as specific leverage ratios go, we have not provided one of those publicly. What we have said is that our goal over time is to get to solid investment grade gratings, which are roughly BBB even. Sorry, and there was one more other thing for you had asked about dividends and buyback. So dividend, the exact wording that we've used around is that is we will consider our dividend policy. Again right now, it's being held even on a per share basis for quarter, as we pay down debt. And when debt paydown as well underway then we can -- we have said that we will be willing to revisit our dividend policy.  Buybacks, you said that we're not going to consider those until our leverage ratios are considerably lower than they are right now. But we haven't put a specific time frame around either one of those.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So how should we think about debt paydown, I think, being fall underway, I think that's kind of what I'm trying to understand?
componenttext: So how should we think about debt paydown, I think, being fall underway, I think that's kind of what I'm trying to understand?

componenttext: Yes. So I can't give you specific outlook on that. What I can say is that for example, last time we did a substantial transaction that would be the transaction in 2012. We, in that instance, had roughly the same language around buybacks and dividends. And if I recall correctly, about 1.5 years after we completed the transaction, we actually did increase the dividend and put in place a dividend payout ratio. And then buybacks came later about 3 years, I believe, later essentially.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: And in the interim time, I mean, we experienced a double upgrade from example from S&P, right? So it all went hand-in-hand with regards to the pace at which we were deleveraging versus when we are and increasing our dividend.

componenttext: That's a good add from Mike, Treasurer. And we exceeded the time frame and to Mike's point, received a double upgrade from example from S&P in 1 year or 2 years after the transaction.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is Mauricio. And again, it is very, very important for us to ensure that this is absolutely clear. So both the transaction-adjusted EPS and the free cash flow number that we gave you, both of those contain these one-time items or these adjustme
componenttext: Mark, this is Mauricio. And again, it is very, very important for us to ensure that this is absolutely clear. So both the transaction-adjusted EPS and the free cash flow number that we gave you, both of those contain these one-time items or these adjustments that have been done because of purchase accounting. It's just that the $6.11 per share is an accounting number based on accrual. It is based on the P&L, okay. And the $1.1 billion is a cash flow number. So we start from operating income and then we make all sorts of adjustment to that number to reflect the actual cash inflows and outflows, so you get to a number of cash flow, which as you know, the cash flow number is not necessarily the same as the underlying earnings number. So per share number for those 2 is not going to be same.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood and appreciate that. And that's the heart of the matter because the way we're going to look at the stock is ultimately about the cash flow. So $1.1 billion, not that you have said this, but call it $1.3 billion when you add back the savings-rel
componenttext: Understood and appreciate that. And that's the heart of the matter because the way we're going to look at the stock is ultimately about the cash flow. So $1.1 billion, not that you have said this, but call it $1.3 billion when you add back the savings-related expenditures you're making. And my question is, can you point us to anything else or is there anything else of any size that's one-time in nature, that's a cash expenditure occurring in calendar '17 that is in that $1.1 billion number? Because again, it's just -- this transaction adjusted EPS as much as we're going to put it on Factset and first call and so forth, it's not going to determine how your stock is valued ultimately. It's a free cash flow. So I'm just trying to understand if there is anything else besides the money you're spending to get 350 -- I'm sorry, 550 in savings, the 350 you're actually spending in cash outlay. Is there anything beside that in that $1.1 billion that you can call out to us, whether that's pension, something usually in the way of working capital increases? Is there anything you can call out to us? Or is it indeed your best guess on an underlying operation basis?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So that's a billion-dollar question. Actually, well done. So no, Mark. So short answer is no, I can't provide any specifics, but you will and I'm not going to front run our annual guidance that we normally provide on our February earnings call. And s
componenttext: Yes. So that's a billion-dollar question. Actually, well done. So no, Mark. So short answer is no, I can't provide any specifics, but you will and I'm not going to front run our annual guidance that we normally provide on our February earnings call. And so you may see some additional, I would say, detail around that, because that's what we're providing not just cost guidance, but also some of the CapEx guidance, also pension cash and expense plans for the year, those type these things. So I would just leave it kind of where I would leave earlier. There are things like pension, CapEx, depreciation -- versus depreciation I should say that will come into play at least to some extent. But we're not going to provide any numbers around what that looks like. But you may get some additional clarity on the fourth quarter call.

componenttext: I think that's right., and I think the same appropriate way to think about it, because as we've said this is essentially we're setting up -- we have kind of 3 different approaches to the Miller International brand in the existing areas, geographies or in geographies, where we have existing infrastructure like Canada and the U.K., pretty clear what we're going to do there, where we have strong existing partnership, that's relatively easy to sort out as well. And then in some of the new markets, when we don't have infrastructure or existing partners then essentially you're building a route to market a supply chain and everything. So what that P&L looks like is something it's work in progress.

componenttext: Okay. And then just one another question related to just free cash flow and more just conceptually Mauricio, is there anything about, I guess, the 2 companies having been separate and now merged that would create any potential working capital benefits or maybe to put a different way, was there's about something about the way things were structured previously that made working capital less efficient than maybe there is room for cash savings or working capital improvements going forward?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bryan. Let me give or couple of headlines and then Mauricio may have some additional texture around that, only part because I have a history. Yes, so MillerCoors, well, we have a PAC model year. Molson Coors. MillerCoors doesn't strictly speaking
componenttext: Thanks, Bryan. Let me give or couple of headlines and then Mauricio may have some additional texture around that, only part because I have a history. Yes, so MillerCoors, well, we have a PAC model year. Molson Coors. MillerCoors doesn't strictly speaking has a pack model, but they're getting it soon. And Gabbin was one of the primary implementers and developers -- certainly implementers of that in Molson Coors. And -- but they've had their own approach to return on invested capital and return on marketing investments and so forth. So there's not a dramatic difference there, but we will do some line with a lot of other pieces of the business. There are also some relatively limited differences in working capital between the 2 companies. And as you can imagine, we'll be exploring any improvements we can make there. Mauricio, is there anything you would add to that?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The only thing I would add to that is there is 3 ways which we can improve our free cash flow going forward is additional earnings obviously, improvements in working capital and then just a detailed evaluation of discretionary CapEx, which we always
componenttext: Yes. The only thing I would add to that is there is 3 ways which we can improve our free cash flow going forward is additional earnings obviously, improvements in working capital and then just a detailed evaluation of discretionary CapEx, which we always do to our pack line. And with respect to working capital, I don't think really that there was anything that wasn't there because the companies were separate. Nevertheless, -- and as Dave correctly pointes out, there is always room for improvement in working capital. We are looking at some specific initiatives, working very closely with the U.S. team with MillerCoors. And hopefully, that will be some interesting benefits coming out of that.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Bryan, I wouldn't answer that specifically, but I what I would say we care deeply, not only about debt paydown but therefore free cash flow and cash available to pay down debt. And so we do look at benchmarks. We do look at best practices and we will, I would say, address or go after any opportunities that we think are appropriate for business. But no, I wouldn't put a specific number on it.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And the one thing I would add to that is it's not enough to simply, I guess, as you're looking at your numbers and comparing to other companies, is not really enough to look at what companies do with respect to working capital. And because there is a
componenttext: Yes. And the one thing I would add to that is it's not enough to simply, I guess, as you're looking at your numbers and comparing to other companies, is not really enough to look at what companies do with respect to working capital. And because there is always a financial component to that, especially if you think about your payables or your receivables, you have to be able to understand what the other side of the equation is that is not hitting your balance sheet, but it's actually hitting your P&L in the sense that you may think, for example, I don't know the way that you manage your payables, you're being very inefficient, but that's not complete picture until we understand what isthe financial benefit that the company would be obtaining in so doing.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just quickly, we have been talking about cash flow, is there anything that structurally changed in the business, if you look it at past 5 years versus going forward in terms of productivity, whether you start from operating income or start from net income
componenttext:
Just quickly, we have been talking about cash flow, is there anything that structurally changed in the business, if you look it at past 5 years versus going forward in terms of productivity, whether you start from operating income or start from net income 2017 question this is?
The ability to turn operating income or pretax income or net income into cash flow is there and I'm not asking specifically to '17, but if I'm thinking sort of past 5 years, next 5 years, is there something that has changed in terms of being able to turn if you start with operating income with cash flows?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. One thing that comes to mind substantial improvements to our working capital that we've done since in 2012. Particularly, if you're just looking at -- if you looking at the P&L versus the cash flow statement, amortization expense is very different to
componenttext: Yes. One thing that comes to mind substantial improvements to our working capital that we've done since in 2012. Particularly, if you're just looking at -- if you looking at the P&L versus the cash flow statement, amortization expense is very different today than what it was a few years ago. Obviously, we're trying to help you with that, so with the transaction-adjusted EPS number.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And let we had something here that I'm hoping for all of you on the call will be useful and impending picture of cash flow. And this analysis, I'll just to do kind of top of my head again sort of the back of the envelope analysis. So if you look at h
componenttext: Yes. And let we had something here that I'm hoping for all of you on the call will be useful and impending picture of cash flow. And this analysis, I'll just to do kind of top of my head again sort of the back of the envelope analysis. So if you look at historically at the capacity to generate free cash flow of the Molson Coors business and then you look at the capacity to generate cash flow of the MillerCoors business and you put the 2 together historically. And you say, okay, well, that's roughly gives me between $1.3 billion, $1.4 billion and obviously, you guys are looking and saying, "Jesus, but these guys are reporting $1.1 billion. So what's happening there?" So just back of the envelope analysis, you take the $1.3 billion, $1.4 billion, okay. You add the $275 million of benefit that you're getting there, so you're getting around $1.6 billion, okay, of cash generation. But now we're paying $250 million per year more of interest, so you have to deduct that from $1.6 billion to get to $1.35 billion, okay. And in addition, you're paying more taxes because we own the other 58% [ph] of MillerCoors. So your $1.35 billion deduct another $200 million, that gives you about 1.15, there you go, that's roughly from a cash flow perspective how I would look at, okay how does the $1.1 billion compared to what should be the norm sort of the "normalized cash flow generation potential" of the 2 separate business, if you just added the 2 together.

componenttext: I have a question on tax rate that you're saying you're paying higher taxes. Presumably, MillerCoors was paying taxes by buying the rest of operation, the free cash flow wasn't at higher taxes in the operation. Could you may be clarified those extra taxes you're about to pay and you would get some relief on -- because of the high leverage?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you for the question. Actually I'm glad you asked that, because it may not be obvious to a lot of folks. When we bought the other 58% of MillerCoors, that increase are significantly our exposure to profit through cash flow, but we're really tal
componenttext:
Yes. Thank you for the question. Actually I'm glad you asked that, because it may not be obvious to a lot of folks. When we bought the other 58% of MillerCoors, that increase are significantly our exposure to profit through cash flow, but we're really talking about profits here increase our exposure to the U.S. business and call it industry and corporate income tax rate, which is among the highest in the world. And so because of the -- I guess, simple migration of pretax income in the direction of U.S. exposure that results in an higher average blend of tax rate. Now to start with though on the 58% of the MillerCoors business that we are buying, we do not pay corporate income taxes on that portion, SAB Miller out of London paid whatever taxes were due on that via their situation. We pay taxes on a 42% of the MillerCoors portion that we own. Now we're -- now our income tax rate on average, we expect to be somewhat higher. In fact, the guidance has changed from 18% to 22% for 2016 without the transaction, so the 25% to 28% in future years, all else being equal no changes in tax rate and those types of things. So you get 25% to 28% on a longer-term basis, including other 58% of MillerCoors. So you can tell several percentage point higher than what we have with the pre-existing shape of the business.
And if you look -- Kevin reminded me, if you look at the pro forma table on the website, you can see a pro forma tax rate of around 25% for the 2015 full year pro forma number. So there you go, I mean, the tax -- the effective tax rate in pro forma is in that 25% to 28% range that we have been talking about. Does that help?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

componenttext: So on the Miller International contribution, so I understand we're not going to incorporate any profit contribution, but just in terms of volume and revenue, because I think you have given the 2014 numbers, but just wanted to get a better sense of kind of what the run rate is from a volume and revenue standpoint? And then for Canada piece specifically just given that you've got extra volume going into that part of the business. Should we actually assume better leverage is from a margin perspective, now that you can absorb more of a volume to your cost structure?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question, Judy. So Miller International volume, we said as far as the transaction communication, that was about 3.2 million hectoliters per year. And we have not changed that point of view. From a revenue standpoint, we've never provided guidanc
componenttext: Yes, good question, Judy. So Miller International volume, we said as far as the transaction communication, that was about 3.2 million hectoliters per year. And we have not changed that point of view. From a revenue standpoint, we've never provided guidance, because actually that was determined or would be determined by the route to market of the brands in a dozens of market around the world. For example, in license revenue, you have different revenue from a royalty revenue versus a wholly-owned market the amount of revenue. So we have not provided a number on that one. I would put that in the bucket of to be determined, similar to some of the comments that Mark made earlier on the call today. From a Canada standpoint, that is an interesting one. When the brands were bought -- the rights of brands of Canada bought were us about 1.5 years ago, they always said about the size of the Miller brands in Canada was mid-single digit percent of our Canada volume. We have not updated that and that would be subject to the performance of those brands over the last 1.5 years under SAB Miller. So we see what that looks like from a volume standpoint and would that provide additional leverage, specific to your question. We'll see. We'll see, which brands will be produced locally versus imported or what. In other words, that will be one of the details that we will sort out with you over time. And then one thing we're not talking about profit but Bryan made a good point that we do have a purchase price protection on the purchases of Miller International brand as they existed in SAP system. If the prophet trailing 12 months EBITDA is less than $70 million for that 12-month time period, then that will be a purchase price adjustment that we would negotiate with ABI it sort of issue of roughly 11.3x.

But other than that, the calculation is exactly the same. So that's all I want to say, Dave.

componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Molson Coors Brewing Company Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Follow-up Session Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now I will turn the call over to Dave Dunnewald, Global Vice President of Investor Relations for Molson Co
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Molson Coors Brewing Company Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Follow-up Session Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now I will turn the call over to Dave Dunnewald, Global Vice President of Investor Relations for Molson Coors. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Laura, and good morning, everyone. On behalf of Molson Coors Brewing Company, thank you for joining us today for our Third Quarter 2016 Follow-Up Earnings Conference Call. Our goal on this call is to address as many additional earnings-related
componenttext:
Thank you, Laura, and good morning, everyone. On behalf of Molson Coors Brewing Company, thank you for joining us today for our Third Quarter 2016 Follow-Up Earnings Conference Call. Our goal on this call is to address as many additional earnings-related questions as possible following our regular earnings conference call with Mark Hunter, Mauricio Restrepo and our business unit CEOs as earlier today. 
We will use a standard question-and-answer format, and we anticipate that the call will last less than an hour. 
Before we begin, I will paraphrase our safe harbor language. Some of our discussion today may include forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from what we project today, so please refer to our most recent 10-K and 10-Q filings for a more complete description of factors that could affect these projections. We do not undertake to publicly update forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future results or otherwise. You should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date they are made. 
Regarding any non-U.S. GAAP measures that we may discuss during the call and from time-to-time by our executives in discussing our company's performance, please visit our website, www.molsoncoors.com, and click on the financial reporting tab at the Investor Relations page for a reconciliation of these measures with the nearest U.S. GAAP results. Also, unless otherwise indicated, all financial results we discuss are versus the comparable prior year period and in U.S. dollars. 
So let's get started with an introduction of the team with me on the call today. First of all, we have Mauricio Restrepo, CFO; Kevin Kim, Investor Relations Senior Manager; Alex Gowan [ph], Finance Forecasting Manager; Erik Mickelson, Technical Accounting Senior Manager; Brian Tabolt Controller; Mike Rumley, Treasurer; and Mark Saks, VP of Tax. 
Regarding quarterly results, as Mark Hunter mentioned on our regular earnings call this morning, in the third quarter, we continue to focus on First Choice ambition and on building a stronger, broader and more premium brand portfolio underpinned by incremental sales and marketing investments, as we have discussed all year. 
Business highlights for the quarter and year-to-date included increasing net sales revenue per hectoliter on a constant currency basis in all of our businesses for the quarter and for the year-to-date, increased investments in our brands globally. Coors Light and Miller Lite again gained share in the U.S. Premium Light segment, including the highest segment share gained in 3 years for Coors Light. 1.2% global volume growth for Coors Light year-to-date, with growth of more than 14% year-to-date outside of North America. Fast growth innovations in key markets, including Henry's Hard Soda in U.S. and Mad Jack in Canada. And global growth year-to-date in Above Premium through -- for example, Doom Bar and other Sharp's craft brands in the U.K., Creemore Springs and Belgian Moon in Canada and 4 newly acquired brewers in the U.S. And Above Premium also included strong growth by Staropramen across Europe outside of its home market, and cider volume increases with Rekorderlig in Europe and Strongbow in Canada. 
So we -- so kind of on an overall basis, we continue to strengthen our business through improvements to our sales execution and revenue management capabilities, increased efficiency of our operations and implementation of common global systems. 
This is a historic time for -- in the evolution of Molson Coors. 3 weeks ago, we completed our acquisition of the remaining 58% stake in the MillerCoors joint venture, along with Miller global brand portfolio. We emerged as the word's third largest brewer, bringing together Molson Coors and MillerCoors into a bigger, better organization. As one company with an expanded portfolio of iconic brands, we intend to leverage our increased scale, resources and synergies as well as combined commercial experience to accelerate our First Choice agenda and deliver long-term shareholder value. 
On the earnings call earlier this morning, Mauricio also shared perspective regarding 3 new performance measures: transaction, adjusted EPS and all-in multi-year cost savings target and an early view of our combined company underlying free cash flow target for 2017. In addition to any earnings-related questions you may have, we would be happy to answer any questions you have regarding these new or updated performance metrics. 
And finally, for your reference, please note that we have posted full year 2015 and year-to-date 2016 pro forma financial statements on our website to give effects to the MillerCoors acquisition and the related financing, as those were completed on January 1, 2015. 
So with that as an introduction, I'd like to turn it over or open it up for questions. Over to you, Laura.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So this is the long-anticipated follow-up call, where we get clarification on the free cash flow guidance. So I guess, what everyone is kind of trying to reconcile is you've got $6.11 of transaction-adjusted EPS in 2015. That translates to roughly $
componenttext: Okay. So this is the long-anticipated follow-up call, where we get clarification on the free cash flow guidance. So I guess, what everyone is kind of trying to reconcile is you've got $6.11 of transaction-adjusted EPS in 2015. That translates to roughly $1.32 billion in terms of the implied cash flow number. And then, Mauricio, you're guiding to $1.1 billion. So it seems like there is a pretty big step-down even after adjusting for cash restructuring charge. So can you just help us sort of reconcile kind of how we go from 2015 to '17 in terms of free cash flow?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let's see. Let me give you some headlines around that. I don't think I'll be able to reconcile it point-by-point, Judy. But what I would say, I guess, first of all, is we're really dealing with 2 different measures here in a sense that it's like accr
componenttext:
Yes. Let's see. Let me give you some headlines around that. I don't think I'll be able to reconcile it point-by-point, Judy. But what I would say, I guess, first of all, is we're really dealing with 2 different measures here in a sense that it's like accrual accounting versus cash accounting. Said more directly, the free cash flow guidance of $1.1 billion is truly a cash performance measure. The transaction-adjusted EPS number is not a cash performance measure. It actually starts with underlying book EPS and then makes to cash adjustments to kinds of amortization or cash -- and cash tax benefits. So they're really -- at least they're not directly comparable. The types of differences that you'd see between those 2 numbers would be things like pension contributions, cash versus expense. So obviously, the pension cash would be directly reflected in the free cash flow number. But the pension expense number would be reflected in underlying EPS, which is the base for the transaction-adjusted EPS. Another example would be capital expenditures versus depreciation and amortization. Third example would be cash taxes versus booked taxes. And we've talked about the -- more than $275 million of cash tax benefits associated with the transaction, but we have not provided guidance on other cash taxes or on booked taxes. Now those are included in the performance, but we don't have a specific view from a cash standpoint for the free cash flow.
And then finally, capital expenditures needed to capture synergies. As Mauricio mentioned on earlier call, we do anticipate some incremental CapEx related to the -- to capturing synergies. And those who tend be loaded more toward the first 2 years of the 3-year time frame that we talked about as far as cost savings go and -- so that then we can capture the synergies, again as he mentioned, predominantly in years 2 and 3 for those. Although, I would hasten to mention that the other cost savings that we mentioned, non-synergies, in other words, actually are skewed more toward years 1 or 2 of the 3-year time period. Does that give you at least some headlines of why there might be some differences between those 2 numbers?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if I can maybe follow up. So if you start with like '15 to $4.64 of underlying booked EPS at starting point, and then you would add the $275 million of the cash tax benefit?
componenttext: So if I can maybe follow up. So if you start with like '15 to $4.64 of underlying booked EPS at starting point, and then you would add the $275 million of the cash tax benefit?

componenttext: Yes. Right, the $4.64 per share is a pro forma full year 2015 number. And then yes, to that, we would add back the transaction-related amortization, call it a noncash item add back to that, plus you have cash tax benefits of $275 million.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, this is Mauricio. So again, remember when you're talking to the $4.64 and then you add those 2 items to get back to $6.11, you're not talking about cash flow EPS. You're not talking about cash flow per share. You're talking about an EPS per share t
componenttext: Sorry, this is Mauricio. So again, remember when you're talking to the $4.64 and then you add those 2 items to get back to $6.11, you're not talking about cash flow EPS. You're not talking about cash flow per share. You're talking about an EPS per share that's been adjusted by those 2 items. When you -- and if that gets you to $1.3 billion, well, that gets you -- then $1.3 billion is not a cash flow number. It would just be an earnings transaction-adjusted number, but it's not a cash flow number. The $1.1 billion is the cash flow number.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. These are really apples and oranges. To bridge this, Judy, you'd really need to know what our pension cash contributions would be, what the CapEx is going to be. Clearly, we're going to have some incremental CapEx in the early years here as well as t
componenttext: Yes. These are really apples and oranges. To bridge this, Judy, you'd really need to know what our pension cash contributions would be, what the CapEx is going to be. Clearly, we're going to have some incremental CapEx in the early years here as well as things like cash taxes that I mentioned earlier.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So yes -- so what I was going to add is, I mean, if you conceptually think about it, the starting point for both numbers, obviously, is the same, because you start from operating income. But then operating income, what you do is when you want to calculate
componenttext: So yes -- so what I was going to add is, I mean, if you conceptually think about it, the starting point for both numbers, obviously, is the same, because you start from operating income. But then operating income, what you do is when you want to calculate your cash flow number, then you have to add back all the noncash, the depreciation, your CapEx, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera to get to a cash flow number. To get to the earnings number, you just -- you go down the P&L and you get to an earnings number. So those 2 aren't comparable.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we will always see sort of the similar gap between the transaction-adjusted EPS number versus the actual free cash flow number. So the 2017 is kind of the new norm from a free cash flow perspective, and we should think about growing off of that going f
componenttext: So we will always see sort of the similar gap between the transaction-adjusted EPS number versus the actual free cash flow number. So the 2017 is kind of the new norm from a free cash flow perspective, and we should think about growing off of that going forward? Or does the '17 free cash flow number depressed by either onetime cash outflow items or underlying operating income being significantly lower year-over-year?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Judy. 2 points on that. One, yes, there are some -- there will be some onetime cash used items in 2017. We've highlighted CapEx to capture synergies as an example. But second of all, the factors that essentially drive the difference between a
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Judy. 2 points on that. One, yes, there are some -- there will be some onetime cash used items in 2017. We've highlighted CapEx to capture synergies as an example. But second of all, the factors that essentially drive the difference between a free cash flow number and a transaction-adjusted EPS number will move over time. So I can't tell you one -- whether or not the gap will stay similar to that in the future. What I can say is we do have some onetime cash uses in 2017.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's fair. But I mean, I guess, the issue is that we're looking at your transaction-adjusted EPS number to value or at least get a good feel for your underlying earnings power. But if there is a big gap that exist between your EPS versus free cash
componenttext: Okay, that's fair. But I mean, I guess, the issue is that we're looking at your transaction-adjusted EPS number to value or at least get a good feel for your underlying earnings power. But if there is a big gap that exist between your EPS versus free cash flow -- the transaction-adjusted EPS number becomes less meaningful, I think, on people's views. So I think that's sort of the issue that we're trying to kind of reconcile with this kind of the new norm? Or over time, we will get to kind of an underlying free cash flow number that more resembles the transaction-adjusted number that we can then assess your underlying free cash flow generation?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think as I say, without some of the onetime cash uses in 2017, there may be more consistency between the 2. But I'm not going to, how do you say, forecast those for you and whether they will increase or decrease in any particular time frame, be
componenttext: Yes. And I think as I say, without some of the onetime cash uses in 2017, there may be more consistency between the 2. But I'm not going to, how do you say, forecast those for you and whether they will increase or decrease in any particular time frame, because we don't give earnings guidance.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And again, -- this is Mauricio. Judy, let me just reemphasize. So definitely, the onetime effect of the 2017 CapEx required to deliver the synergies, well, that's something that's not going to be recurring. So that's going to obviously increase the free c
componenttext: And again, -- this is Mauricio. Judy, let me just reemphasize. So definitely, the onetime effect of the 2017 CapEx required to deliver the synergies, well, that's something that's not going to be recurring. So that's going to obviously increase the free cash flow going forward if you assume all else being equal from a 2017 base. And then going forward, obviously, all of the accounting and accrual adjustments versus cash adjustments, meaning the idea of showing the transaction-adjusted EPS would simply to give a reflection of the earnings capability of the business once you take that underlying earnings per share and you just -- you adjusted for 2 items that are not evident when you go back in time and look at the pro forma. Of course, going forward, the $275 million of cash tax benefit will be hitting your earnings. It's just that as we went back and we were looking at the earnings in 2015, that's one adjustment that we had to make. So at the end of the day, again, one is an accrual and an accounting measure and the other one is a cash flow measure. Now in that cash flow of the $1.1 billion, you will have the impact of additional interest expense, of the additional taxes that are being paid, et cetera, et cetera.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Brian, did you have something to add as well?

componenttext: This is Brian Tabolt, Controller here at Molson Coors. The one thing just I wanted to clarify, I think, when you're looking at the transaction-adjusted EPS, if you recall, I think when we announced the acquisition last year, one of the key things that we indicated is that the cash tax benefits of now the $275 million, that will not impact our EPS on a go-forward basis. So that's why we -- one of the reasons why we wanted to give you the transaction-adjusted EPS to give you visibility of those tax benefits. But otherwise, it won't come into the competition of our EPS number.

componenttext: Okay. I think it's a little clear. And then just on the transaction-adjusted EPS, so $6.11 now assumes interest expense of $250 million. That's lower than what you had indicated at the September conference. headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the -- that's right. If you look at the pro formas on the left side, you'll see that there is transaction-related interest expense of $250 million that are included in pro forma. And that is a very different number from the interest expense that we g
componenttext: Yes, the -- that's right. If you look at the pro formas on the left side, you'll see that there is transaction-related interest expense of $250 million that are included in pro forma. And that is a very different number from the interest expense that we gave you in the May '12 pro forma, which is the last time we filed them. And that's what I was referring to earlier -- on earlier call when I mentioned the bridge financing. However, compared to the Boston Conference pro forma number of, what was that? $572 million, yes, thanks, Brian, the -- as I think you mentioned, Judy, there is $0.39 change. And actually that was due to 3 main factors. One of them is the increase in the cash tax benefits that we're seeing, that's above $0.12. We're also seeing an adjustment to both amortization and depreciation. But as you know, we strip out booked amortization for transaction-adjusted EPS. However, depreciation, we do not strip out, and that actually was a $0.10 improvement via the purchase accounting work that the accounting team has been doing here. And then the rest of the difference is related to other purchase accounting adjustments, including valuation of assets and liabilities, things like pension and other property, plant and equipment, where they're going to continue to do their work, and you'll actually in all likelihood see additional adjustments, albeit they may be a bit smaller, but additional adjustments in future quarters until in fact the opening balance sheet is locked down 1 year from the close of the transaction.

componenttext: Got it, okay. And then lastly just on the $550 million all-in cost save. Is that the understanding?

componenttext: Well, what you're saying is not inconsistent with what we said on earlier call, which is that right, the synergies are loaded more or skewed a bit more toward years 2 and 3, and the preexisting cost programs are skewed more toward years 1 and 2. And they're roughly equal size between those 2 buckets.
