headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping that you could help us to understand how we should think about your deleveraging plan in terms of when we should think -- or what sort of level we should think about when determining when you could potentially restart, like, your dividend gro
componenttext: I was hoping that you could help us to understand how we should think about your deleveraging plan in terms of when we should think -- or what sort of level we should think about when determining when you could potentially restart, like, your dividend growth or maybe even consider some share buybacks?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me give some headlines, and then we'll see whether Mauricio or Mike want to add some color to that. So our deleveraging plan, obviously, that is our primary focus for capital allocation over the next 2 to 3 years debt pay-down. We want to reduce
componenttext: Sure. Let me give some headlines, and then we'll see whether Mauricio or Mike want to add some color to that. So our deleveraging plan, obviously, that is our primary focus for capital allocation over the next 2 to 3 years debt pay-down. We want to reduce our debt levels in order to maintain our firm commitment to investment-grade ratings, and we have a specific plan with the rating agencies to maintain that investment-grade rating. What I would say as far as specific leverage ratios go, we have not provided one of those publicly. What we have said is that our goal over time is to get to solid investment-grade ratings, which are roughly BBB even. Sorry, and there was one other thing for you. You had asked about dividends and buyback. So dividend, the exact wording that we've used around that is that we will consider our dividend policy. Again, right now, it's being held even on a per share basis per quarter as we pay down debt. And when debt pay-down as well underway, then we can -- we have said that we will be willing to revisit our dividend policy. Buybacks, we've said that we're not going to consider those until the -- our leverage ratios are considerably lower than they are right now. But we haven't put a specific time frame around either one of those.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So how should we think about debt paydown being well underway? I think that's kind of what I'm trying to understand.
componenttext: So how should we think about debt paydown being well underway? I think that's kind of what I'm trying to understand.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I can't give you specific outlook on that. What I can say is that, for example, last time we did a substantial transaction that would be the StarBev transaction in 2012. We, in that instance, had roughly the same language around buybacks and divid
componenttext: Yes. So I can't give you specific outlook on that. What I can say is that, for example, last time we did a substantial transaction that would be the StarBev transaction in 2012. We, in that instance, had roughly the same language around buybacks and dividends. And if I recall correctly, about 1.5 years after we completed the transaction, we actually did increase the dividend and put in place a dividend payout ratio. And then buybacks came later about 3 years, I believe, later essentially.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And in that interim time, I mean, we experienced a double upgrade, for example, from S&P, right? So it all went hand-in-hand with regard to the pace at which we were deleveraging versus when we were evaluating and increasing our dividend.
componenttext: Yes. And in that interim time, I mean, we experienced a double upgrade, for example, from S&P, right? So it all went hand-in-hand with regard to the pace at which we were deleveraging versus when we were evaluating and increasing our dividend.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good add from Mike Rumley, Treasurer. Yes, we -- as we do today, back in 2012, we had a time line and a schedule and a commitment around -- with our rating agencies around debt pay-down and deleverage. And we exceeded that time frame, and to Mike
componenttext: That's a good add from Mike Rumley, Treasurer. Yes, we -- as we do today, back in 2012, we had a time line and a schedule and a commitment around -- with our rating agencies around debt pay-down and deleverage. And we exceeded that time frame, and to Mike's point, received a double upgrade, for example, from S&P in a year or 2 after the transaction.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's fair to think about the deleveraging tracks that S&P and Moody's have put out as sort of a base scenario that we should view as possible in terms of how to think about your deleveraging?
componenttext: So it's fair to think about the deleveraging tracks that S&P and Moody's have put out as sort of a base scenario that we should view as possible in terms of how to think about your deleveraging?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I would say is that our -- we have specific arrangements and commitments with the rating agencies, and we'll let their communications stand on their own. From our standpoint, we intend and we do have a firm commitment to investment-grade ratings. And
componenttext: What I would say is that our -- we have specific arrangements and commitments with the rating agencies, and we'll let their communications stand on their own. From our standpoint, we intend and we do have a firm commitment to investment-grade ratings. And so we obviously understand how important that is, and we intend to meet those commitments.

componenttext: First a mea culpa. I -- that $1.1 billion you've given us for free cash flow next year is now clear to me. That, as you said, has onetime costs and CapEx and it were as transaction-adjusted EPS doesn't. So I was mixing apples and oranges. So I just want to acknowledge that. And then...

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. Appreciate the question though.
componenttext: Okay, understood. Appreciate the question though.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is Mauricio. I wanted -- and again, it is very, very important for us to ensure that this is absolutely clear. So both the transaction-adjusted EPS and the free cash flow number that we gave you, both of those contain these onetime items or the
componenttext: Mark, this is Mauricio. I wanted -- and again, it is very, very important for us to ensure that this is absolutely clear. So both the transaction-adjusted EPS and the free cash flow number that we gave you, both of those contain these onetime items or these adjustments that have been done because of purchase accounting. It's just that the $6.11 per share is an accounting number based on accrual. It is based of a P&L, okay? And the $1.1 billion is a cash flow number. So we start from operating income, and then we make all sorts of adjustment to that number to reflect the actual cash inflows and outflows. So you get to a number of cash flow, which as you know, the cash flow number is not necessarily the same as the underlying earnings number. So per share number for those 2 aren't going to be the same.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, understood and appreciate that. And that's the heart of the matter, because the way we're going to look at the stock is ultimately about the cash flow. So $1.1 billion, not that you've said this, but call it $1.3 billion when you add back the savings
componenttext: Yes, understood and appreciate that. And that's the heart of the matter, because the way we're going to look at the stock is ultimately about the cash flow. So $1.1 billion, not that you've said this, but call it $1.3 billion when you add back the savings-related expenditures you're making. And my question is, can you point us to anything else or is there anything else of any size that's onetime in nature that's a cash expenditure occurring in calendar '17 that is in that $1.1 billion number? Because again, it's just -- this transaction-adjusted EPS as much as we're all going to put it on FactSet and First Call and so forth, it's not going to determine how your stock is valued ultimately. It's a free cash flow. So I'm just trying to understand if there's anything else besides money you're spending to get the $350 million -- I'm sorry, $550 million in savings, the $350 million you're actually spending in cash outlay? Is there anything besides that in that $1.1 billion that you can call out to us, whether it's a pension contribution, something usual in the way of working capital increases? Is there anything else you can call out to us? Or is it indeed just your best guess on an underlying operations basis?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So that's a billion dollar question. Well done. So -- no actually, Mark -- so short answer is no, I can't provide any specifics. But you will and I'm not going to front-run our annual guidance that we normally provide on our February earnings call. A
componenttext: Yes. So that's a billion dollar question. Well done. So -- no actually, Mark -- so short answer is no, I can't provide any specifics. But you will and I'm not going to front-run our annual guidance that we normally provide on our February earnings call. And so you may see some additional, how do you say, detail around that, because that's what we're providing, not just cost guidance, but also some of the CapEx guidance, also pension cash and expense plans for the year, those types of things. So I at this point, I think I would just leave it kind of where I talked about earlier. There are things like pension, CapEx, depreciation -- versus depreciation, I should say, that will come into play at least to some extent. But we're not going to provide any numbers around what that looks like. And -- but you may get some additional clarity on the fourth quarter call.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: And our next question will come from Bryan Spillane of Bank of America.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just a shift, I guess, just some clarity or clarification on the, I guess, the $6.11 of transaction-adjusted EPS for '15? Or I guess, the way I was even looking at it, if I take the first 3 quarters of '16 add the 4Q of '15 to it, I'll get to a trailin
componenttext: So just a shift, I guess, just some clarity or clarification on the, I guess, the $6.11 of transaction-adjusted EPS for '15? Or I guess, the way I was even looking at it, if I take the first 3 quarters of '16 add the 4Q of '15 to it, I'll get to a trailing 12 months of like $6.36. And in that -- I guess, inside that number, now we've got the capital structure, and the cost of the capital structure is included in there, the new effective tax rate for the newco. But -- and then what's not in there is whatever incremental costs there may be related to the MillerCoors international and taking in the Miller brands and then obviously, whatever underlying growth and/or whatever underlying savings there are. Is that -- we're just trying to bridge how we should think about the key system move going forward off of a base. Is that the right way to think about it, or is there something else that needs to be included or excluded?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's all I can think of except for one addition if anybody around the table here thinks of anything else, but it also would not include Miller International brands profit, so whatever that looks like, and to your point, the costs as well.
componenttext: Yes, that's all I can think of except for one addition if anybody around the table here thinks of anything else, but it also would not include Miller International brands profit, so whatever that looks like, and to your point, the costs as well.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bryan, just to add, one another element that's not included in that transaction-adjusted EPS is the deal-related synergies.
componenttext: Bryan, just to add, one another element that's not included in that transaction-adjusted EPS is the deal-related synergies.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, right. So we would effect it for underlying growth, what we think happens to synergies. And then I guess, in terms of the Miller brands, there is 2 pieces, right? We're not -- we don't see the profits, but we do see whatever incremental costs there
componenttext: Right, right. So we would effect it for underlying growth, what we think happens to synergies. And then I guess, in terms of the Miller brands, there is 2 pieces, right? We're not -- we don't see the profits, but we do see whatever incremental costs there may be associated with it?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right. And I think that's the appropriate way to think about it, because as we've said, essentially we're setting up -- we have kind of 3 different approaches to the Miller International brands in the existing areas, geographies or in geograph
componenttext: Yes, that's right. And I think that's the appropriate way to think about it, because as we've said, essentially we're setting up -- we have kind of 3 different approaches to the Miller International brands in the existing areas, geographies or in geographies where we have existing infrastructure like Canada and the U.K., pretty clear what we're going to do there and where we have strong existing partnerships. And that's relatively easy to sort out as well. And then in some of the new markets, where we don't have infrastructure or existing partners, then essentially, you're building a route to market, a supply chain and everything. And so what that P&L looks like is something -- it's work in progress.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one other question related to just free cash flow. And more just conceptually, Mauricio, is there anything about, I guess, the 2 companies having been separate and now merged that would create any potential working capital benefits? Or
componenttext: Okay. And then just one other question related to just free cash flow. And more just conceptually, Mauricio, is there anything about, I guess, the 2 companies having been separate and now merged that would create any potential working capital benefits? Or maybe to put it a different way, was there about the way things were structured previously that made working capital less efficient than maybe there's room for cash savings or working capital improvements going forward?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bryan. Let me give a couple of headlines and then Mauricio may have some additional texture around that, only partly because I have a history. Yes, so MillerCoors, well, we have a PAC model here at Molson Coors. MillerCoors doesn't, strictly speak
componenttext: Thanks, Bryan. Let me give a couple of headlines and then Mauricio may have some additional texture around that, only partly because I have a history. Yes, so MillerCoors, well, we have a PAC model here at Molson Coors. MillerCoors doesn't, strictly speaking, has a PAC model, but they're getting it soon. And Gavin was one of the primary implementers and developers of -- certainly implementers of that in Molson Coors. And -- because they had their own approach to return on invested capital and return on marketing investments and so forth. So there's not a dramatic difference there, but we'll do some alignment there as with a lot of other pieces of the business. There are also some relatively limited differences in working capital between the 2 companies. And as you can imagine, we'll be exploring any improvements we can make there. Mauricio, is there anything you'd add to that?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes -- no. I mean, the only thing that I would add to that is to say, I mean, there is really 3 ways by which we can improve our free cash flow going forward. That's additional earnings, obviously, improvements in working capital and then just a detailed
componenttext: Yes -- no. I mean, the only thing that I would add to that is to say, I mean, there is really 3 ways by which we can improve our free cash flow going forward. That's additional earnings, obviously, improvements in working capital and then just a detailed evaluation of discretionary CapEx, which we always do to our PAC lens. And with respect to working capital, I don't think really that there was anything that wasn't there, because the companies were separate. Nevertheless -- and as Dave correctly pointed out, there's always room for improvement in working capital. We are looking at some specific initiatives, working very closely with the U.S. team with MillerCoors. And hopefully, there will be some interesting benefits coming out of that.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a sense, just as a starting point, if you were to even benchmark it versus other companies or other peer companies? Is it -- is the working capital or cash conversion in the middle, better, worse than kind of what you see as you benchmark
componenttext: Can you give us a sense, just as a starting point, if you were to even benchmark it versus other companies or other peer companies? Is it -- is the working capital or cash conversion in the middle, better, worse than kind of what you see as you benchmark it?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bryan, I guess, wouldn't answer that specifically. But I what I would say is that we care deeply not only about debt pay-down, but therefore free cash flow and cash available to pay down debt. And so we do look at benchmarks. We do look at best pract
componenttext: Yes, Bryan, I guess, wouldn't answer that specifically. But I what I would say is that we care deeply not only about debt pay-down, but therefore free cash flow and cash available to pay down debt. And so we do look at benchmarks. We do look at best practices. And we will, how do you say, address or go after any opportunities that we think are appropriate for business. But no, I wouldn't put a specific number on it.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And the one thing that I would add to that is it's not enough to simply -- I guess, as you're looking at your numbers and comparing to other companies, it's not really enough to look at what companies do with respect to working capital. And -- becaus
componenttext: Yes. And the one thing that I would add to that is it's not enough to simply -- I guess, as you're looking at your numbers and comparing to other companies, it's not really enough to look at what companies do with respect to working capital. And -- because there's always a financial component to that, especially if you think about your payables or your receivables. You would have to be able to understand what the other side of the equation is that is not hitting your balance sheet, but it's actually hitting your P&L in the sense that you may think, for example, in your, I don't know, the way that you manage your payables, you're being very inefficient. But that's not the complete picture until you understand what is the financial benefit that the company would be obtaining in so doing.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oftentimes, there is a trade-off between the length of terms and the cost of terms.
componenttext: Oftentimes, there is a trade-off between the length of terms and the cost of terms.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Next we have a question from Brett Cooper of Consumer Edge Research.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just quickly, we've been talking about cash flow. Is there something that has structurally changed in the business if you look at sort of the past 5 years versus going forward in terms of productivity, whether you start from operating income or start from
componenttext: Just quickly, we've been talking about cash flow. Is there something that has structurally changed in the business if you look at sort of the past 5 years versus going forward in terms of productivity, whether you start from operating income or start from net income? It's a 2017 question this is. The ability to turn operating income or pretax income or net income into cash flow is there. And I'm not asking specifically to '17. But if I'm thinking sort of past 5 years, next 5 years, is there something that has changed in terms of being able to turn if you start with operating income into the cash flows?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. One thing that comes to mind is substantial improvements in our working capital that we've done since 2012. You -- particularly, if you're just looking at the -- if you're looking at the P&L versus the cash flow statement, amortization expense is ver
componenttext: Yes. One thing that comes to mind is substantial improvements in our working capital that we've done since 2012. You -- particularly, if you're just looking at the -- if you're looking at the P&L versus the cash flow statement, amortization expense is very different today than what it was a few years ago. Obviously, we're trying to help you with that with the transaction-adjusted EPS number.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And let me add something here that I'm hoping for all of you on the call will be useful and impending a mental picture of the cash flow. And in this analysis, I'll just to do kind of a top-of-my-head again, sort of the back-of-the-envelope analysis.
componenttext: Yes. And let me add something here that I'm hoping for all of you on the call will be useful and impending a mental picture of the cash flow. And in this analysis, I'll just to do kind of a top-of-my-head again, sort of the back-of-the-envelope analysis. So if you look historically at the capacity to generate free cash flow of the Molson Coors business and then you look at the capacity to generate cash flow of the MillerCoors business and you put the 2 together historically and you say, okay, well, that roughly gives me between $1.3 billion, $1.4 billion. And obviously, you guys are looking and saying, Jesus, but these guys are reporting the $1.1 billion. So what's happening there? So just back-of-the-envelope analysis, you take the $1.3 billion, $1.4 billion, okay? You add the $275 million of benefit that you're getting there, so you're getting around $1.6 billion, okay, of cash generation. But now we're paying $250 million per year more of interest, okay? So you have to deduct that from the $1.6 billion. You get to $1.35 billion, okay? And in addition, you're paying more taxes, because we own the other 58% of MillerCoors. So of your $1.35 billion, deduct another $200 million. That gives you about $1.15 billion. There you go. That's roughly, from a cash flow perspective, how I would look at, okay, how does the $1.1 billion compare to what should be the norm sort of the "normalized cash flow generation potential" of the 2 separate business if you just added the 2 together.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the MCI business has not -- how do you say, we've not said anything additional about MCI getting to flat profit this year, beyond what we've said on our last earnings call, which is that they -- if you exclude the Bihar alcohol prohibition, which
componenttext: Yes. So the MCI business has not -- how do you say, we've not said anything additional about MCI getting to flat profit this year, beyond what we've said on our last earnings call, which is that they -- if you exclude the Bihar alcohol prohibition, which nobody expected starting in April of this year as well as the FX since 2013, which we've been talking about for years, then the MCI business' goal for 2016 was to get to profitability, excluding the Miller International brands. And we have not changed that guidance.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from [indiscernible] of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from [indiscernible] of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually [indiscernible]. We have a question on tax rate that you're saying you're paying higher taxes. Presumably, MillerCoors was paying taxes by buying the rest of the operation, the free cash flow wouldn't add higher taxes in your operation. Coul
componenttext: It's actually [indiscernible]. We have a question on tax rate that you're saying you're paying higher taxes. Presumably, MillerCoors was paying taxes by buying the rest of the operation, the free cash flow wouldn't add higher taxes in your operation. Could you may be clarify those extra taxes you're about to pay? And actually, you would get some relief on -- because of the high leverage?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you for the question. Actually, I'm glad you asked that, because it may not be obvious to a lot of folks. When we bought the other 58% of MillerCoors, that increases our significantly our exposure to profit through cash flow, but we're really t
componenttext: Yes. Thank you for the question. Actually, I'm glad you asked that, because it may not be obvious to a lot of folks. When we bought the other 58% of MillerCoors, that increases our significantly our exposure to profit through cash flow, but we're really talking about profits here, because booked tax rate that we're talking about, increases our exposure to the U.S. business and call it industry and corporate income tax rate, which is among the highest in the world. And so because of the -- I guess, simple migration of pretax income in the direction of U.S. exposure, that results in a higher average blended tax rate. Now to start with though on the 58% of the MillerCoors business that we're buying, we did pay corporate income taxes on that portion, SABMiller out of London paid whatever taxes were due on that via their situation. We paid taxes on a 42% of the MillerCoors portion that we owned. Now we're -- now our income tax rate on average, we expect to be somewhat higher. In fact, the guidance has changed from 18% to 22% for 2016 without the transaction to the 25% to 28% in future years, all else being equal, no changes in tax rate and those types of things. So 25% to 28% on a longer-term basis, including the other 58% of MillerCoors. So you can tell that's several percentage point higher than what we have with the preexisting shape of the business. And if you look -- Kevin reminded me, if you look at the pro forma table on the website, you can see a pro forma tax rate of around 25% for the 2015 full year pro forma number. So there you go. I mean, the tax -- the effective tax rate in the pro forma is in that 25% to 28% range that we've been talking about.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next we have a follow-up question from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And next we have a follow-up question from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the Miller International contribution, so I understand we're not going to incorporate any profit contribution. But just in terms of volume and revenue, because I think you had given the 2014 numbers, but just wanted to get a better sense of kind of
componenttext: So on the Miller International contribution, so I understand we're not going to incorporate any profit contribution. But just in terms of volume and revenue, because I think you had given the 2014 numbers, but just wanted to get a better sense of kind of what the run rate is from a volume and revenue standpoint. And then for Canada piece specifically, just given that you've got extra volume going into that part of the business, should we actually assume better leverages from a margin perspective now that you can absorb more of the volume to your cost structure?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question, Judy. On the -- so Miller International volume, we said as far as the transaction communication, that, that was about 3.2 million hectoliters per year. And we have not changed that point of view. From a revenue standpoint, we've never
componenttext: Yes, good question, Judy. On the -- so Miller International volume, we said as far as the transaction communication, that, that was about 3.2 million hectoliters per year. And we have not changed that point of view. From a revenue standpoint, we've never provided guidance, because actually that was determinant or would be determined by the route to market of the brands in a dozens of markets around the world. For example, in a license market, you have different revenue from a royalty revenue versus a wholly-owned market the amount of revenue. So we have not provided a number on that one. I would put that in the bucket of to-be-determined, similar to some of the comments that Mark made earlier on the call today. From a Canada standpoint, that is an interesting one. When the brands were bought -- the rights of the brands of Canada bought from us about 1.5 years ago or so, they always said about the size of the Miller brands in Canada was mid-single-digit percent of our Canada volume. We have not updated that, and that would be subject to the performance of those brands over the last 1.5 years under SABMiller. And so we'll see what that looks like from a volume standpoint. And would that provide additional leverage, specific to your question? We'll see. We'll see which brands will be produced locally versus imported or what. In other words, that will be one of the details that we'll sort out with you over time. And one thing -- we're not talking about profit, but Bryan made a good point that we do have a purchase price protection on the purchases of the Miller International brand as they existed in SAB system. If the profit trailing 12 months' EBITDA is less than $70 million for that 12-month time period, then there will be a purchase price adjustment that we would negotiate with ABI, and it's sort of ratio of roughly 11.3x.

componenttext: Yes, thank you. Thank you, Dave. Just as a final comment then, I think just going back to Vivian's question in terms of whether we had pro forma 2015 cash flows. However, there is no pro forma 2015 cash flow that will tie to your $1.1 billion. Nevertheless, because the information is there, I just want to -- just to make your life easier, you guys, I mean, it's an exercise that you can try to do yourself in the sense that you know what the underlying free cash flow was for both businesses. So the same exercise that I did for 2017, you yourselves can do for 2015. So you just add the underlying free cash flows of both businesses and with MillerCoors at 100% as well. To that, you add the $275 million of annual tax benefit. From that, you deduct the $200 million of additional tax and the $250 million of additional interest. The only little piece that you wouldn't have is the CapEx that will be spent in 2017 to obtain the synergies. But other than that, the calculation is exactly the same. So that's all I want to say. Dave?

componenttext: Okay. Great. Thanks, Mauricio. Well, in closing, I'd like to thank all of you in your interest in Molson Coors and for joining us today. headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Molson Coors Brewing Company Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Follow-up Session Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now I will turn the call over to Dave Dunnewald, Global Vice President of Investor Relations for Molson Co
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Molson Coors Brewing Company Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Follow-up Session Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now I will turn the call over to Dave Dunnewald, Global Vice President of Investor Relations for Molson Coors. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Laura, and good morning, everyone. On behalf of Molson Coors Brewing Company, thank you for joining us today for our Third Quarter 2016 Follow-Up Earnings Conference Call. Our goal on this call is to address as many additional earnings-related
componenttext:
Thank you, Laura, and good morning, everyone. On behalf of Molson Coors Brewing Company, thank you for joining us today for our Third Quarter 2016 Follow-Up Earnings Conference Call. Our goal on this call is to address as many additional earnings-related questions as possible following our regular earnings conference call with Mark Hunter, Mauricio Restrepo and our business unit CEOs as earlier today. 
We will use a standard question-and-answer format, and we anticipate that the call will last less than an hour. 
Before we begin, I will paraphrase our safe harbor language. Some of our discussion today may include forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from what we project today, so please refer to our most recent 10-K and 10-Q filings for a more complete description of factors that could affect these projections. We do not undertake to publicly update forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future results or otherwise. You should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date they are made. 
Regarding any non-U.S. GAAP measures that we may discuss during the call and from time-to-time by our executives in discussing our company's performance, please visit our website, www.molsoncoors.com, and click on the financial reporting tab at the Investor Relations page for a reconciliation of these measures with the nearest U.S. GAAP results. Also, unless otherwise indicated, all financial results we discuss are versus the comparable prior year period and in U.S. dollars. 
So let's get started with an introduction of the team with me on the call today. First of all, we have Mauricio Restrepo, CFO; Kevin Kim, Investor Relations Senior Manager; Alex Going [ph], Finance Forecasting Manager; Erik Mickelson, Technical Accounting Senior Manager; Brian Tabolt Controller; Mike Rumley, Treasurer; and Mark Saks, VP of Tax. 
Regarding quarterly results, as Mark Hunter mentioned on our regular earnings call this morning, in the third quarter, we continue to focus on First Choice ambition and on building a stronger, broader and more premium brand portfolio underpinned by incremental sales and marketing investments, as we have discussed all year. 
Business highlights for the quarter and year-to-date included increasing net sales revenue per hectoliter on a constant currency basis in all of our businesses for the quarter and for the year-to-date, increased investments in our brands globally. Coors Light and Miller Lite again gained share in the U.S. Premium Light segment, including the highest segment share gain in 3 years for Coors Light. 1.2% global volume growth for Coors Light year-to-date, with growth of more than 14% year-to-date outside of North America. Fast growth innovations in key markets, including Henry's Hard Sodas in U.S. and Mad Jack in Canada. And global growth year-to-date in Above Premium through, for example, Doom Bar and other Sharp's craft brands in the U.K., Creemore Springs and Belgian Moon in Canada and 4 newly acquired brewers in the U.S. And Above Premium also included strong growth by Staropramen across Europe outside of its home market, and cider volume increases with Rekorderlig in Europe and Strongbow in Canada. 
So we -- so kind of on an overall basis, we continued to strengthen our business through improvements to our sales execution and revenue management capabilities, increased efficiency of our operations and implementation of common global systems. 
This is a historic time for -- in the evolution of Molson Coors. 3 weeks ago, we completed our acquisition of the remaining 58% stake in the MillerCoors joint venture, along with Miller global brand portfolio. We emerged as the world’s third largest brewer, bringing together Molson Coors and MillerCoors into a bigger, better organization. As one company with an expanded portfolio of iconic brands, we intend to leverage our increased scale, resources and synergies as well as combined commercial experience to accelerate our First Choice agenda and deliver long-term shareholder value. 
On the earnings call earlier this morning, Mauricio also shared perspective regarding 3 new performance measures: transaction, adjusted EPS and all-in multi-year cost savings target and an early view of our combined company underlying free cash flow target for 2017. In addition to any earnings-related questions you may have, we would be happy to answer any questions you have regarding these new or updated performance metrics. 
And finally, for your reference, please note that we have posted full year 2015 and year-to-date 2016 pro forma financial statements on our website that give effect to the MillerCoors acquisition and the related financing, as if those were completed on January 1, 2015. 
So with that as an introduction, I'd like to turn it over -- or open it up for questions. Over to you, Laura.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So this is the long-anticipated follow-up call, where we get clarification on the free cash flow guidance. So I guess, what everyone is kind of trying to reconcile is you've got $6.11 of transaction-adjusted EPS in 2015. That translates to roughly $
componenttext: Okay. So this is the long-anticipated follow-up call, where we get clarification on the free cash flow guidance. So I guess, what everyone is kind of trying to reconcile is you've got $6.11 of transaction-adjusted EPS in 2015. That translates to roughly $1.32 billion in terms of the implied cash flow number. And then, Mauricio, you were guiding to $1.1 billion. So it seems like there is a pretty big step-down even after adjusting for cash restructuring charge. So can you just help us sort of reconcile kind of how we go from 2015 to '17 in terms of free cash flow?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let's see. Let me give you some headlines around that. I don't think I'll be able to reconcile it point-by-point, Judy. But what I would say, I guess, first of all, is we're really dealing with 2 different measures here in a sense that it's like accr
componenttext:
Yes. Let's see. Let me give you some headlines around that. I don't think I'll be able to reconcile it point-by-point, Judy. But what I would say, I guess, first of all, is we're really dealing with 2 different measures here in a sense that it's like accrual accounting versus cash accounting. Said more directly, the free cash flow guidance of $1.1 billion is truly a cash performance measure. The transaction-adjusted EPS number is not a cash performance measure. It actually starts with underlying book EPS and then makes 2 cash adjustments, 2 kinds of amortization or cash -- and cash tax benefits. So they're really, how do you say, not directly comparable. The types of differences that you'd see between those 2 numbers would be things like pension contributions, cash versus expense. So obviously, the pension cash would be directly reflected in the free cash flow number. But the pension expense number would be reflected in underlying EPS, which is the base for the transaction-adjusted EPS. Another example would be capital expenditures versus depreciation and amortization. Third example would be cash taxes versus booked taxes. And we've talked about the -- more than $275 million of cash tax benefits associated with the transaction, but we have not provided guidance on other cash taxes or on booked taxes. Now those are included in the pro formas, but we don't -- you don't have a specific view from a cash standpoint for the free cash flow.
And then finally, capital expenditures needed to capture synergies. As Mauricio mentioned on the earlier call, we do anticipate some incremental CapEx related to the -- to capturing synergies. And those will tend be loaded more toward the first 2 years of the 3-year time frame that we talked about as far as cost savings go and -- so that then we can capture the synergies, again as he mentioned, predominantly in years 2 and 3 for those. Although, I would hasten to mention that the other cost savings that we mentioned, non-synergies, in other words, actually are skewed more toward years 1 or 2 of the 3-year time period. Does that give you at least some headlines of why there might be some differences between those 2 numbers?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if I can maybe follow up. So you would start with like '15 the $4.64 of underlying booked EPS at starting point, and then you would add the $275 million of the cash tax benefit?
componenttext: So if I can maybe follow up. So you would start with like '15 the $4.64 of underlying booked EPS at starting point, and then you would add the $275 million of the cash tax benefit?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Right, the $4.64 per share is a pro forma full year 2015 number. And then yes, to that, we would add back the transaction-related amortization, call it a noncash item, add back to that, plus you have cash tax benefits of $275 million.
componenttext: Yes. Right, the $4.64 per share is a pro forma full year 2015 number. And then yes, to that, we would add back the transaction-related amortization, call it a noncash item, add back to that, plus you have cash tax benefits of $275 million.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that gets to $1.3 billion roughly? And what do we take out from there?
componenttext: So that gets to $1.3 billion roughly? And what do we take out from there?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, this is Mauricio. So again, remember when you're talking to the $4.64 and then you add those 2 items to get back to $6.11, you're not talking about cash flow EPS. You're not talking about cash flow per share. You're talking about an EPS per share t
componenttext: Sorry, this is Mauricio. So again, remember when you're talking to the $4.64 and then you add those 2 items to get back to $6.11, you're not talking about cash flow EPS. You're not talking about cash flow per share. You're talking about an EPS per share that's been adjusted by those 2 items. When you -- and if that gets you to $1.3 billion, well, that gets you -- then $1.3 billion is not a cash flow number. It would just be an earnings transaction-adjusted number, but it's not a cash flow number. The $1.1 billion is the cash flow number.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. These are really apples and oranges. To bridge this, Judy, you'd really need to know what our pension cash contributions would be, what the CapEx is going to be. Clearly, we're going to have some incremental CapEx in the early years here as well as t
componenttext: Yes. These are really apples and oranges. To bridge this, Judy, you'd really need to know what our pension cash contributions would be, what the CapEx is going to be. Clearly, we're going to have some incremental CapEx in the early years here as well as things like cash taxes and -- that I mentioned earlier.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So yes -- so what I was going to add is, I mean, if you conceptually think about it, the starting point for both numbers, obviously, is the same, because you start from operating income. But then operating income, what you do is when you want to calculate
componenttext: So yes -- so what I was going to add is, I mean, if you conceptually think about it, the starting point for both numbers, obviously, is the same, because you start from operating income. But then operating income, what you do is when you want to calculate your cash flow number, then you have to add back all the noncash, the depreciation, your CapEx, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera to get you to a cash flow number. To get to the earnings number, you just -- you go down the P&L and you get to an earnings number. So those 2 aren't comparable.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we will always see sort of the similar gap between the transaction-adjusted EPS number versus the actual free cash flow number. So the 2017 is kind of the new norm from a free cash flow perspective, and we should think about growing off of that going f
componenttext: So we will always see sort of the similar gap between the transaction-adjusted EPS number versus the actual free cash flow number. So the 2017 is kind of the new norm from a free cash flow perspective, and we should think about growing off of that going forward? Or does the '17 free cash flow number depressed by either onetime cash outflow items or underlying operating income being significantly lower year-over-year?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Judy. 2 points on that. One, yes, there are some -- there will be some onetime cash used items in 2017. We've highlighted CapEx to capture synergies as an example. But second of all, the factors that essentially drive the difference between a
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Judy. 2 points on that. One, yes, there are some -- there will be some onetime cash used items in 2017. We've highlighted CapEx to capture synergies as an example. But second of all, the factors that essentially drive the difference between a free cash flow number and a transaction-adjusted EPS number will move over time. So I can't tell you one -- whether or not the gap will stay similar to that in the future. What I can say is we do have some onetime cash uses in 2017.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's fair. But I mean, I guess, the issue is that we're looking at your transaction-adjusted EPS number to value or at least get a good feel for your underlying earnings power. But if there is a big gap that exist between your EPS versus free cash
componenttext: Okay, that's fair. But I mean, I guess, the issue is that we're looking at your transaction-adjusted EPS number to value or at least get a good feel for your underlying earnings power. But if there is a big gap that exist between your EPS versus free cash flow -- the transaction-adjusted EPS number becomes less meaningful, I think, on people's views. So I think that's sort of the issue that we're trying to kind of reconcile with this, is kind of the new norm? Or over time, we will get to kind of an underlying free cash flow number that more resembles the transaction-adjusted number that we can then assess your underlying free cash flow generation?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think as I say, without some of the onetime cash uses in 2017, there may be more consistency between the 2. But I'm not going to, how do you say, forecast those for you and whether they will increase or decrease in any particular time frame, be
componenttext: Yes. And I think as I say, without some of the onetime cash uses in 2017, there may be more consistency between the 2. But I'm not going to, how do you say, forecast those for you and whether they will increase or decrease in any particular time frame, because we don't give earnings guidance.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And again, -- this is Mauricio. Judy, let me just reemphasize. So definitely, the onetime effect of the 2017 CapEx required to deliver the synergies, well, that's something that's not going to be recurring. So that's going to obviously increase the free c
componenttext: And again, -- this is Mauricio. Judy, let me just reemphasize. So definitely, the onetime effect of the 2017 CapEx required to deliver the synergies, well, that's something that's not going to be recurring. So that's going to obviously increase the free cash flow going forward if you assume all else being equal from a 2017 base. And then going forward, obviously, all of the accounting and accrual adjustments versus cash adjustments, meaning the idea of showing the transaction-adjusted EPS was simply to give a reflection of the earnings capability of the business once you take that underlying earnings per share and you just -- you adjust it for 2 items that are not evident when you go back in time and look at the pro forma. Of course, going forward, the $275 million of cash tax benefit will be hitting your earnings. It's just that as we went back and we were looking at the earnings in 2015, that's one adjustment that we had to make. So at the end of the day, again, one is an accrual and an accounting measure and the other one is a cash flow measure. Now in that cash flow of the $1.1 billion, you will have the impact of additional interest expense, of the additional taxes that are being paid, et cetera, et cetera.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, did you have something to add as well?
componenttext: Brian, did you have something to add as well?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Brian Tabolt, Controller here at Molson Coors. The one thing just I wanted to clarify, I think, when you're looking at the transaction-adjusted EPS, if you recall, I think when we announced the acquisition last year, one of the key things that we
componenttext: This is Brian Tabolt, Controller here at Molson Coors. The one thing just I wanted to clarify, I think, when you're looking at the transaction-adjusted EPS, if you recall, I think when we announced the acquisition last year, one of the key things that we indicated was that the cash tax benefits of, now the $275 million, that will not impact our EPS on a go-forward basis. So that's why we -- one of the reasons why we wanted to give you the transaction-adjusted EPS to give you visibility of those tax benefits. But otherwise, it won't come into the computation of our EPS number.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And they provide obviously real value for the company and our shareholders. Go ahead, Judy.
componenttext: And they provide obviously real value for the company and our shareholders. Go ahead, Judy.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I think it's a little clearer. And then just on the transaction-adjusted EPS, so $6.11 now assumes interest expense of $250 million. That's lower than what you had indicated at the September conference. So is that one difference where now the intere
componenttext: Okay. I think it's a little clearer. And then just on the transaction-adjusted EPS, so $6.11 now assumes interest expense of $250 million. That's lower than what you had indicated at the September conference. So is that one difference where now the interest expenses is $250 million, and that's kind of what we should be using going forward from an interest rate perspective?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the -- that's right. If you look at the pro formas on the left side, you'll see that there is transaction-related interest expense of $250 million that are included in pro formas. And that is a very different number from the interest expense that we
componenttext: Yes, the -- that's right. If you look at the pro formas on the left side, you'll see that there is transaction-related interest expense of $250 million that are included in pro formas. And that is a very different number from the interest expense that we gave you in the May '12 pro formas, which is the last time we filed them. And that's what I was referring to earlier -- on earlier call when I mentioned the bridge financing. However, compared to the Boston Conference pro forma number of, what was that? $572 million, yes, thanks, Brian, the -- as I think you mentioned, Judy, there is $0.39 change. And actually that was due to 3 main factors. One of them is the increase in the cash tax benefits that we're seeing, that's above $0.12. We're also seeing an adjustment to both amortization and depreciation. But as you know, we strip out booked amortization for transaction-adjusted EPS. However, depreciation, we do not strip out, and that actually was a $0.10 improvement via the purchase accounting work that the accounting team has been doing here. And then the rest of the difference is related to other purchase accounting adjustments, including valuation of assets and liabilities, things like pension and other property, plant and equipment, where they're going to continue to do their work, and you'll actually in all likelihood see additional adjustments, albeit they may be a bit smaller, but additional adjustments in future quarters until in fact the opening balance sheet is locked down 1 year from the close of the transaction.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. And then lastly just on the $550 million all-in cost save. So the phasing of that, it sounds to me like it's evenly spread out over 3 years, but the first part being more skewed to kind of the legacy cost savings and then year 2 and 3 more f
componenttext: Got it, okay. And then lastly just on the $550 million all-in cost save. So the phasing of that, it sounds to me like it's evenly spread out over 3 years, but the first part being more skewed to kind of the legacy cost savings and then year 2 and 3 more from the cost synergies perspective. Is that the understanding?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Well, what you're saying is not inconsistent with what we said on earlier call, which is that, right, the synergies are loaded more or skewed a bit more toward years 2 and 3, and the preexisting cost programs are skewed more toward years 1 and 2. And they're roughly equal size between those 2 buckets.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: And our next question will come from Priya Ohri-Gupta of Barclays.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping that you could help us to understand how we should think about your deleveraging plan in terms of when we should think -- or what sort of level we should think about when determining when you could potentially restart, like, your dividend gro
componenttext: I was hoping that you could help us to understand how we should think about your deleveraging plan in terms of when we should think -- or what sort of level we should think about when determining when you could potentially restart, like, your dividend growth or maybe even consider some share buybacks?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me give some headlines, and then we'll see whether Mauricio or Mike want to add some color to that. So our deleveraging plan, obviously, that is our primary focus for capital allocation over the next 2 to 3 years, is debt pay-down. We want to re
componenttext:
Sure. Let me give some headlines, and then we'll see whether Mauricio or Mike want to add some color to that. So our deleveraging plan, obviously, that is our primary focus for capital allocation over the next 2 to 3 years, is debt pay-down. We want to reduce our debt levels in order to maintain our firm commitment to investment-grade ratings, and we have a specific plan with the rating agencies to maintain that investment-grade rating. What I would say as far as specific leverage ratios go, we have not provided one of those publicly. What we have said is that our goal over time is to get to solid investment-grade ratings, which are roughly BBB even. 
Sorry, and there was one other thing for you. You had asked about dividends and buyback. So dividend, the exact wording that we've used around that is that we will consider our dividend policy. Again, right now, it's being held even on a per share basis per quarter as we pay down debt. And when debt pay-down as well underway, then we can -- we are -- we have said that we will be willing to revisit our dividend policy. Buybacks, we've said that we're not going to consider those until the -- our leverage ratios are considerably lower than they are right now. But we haven't put a specific time frame around either one of those.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So how should we think about debt paydown being well underway? I think that's kind of what I'm trying to understand.
componenttext: So how should we think about debt paydown being well underway? I think that's kind of what I'm trying to understand.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I can't give you specific outlook on that. What I can say is that, for example, last time we did a substantial transaction, that would be the StarBev transaction in 2012, we in that instance had roughly the same language around buybacks and divide
componenttext: Yes. So I can't give you specific outlook on that. What I can say is that, for example, last time we did a substantial transaction, that would be the StarBev transaction in 2012, we in that instance had roughly the same language around buybacks and dividends. And if I recall correctly, about 1.5 years after we completed the transaction, we actually did increase the dividend and put in place a dividend payout ratio. And then buybacks came later about 3 years, I believe, later essentially.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And in that interim time, I mean, we experienced a double upgrade, for example, from S&P, right? So it all went hand-in-hand with regard to the pace at which we were deleveraging versus when we were evaluating and increasing our dividend.
componenttext: Yes. And in that interim time, I mean, we experienced a double upgrade, for example, from S&P, right? So it all went hand-in-hand with regard to the pace at which we were deleveraging versus when we were evaluating and increasing our dividend.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good add from Mike Rumley, Treasurer. Yes, we -- as we do today, back in 2012, we had a time line and a schedule and a commitment around -- with our rating agencies around debt pay-down and deleverage. And we exceeded that time frame, and to Mike
componenttext: That's a good add from Mike Rumley, Treasurer. Yes, we -- as we do today, back in 2012, we had a time line and a schedule and a commitment around -- with our rating agencies around debt pay-down and deleverage. And we exceeded that time frame, and to Mike's point, received a double upgrade, for example, from S&P in -- a year or 2 after the transaction.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's fair to think about the deleveraging tracks that S&P and Moody's have put out as sort of a base scenario that we should view as possible in terms of how to think about your deleveraging?
componenttext: So it's fair to think about the deleveraging tracks that S&P and Moody's have put out as sort of a base scenario that we should view as possible in terms of how to think about your deleveraging?

componenttext: What I would say is that our -- we have specific arrangements and commitments with the rating agencies, and we'll let their communications stand on their own. From our standpoint, we intend and we do have a firm commitment to investment-grade ratings. And so we obviously understand how important that is, and we intend to meet those commitments.

componenttext: First a mea culpa. I -- that $1.1 billion you've given us for free cash flow next year is now clear to me. That, as you said, has onetime costs and CapEx and it were as transaction-adjusted EPS doesn't. So I was mixing apples and oranges. So I just want to acknowledge that. And then...

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. Appreciate the question though.
componenttext: Okay, understood. Appreciate the question though.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: But Mark, this is Mauricio. I wanted -- and again, it is very, very important for us to ensure that this is absolutely clear. So both the transaction-adjusted EPS and the free cash flow number that we gave you, both of those contain these onetime items or
componenttext: But Mark, this is Mauricio. I wanted -- and again, it is very, very important for us to ensure that this is absolutely clear. So both the transaction-adjusted EPS and the free cash flow number that we gave you, both of those contain these onetime items or these adjustments that have been done because of purchase accounting. It's just that the $6.11 per share is an accounting number based on accrual. It is based of a P&L, okay? And the $1.1 billion is a cash flow number. So we start from operating income, and then we make all sorts of adjustments to that number to reflect the actual cash inflows and outflows. So you get to a number of cash flow, which as you know, the cash flow number is not necessarily the same as the underlying earnings number. So per share number for those 2 aren't going to be the same.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, understood and appreciate that. And that's the heart of the matter, because the way we're going to look at the stock is ultimately about the cash flow. So $1.1 billion, not that you've said this, but call it $1.3 billion when you add back the savings
componenttext: Yes, understood and appreciate that. And that's the heart of the matter, because the way we're going to look at the stock is ultimately about the cash flow. So $1.1 billion, not that you've said this, but call it $1.3 billion when you add back the savings-related expenditures you're making. And my question is, can you point us to anything else or is there anything else of any size that's onetime in nature that's a cash expenditure occurring in calendar '17 that is in that $1.1 billion number? Because again, it's just -- this transaction-adjusted EPS as much as we're all going to put it on FactSet and First Call and so forth, it's not going to determine how your stock is valued ultimately. It's the free cash flow. So I'm just trying to understand if there's anything else besides money you're spending to get the $350 million -- I'm sorry, $550 million in savings, the $350 million you're actually spending in cash outlay? Is there anything besides that in that $1.1 billion that you can call out to us, whether it's a pension contribution, something usual in the way of working capital increases? Is there anything else you can call out to us? Or is it indeed just your best guess on an underlying operations basis?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So that's a billion dollar question. Well done. So -- no actually, Mark -- so short answer is no, I can't provide any specifics. But you will -- and I'm not going to front-run our annual guidance that we normally provide on our February earnings call
componenttext: Yes. So that's a billion dollar question. Well done. So -- no actually, Mark -- so short answer is no, I can't provide any specifics. But you will -- and I'm not going to front-run our annual guidance that we normally provide on our February earnings call. And so you may see some additional, how do you say, detail around that, because that's what we're providing, not just cost guidance, but also some of the CapEx guidance, also pension cash and expense plans for the year, those types of things. So at this point, I think I would just leave it kind of where I talked about earlier. There are things like pension, CapEx, depreciation -- versus depreciation, I should say, that will come into play at least to some extent. But we're not going to provide any numbers around what that looks like. And -- but you may get some additional clarity on the fourth quarter call.

componenttext: And our next question will come from Bryan Spillane of Bank of America.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: So just a shift, I guess, just some clarity or clarification on the, I guess, the $6.11 of transaction-adjusted EPS for '15? Or I guess, the way I was even looking at it, if I take the first 3 quarters of '16 add the 4Q of '15 to it, I get to a trailing 12 months of like $6.36. And in that -- I guess, inside that number, now we've got the capital structure, and the cost of the capital structure is included in there, the new effective tax rate for the newco. But -- and then what's not in there is whatever incremental costs there may be related to the MillerCoors international and taking in the Miller brands and then obviously, whatever underlying growth and/or whatever underlying savings there are. Is that -- as we're just trying to bridge how we should think about the pieces to move going forward off of a base. Is that the right way to think about it, or is there something else that needs to be included or excluded?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's all I can think of except for one addition, if anybody around the table here thinks of anything else, but it also would not include Miller International brands profit, whatever that looks like, and to your point, the costs as well.
componenttext: Yes, that's all I can think of except for one addition, if anybody around the table here thinks of anything else, but it also would not include Miller International brands profit, whatever that looks like, and to your point, the costs as well.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bryan, just to add, one another element that's not included in that transaction-adjusted EPS is the deal-related synergies.
componenttext: Bryan, just to add, one another element that's not included in that transaction-adjusted EPS is the deal-related synergies.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, right. So we would effect it for underlying growth, what we think happens to synergies. And then I guess, in terms of the Miller brands, there's 2 pieces, right? We're not -- we don't see the profits, but we do see whatever incremental costs there
componenttext: Right, right. So we would effect it for underlying growth, what we think happens to synergies. And then I guess, in terms of the Miller brands, there's 2 pieces, right? We're not -- we don't see the profits, but we do see whatever incremental costs there may be associated with it?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right. And I think that's the appropriate way to think about it, because as we've said, essentially we're setting up -- we have kind of 3 different approaches to the Miller International brands in the existing areas, geographies or in geograph
componenttext: Yes, that's right. And I think that's the appropriate way to think about it, because as we've said, essentially we're setting up -- we have kind of 3 different approaches to the Miller International brands in the existing areas, geographies or in geographies where we have existing infrastructure like Canada and the U.K., pretty clear what we're going to do there and where we have strong existing partnerships. And that's relatively easy to sort out as well. And then in some of the new markets, where we don't have infrastructure or existing partners, then essentially, you're building a route to market, a supply chain and everything. And so what that P&L looks like is something -- it's work in progress.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one other question related to just free cash flow. And more just conceptually, Mauricio, is there anything about, I guess, the 2 companies having been separate and now merged that would create any potential working capital benefits? Or
componenttext: Okay. And then just one other question related to just free cash flow. And more just conceptually, Mauricio, is there anything about, I guess, the 2 companies having been separate and now merged that would create any potential working capital benefits? Or maybe to put it a different way, was there about the way things were structured previously that made working capital less efficient than maybe there's room for cash savings or working capital improvements going forward?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bryan. Let me give a couple of headlines and then Mauricio may have some additional texture around that, only partly because I have a history. Yes, so MillerCoors, well, we have a PACC model here at Molson Coors. MillerCoors doesn't, strictly spea
componenttext: Thanks, Bryan. Let me give a couple of headlines and then Mauricio may have some additional texture around that, only partly because I have a history. Yes, so MillerCoors, well, we have a PACC model here at Molson Coors. MillerCoors doesn't, strictly speaking, have a PACC model, but they're getting it soon. And Gavin was one of the primary implementers and developers of -- certainly implementers of that in Molson Coors. And -- but they've had their own approach to return on invested capital and return on marketing investments and so forth. So there's not a dramatic difference there, but we'll do some alignment there as with a lot of other pieces of the business. There are also some relatively limited differences in working capital between the 2 companies. And as you can imagine, we'll be exploring any improvements we can make there. Mauricio, is there anything you'd add to that?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes -- no. I mean, the only thing that I would add to that is to say, I mean, there is really 3 ways by which we can improve our free cash flow going forward. That's additional earnings, obviously, improvements in working capital and then just a detailed
componenttext: Yes -- no. I mean, the only thing that I would add to that is to say, I mean, there is really 3 ways by which we can improve our free cash flow going forward. That's additional earnings, obviously, improvements in working capital and then just a detailed evaluation of discretionary CapEx, which we always do to our PACC lens. And with respect to working capital, I don't think really that there was anything that wasn't there because the companies were separate. Nevertheless -- and as Dave correctly pointed out, there's always room for improvement in working capital. We are looking at some specific initiatives, working very closely with the U.S. team with MillerCoors. And hopefully, there will be some interesting benefits coming out of that.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a sense, just as a starting point, if you were to even benchmark it versus other companies or other peer companies? Is it -- is the working capital or cash conversion in the middle, better, worse than kind of what you see as you benchmark
componenttext: Can you give us a sense, just as a starting point, if you were to even benchmark it versus other companies or other peer companies? Is it -- is the working capital or cash conversion in the middle, better, worse than kind of what you see as you benchmark it?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bryan, I guess, wouldn't answer that specifically. But what I would say is that we care deeply not only about debt pay-down, but therefore free cash flow and cash available to pay down debt. And so we do look at benchmarks. We do look at best practic
componenttext: Yes, Bryan, I guess, wouldn't answer that specifically. But what I would say is that we care deeply not only about debt pay-down, but therefore free cash flow and cash available to pay down debt. And so we do look at benchmarks. We do look at best practices. And we will, how do you say, address or go after any opportunities that we think are appropriate for business. But no, I wouldn't put a specific number on it.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And the one thing that I would add to that is it's not enough to simply -- I guess, as you're looking at your numbers and comparing to other companies, it's not really enough to look at what companies do with respect to working capital. And -- becaus
componenttext: Yes. And the one thing that I would add to that is it's not enough to simply -- I guess, as you're looking at your numbers and comparing to other companies, it's not really enough to look at what companies do with respect to working capital. And -- because there's always a financial component to that, especially if you think about your payables or your receivables. You would have to be able to understand what the other side of the equation is that is not hitting your balance sheet, but it's actually hitting your P&L in the sense that you may think, for example, in your, I don't know, the way that you manage your payables, you're being very inefficient. But that's not the complete picture until you understand what is the financial benefit that the company would be obtaining in so doing.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oftentimes, there is a trade-off between the length of terms and the cost of terms.
componenttext: Oftentimes, there is a trade-off between the length of terms and the cost of terms.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
